From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, May 05, 2016 4:55 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Sr. Video Producer says "Cisco is just ok."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Sr. Video Producer says "Cisco is just ok."

From Cisco Systems Sr. Video Producer (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Thu, 5 May 2016

Pros
The line of work is interesting, and mostly cool projects to work on. My direct team is great. Stable. Work from home option is great.

Cons
There is a definite corporate politics atmosphere, where schmoozing is important the higher up you are. I have experienced a culture of entitlement from execs who believe the world revolves around them.

Advice to Senior Management
Whether you are a blue badge or a red badge, an executive VP or just an intern, when someone is working their butt off to help you, human kindness and humility go a long way.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10507213.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10507213.htm>

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Company - Toxic First Line Management"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Thu, 5 May 2016

Pros
Great company to work for, well meaning executive management. Great employee friendly policies. Good mobility between groups.

Cons
Toxic first line management, no empathy, slave drivers and makes me wonder how & why they promote these clowns.

Advice to Senior Management
Be careful when you promote individual contributors to first line management and train them. Watch them for first year, hear to employee 360 and remove those who do not make a cut.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, May 04, 2016 2:19 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Work Life Balance"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Work Life Balance"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 4 May 2016

Pros
Cisco is one of the few companies that actually provides a true work life balance. Heavy adoption of their collaboration technologies allows for working from home when not traveling.

Cons
Rapid shift in technology over the past few years has resulted in numerous layoffs. Cisco is hiring but weeding out those that aren't adapting to the new world. This should be done once vs many smaller actions.

Advice to Senior Management
Performing the required reduction in headcount once and be done with it. The numerous smaller reductions take a toll on morale. Mobility in the company is limited if you aren't in San Jose.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10492976.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10492976.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Mixed feelings"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 4 May 2016

Pros
Flexible working hours; Good overall health benefits

Cons
A lot of politics to play; Management change frequently, and not every leader understands the business; The idea to change to open space is a bad call. It works some people, but not ALL; No cap award, little recognition, and no salary raise for years; Re-org, lay-off is norm every summer;

Advice to Senior Management
Be consistent, and focus on the right business, and do the right thing. Trust the team, and give the IC enough authority to explore.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, May 01, 2016 9:30 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Product Manager says "Great place to work, strong future outlook"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Product Manager says "Great place to work, strong future outlook"

From Cisco Systems Product Manager (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sun, 1 May 2016

Pros
Strong work/life balance, Opportunity to work remotely, Improved market position in collaboration, Large organization but trying to bring in agile/startup culture and renovating a lot of the HQ offices with open floor spaces, etc. Would recommend working here to others.

Cons
Large organization still in the process of becoming more agile, so the bureaucracy and slow pace can be a hinderance at times. Many Cisco lifers are passionate about what they're working on, but some seem to be along for the ride, only to do the minimal amount of work necessary (I'm sure most large companies experience this). Lots of senior leadership changes in recent years leads to frequent strategic changes and internal bickering at times.

Advice to Senior Management
I'd suggest focusing on promoting the strong performers and removing the less productive team members. It sounds obvious but doesn't seem to be the case.

Comments (1) <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10457055.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10457055.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, May 01, 2016 2:03 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Software Engineer Intern"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Software Engineer Intern"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sun, 1 May 2016

Pros
Really nice people (both current employees and interns) Great work life balance Perks: Free & on-campus gym with classes, transportation reimbursement Nice location (I was in San Jose, CA) Although I wish the work was more challenging, I had a positive experience overall. My boss was helpful, gave great feedback, and was generally very supportive.

Cons
I didn't have that much to do project-wise which I found to be common with a lot of other interns Culture can be bureaucratic and typical of a large company

Advice to Senior Management
Have a few projects for your interns, even if they're small it's better than nothing.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, April 29, 2016 8:08 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Great Place. Changed a lot in the time I was there."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Great Place. Changed a lot in the time I was there."

From Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 29 Apr 2016

Pros
I worked with leaders in the field. If you needed to talk to an expert in a given protocol or product you just picked up the phone. Communication was very open. I have nothing but respect for those I worked with.

Cons
Eventually (after over 10 years there)I had to leave to grow my career. In Advanced Services if you don't work at it you can get pigeon-holed.

Advice to Senior Management
At the time I left in 2012, Cisco was deep into outsourcing and offshoring mature software products. The reasoning was sound but in some cases rushed.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, April 28, 2016 11:36 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Good company, waste management"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Good company, waste management"

From Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 4 of 4 found this helpful — Thu, 28 Apr 2016

Pros
Good company. You get to work on latest technologies, good HR policies. I have worked in cisco for 6+ years, this company is NOT what it used to be. Good place for freshers to start your career.

Cons
Management is a waste. Boot lickers get the perks, hikes, growth while hard workers get nothing. Too much of management hierarchy. Performance reviews are an eyewash- Manager does what he feels like. Managers practicing regionalism etc Frequent secret layoffs ...

Advice to Senior Management
Managers should me more educated, should understand employee pain points, growth aspects etc. Recognise employee for his/her hard work.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Intern says "Business Analyst"

From Cisco Systems Intern (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Thu, 28 Apr 2016

Pros
Job is very flexible. It allows you to work from home and be more productive.

Cons
The fast pace doesn't allow you to solve issues properly. Quick fix is not the best way to create productive processes.

Advice to Senior Management
Some managers specially in Customer Assurance Business Intelligence need to be more professional and treat people with respect. The unprofessional attitude of one specific manager damage the entire organization. Cisco needs to hire and retain managers with people skills who enjoy helping others to succeed without asking to pay any help back. Cisco in general seems to be a very good company, but needs to get rid of those who put the Cisco name down. HR needs to take action on this type of issue in order to fix the company image.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, April 27, 2016 5:22 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "Great perks,slow growth,does not like to challenge status quo"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "Great perks,slow growth,does not like to challenge status quo"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Wed, 27 Apr 2016

Pros
Great perks Above average compensation Work from home (WFH) Good technical exposure

Cons
The work gets hectic sometimes. Most of the time you will end up working 10-12 hours a day.Your life becomes Cisco if are not careful. Slow growth specially when you join in grade 8.This is crowded grade and you will have to wait till eternity to get promoted. Yes sir culture. If you challenge the decision of your manager, you are screwed and your growth will be hampered. Overall perks used be great but not anymore. They are taking way benefits one by one. May be in future it will not have as many perks as used to be.

Advice to Senior Management
Have transparent appraisal system. Management takes their own decision regarding promotion and growth and do not feel the need to inform engineers. No HR Exists in Cisco to take care of your issues..so try to have one if you care.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, April 26, 2016 11:26 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Project Manager says "Not in Kansas any more"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Project Manager says "Not in Kansas any more"

From Cisco Systems Project Manager (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 26 Apr 2016

Pros
Great caliber of people to work with. The best and brightest in all areas. Fast paced, great comp and benefits

Cons
Recent years have seen a shift in corporate culture. Thought Cisco has always been focused on profit and growth it was always done with the employees in mind. Recent pressures of the stock holders and the IT market have seen a shift to more main stream corporate operating cultures. Lay-offs are more common in Cisco now and there is less alignment between what the CEO "says" is the focus and what is actually executed. The word "family" has a diminished meaning in the Cisco culture. Less reward for performance at the discretion of line managers.

Advice to Senior Management
Don't loose site of what made Cisco great and able to grow to be the giant that it is.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10399711.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10399711.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, April 26, 2016 10:48 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer says "Market Transitioning"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer says "Market Transitioning"

From Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 26 Apr 2016

Pros
Good work-life balance, manager is supportive and hands-off, newer buildings are furnished nicely, snacks available in new buildings, gym has everything you can ask for.

Cons
Cisco has been stuck in a "market transition" over the last few years. Although our profits are still good, we've still yet to capitalize on the "internet of everything".

Advice to Senior Management
More transparency from the upper management in the direction of things to come. Don't just blurt out big words. I want to see more graphs and tables on our performance, and concrete things we're doing to take things to the next level.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10399127.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, April 25, 2016 5:19 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco through Vendor"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco through Vendor"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 25 Apr 2016

Pros
Cisco has some very difficult problems to solve and is a good place to find enterprise-level design issues in nearly all IT functions. Compensation is decent, more so if you are a remote contributor. Remote contribution is not only possible but the norm in many sub-groups within IT functions where that is possible. (i.e. web work)

Cons
If working through a vendor you may be required to fund your own travel to your department site and this may vary from occasional to often depending on function; this must be considered. Working with offshore teams is expected in many groups and this may result in some odd working hours. Culture can be poor to non-existent, especially for remote workers, be prepared to bring your own.

Advice to Senior Management
Convert more of your best contingent staff to salaried employees once their skill and commitment is apparent.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10390525.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10390525.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, April 24, 2016 6:30 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sun, 24 Apr 2016

Pros
Good work-life balance makes working there very appealing. Cisco embraces telecommuting and has all the tech to make this happen.

Cons
Constant reorganization makes it difficult to gain momentum in your career. HR is a partner for upper management and usually on visible during reorganizations or layoffs.

Advice to Senior Management
Start a genuine process about employee development. Employees are very US centric. Need to start thinking more globally and encouraging employees to do so well. International assignments would be a great start.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, April 22, 2016 1:09 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Awesome place to work"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Awesome place to work"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Fri, 22 Apr 2016

Pros
great benefits, work life balance, love the CEO, in a great place in the market. whats not to love?

Cons
not many cons. i'm in finance, so i don't see the stress of the TS employees or delivery. the work is HARD, but engaging and a great development opportunity.

Advice to Senior Management
focus more on the market and where Cisco makes sense to fit. we doubled down on the cloud, but don't think we had a strategy in place. execs need to work together. its embarrassing seeing VPs not communicating or interlocking the way that finance analysts do - you're the leadership of the company, so act like it.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, April 22, 2016 11:39 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Associate says "Corporate Development Associate"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Associate says "Corporate Development Associate"

From Cisco Systems Associate (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Fri, 22 Apr 2016

Pros
Overall, colleagues were simply awesome. Everyone is super friendly but your experience completely depends on the people you work with and the vertical you are in. If your vertical isn't a focus area, you'll probably be bored. If your vertical is a focus area, you will get absolutely smoked but learn a ton. Fridays are pretty laid back. If you aren't on a deal, you should be able to work from home or SF if interested. Relocation assistance is probably best-in-class....make sure to ask for it $10-20K. It's baked into your fully burned opex cost, so theoretically the org has planned for it. Don't be afraid to ask: get the offer and then ask HR. Bus Shuttle from SF->SJC Yearly off-site Executive exposure - you sit on the same floor as C-suite and work with SVPs often. The engineers are super nice and approachable.

Cons
Wages stay flat YoY. No inflation adjustment for junior deal team members. Working remotely isn't really an option outside of Friday Unreal revolving door environment Work/life balance can be non-existent OG environment

Advice to Senior Management
Allow applicants to meet their potential team in person before joining even if it's a junior role. Small teams are a marriage. TelePresence isn't the same thing as meeting someone in person. It's not aggressive to expect an inflation adjustment. The bay area is kind of expensive and younger employees rarely own property. If you get called back while on PTO, you shouldn't have to cover the cost of the ticket and other miscellaneous expenses...that's just mean.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10361717.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10361717.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, April 22, 2016 9:48 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Director says "Overall, very good place to work"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Director says "Overall, very good place to work"

From Cisco Systems Director (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 22 Apr 2016

Pros
Fast paced environment (for a big company); Smart people that work hard and play hard. Genuinely committed to our customers success

Cons
Has become too bureaucratic; internal systems not built for shift to cloud/SaaS models, yearly layoffs hurt morale (we'll see if Chuck changes this); too many layers of management

Advice to Senior Management
Chuck Robbins has breathed new life into Cisco, with more direct communications and monthly roundtables where all questions are fair game. Continue to engage and communicate with employees and the Cisco culture will flourish. Also, be mindful of hiring practices so we don't become like every other large tech company that has annual layoffs.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10360384.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10360384.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, April 19, 2016 7:57 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader says "Not what I was expecting, but so far it's been awesome!"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader says "Not what I was expecting, but so far it's been awesome!"

From Cisco Systems Technical Leader (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 19 Apr 2016

Pros
I was always afraid of joining a behemoth of a company: afraid to lose my creativity and individuality. Of course, you're a small fish in a large ocean at Cisco, but I've come to realize/understand that everything (your enjoyment, focus, motivation, loyalty, and on and on) hinges directly on the business unit (BU) and managing chain you're brought into. I was extremely fortunate to have landed in an up-and-coming BU that is constantly heralded as a "do not fail" BU which really keeps you positive. If anything, do your homework and talk to multiple people that work directly in or with your team under the same direct chain of management and pray you'll not be working under an old-school type that refuses to learn new technologies and practices. Some of those guys refuse to accept that it's 2016 and the world has moved on :) Below are some things I find great about working here (keeping in mind both my manager and director are wicked smart and easy-going if you're a hard worker and can prove you're a solid engineer): * a fantastic work from home policy - I refuse to uproot my family and slog it out in CA where home prices are 4-5x more, so I get an income that basically no other local company can match in overall compensation without moving more into the senior manager/VP positions * benefits are great - my family uses the high deductible plan which works well for us if you can build up enough buffer in your HSA and take advantage of the hundreds of dollars of HSA incentives; paid life insurance; paid short- and long-term disability * structured bonus plan - the bonus is nothing to laugh at and is extremely welcome; it's tied to both your performance (kind of derived by your manager) and the companies metrics (customer service quality, shareholders, revenue, etc) but if both do well your percentage goes up * 4.5% match, immediately vested, 401k-roth option, brokerage option, bonus matching, bonus stock (4-year vesting) * BU-dependent, but budget for training, conferences, books, classes, etc are all very good if you choose to use them * perks galore - I guess I didn't realize that with thousands of employees comes greater purchasing power, so various discounts on anything from Whirlpool appliances and movie tickets, to reduced cell phone bills and (I kid you not) solar panel installs. You may not use all of what's available or even care, but to even provide so many different ways to save you cash on things you're going to buy will lead to more compensation * the career path and income increases in all former jobs has been engineer, senior engineer, (maybe principal), manager, glass ceiling...then what? More management? At Cisco they have two paths: management and engineering. The roles and responsibilities increase as you go up levels in either of those paths, as well as the pay and perks, however, they understand that good engineers may want to remain engineers, and they reward their great ones accordingly. I think this is in my top 3.

Cons
* Kind of an ongoing reorganization (aka, forced layoffs) discussion that seems to have been a strong theme the last few years, but nothing really negative as happened yet. I believe there's a severance package if this does happen to you? * Like many places, your peers could be complete duds, which forces you to pick up their slack or else the entire team including yourself look terrible...but, without any "real" guidelines in place to let these people go they kind of hang around and leach off the company and their peers * I've been here over a year and through various conversations with my peers I've discovered that I should probably be a level above where I'm at now, however it is not really clear at all how you move up

Advice to Senior Management
* Find a way to weed out the bad eggs from the solid, capable engineers. Some of them are literally stealing money from you by not working. And try to do it in a way where you insulate the good engineers from getting caught up in a "re-org" net. * The benefits, perks, pay, etc are all stellar in my opinion and I think really sets Cisco apart from some of the competitors. Keep that up and reward your workforce for staying. * Keep innovating to attract new talent to fuel the future. I think some of the recent moves at the higher levels have been truly great and hopefully will stabilize soon so everyone can focus on the mission.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10327794.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10327794.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, April 18, 2016 7:11 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Great company and overall work experience"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Great company and overall work experience"

From Cisco Systems Program Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 18 Apr 2016

Pros
-breadth of project and program work -have grown my responsibilities tremendously. Company gives you opportunity to grow -competitive compensation and benefits -the work from home perk is bar none. i make my own schedule around work.

Cons
-so vast and process laden, really difficult to get things done swiftly -super slow release cycles -the offices are really crappy looking and dated (except for 1-2 buildings in SJ) -all that work from home makes you feel like a shut in -all that work from home drives an email culture which is slow and less collaborative -alot of waste, inefficiency, and lack of basic tech proficiency -insane amounts of managing up

Advice to Senior Management
look for ways and workers who improve efficiency and let them lead. stop employing wasteful people. Stop the managing up cycle and do some of your job as actual managers.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, April 17, 2016 4:28 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems IT Intern says "Summer Internship Review"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems IT Intern says "Summer Internship Review"

From Cisco Systems IT Intern (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sun, 17 Apr 2016

Pros
As an intern, I felt there was a real camaraderie among all the interns, and this was encouraged by the managers. Also, the managers I worked under were results oriented. They did not care whether you were an intern or full time worker, and they treated both equally. Once my manager was aware of my skills, he gave me just as much responsibility as any other employee, and I felt I fit in with my team very well.

Cons
A downside of being treated exactly like the other employees was that since this was my first internship, or even real job, at moments I did feel a bit overwhelmed at times since I wasn't used to work like that. However, it was comforting that the managers thought highly enough of my skills to give me such assignments.

Advice to Senior Management
The internship program is very well done, and I have few complaints with the way those things were done. That program can be kept the way it is. Perhaps, ensure that the interns have time to participate in the events, along with the assignments.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10299896.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Individual Contributor says "Review on Cisco Systems India"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Individual Contributor says "Review on Cisco Systems India"

From Cisco Systems Individual Contributor (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Fri, 15 Apr 2016

Pros
Good Company if you are in the right group and with the right manager

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, April 13, 2016 1:18 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Sales says "Great technology, talent"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Sales says "Great technology, talent"

From Cisco Systems Sales (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 13 Apr 2016

Pros
Some very talented people. Those who perform will succeed. Poor performers usually weeded out. Products, solutions, and services that can be confidently sold. Good work/life balance.

Cons
High pressure. Always a looming feeling of impending restructuring. Trend towards reducing overheads by hiring lower-cost early-in-career resources. This is a pro if you're early-in-career.

Advice to Senior Management
Frequent transparent communication does a lot to instill confidence in the workforce, even when the news is bad. Don't keep them guessing.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, April 13, 2016 8:43 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Acquisitions says "Decent place to work"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Acquisitions says "Decent place to work"

From Cisco Systems Acquisitions (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 13 Apr 2016

Pros
Great people to work with. At times work is challenging. Not so hard to move around between groups. Relentless focus on execution, however, sometime ready, fire, aim. Biggest plus is Flexible work - just get your work done, people don't care where you are (That said, some groups do)

Cons
Very big - tiny cog in big machine - hard to make a difference Constant focus on you adjusting to change - just not changing any of the pre-year 2000 systems. Lots of talk about digitization, but operationally really falling behind - unable to support new business models Promotions are very hard. Raises and high bonuses are only really given to top performers

Advice to Senior Management
Focus on making Cisco easy to do business with. You make partners work too hard. If it were easier, you'd make a lot more money off of the partners. Also stop doing share buy-backs and invest in the company. Rebecca is clearly not the one to revamp the antiquated operational infrastructure - bit the bullet and modernize.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10254801.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10254801.htm>

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing says "Big Company with all the pros and cons"

From Cisco Systems Marketing (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 12 Apr 2016

Pros
Great work/life balance (integration) Good benefits -- they take care of employees Liberal telecommuting policy Great technology -- constantly trying out newest collaboration technologies so even when you are remote the work is pretty seamless Great co-workers International business -- exposed to a lot of variables and situations Strong organizational integrity and values

Cons
Intensely political environment Large disparities between organizations -- sales-driven machine and so sales gets the bulk of the attention and rewards Incredibly bureaucratic Little opportunity for advancement or promotion -- static organization that drives out top performers

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, April 12, 2016 1:38 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Controller"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Controller"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 12 Apr 2016

Pros
Cisco is a company that believes treating its employees well and invests heavily to maintain that culture. The even have things like on site day care, a really nice gym, and on site doctors with a pharmacy. As far as the business is concerned it is still a monster generating a lot of cash but it still primarily comes from Routing and Switching - a market that is being disrupted.

Cons
Lots of red tape and politics. In recent years the company has had little growth and with a lower turnover rate due to a good work environment it creates challenges for people to move up even when they are more than ready.

Advice to Senior Management
Focus more on results and less on what looks good. Often times what looks good gets rewarded over actual results.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10244907.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, April 12, 2016 10:41 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Company Review"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Company Review"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 12 Apr 2016

Pros
- Strong and passionate community committed to Cisco's success - Smart people - Leadership honors commitment to grow people by giving rotation opportunities across the company

Cons
- Frequent organizational adjustments can be disruptive at times. Have seen resources change direct reporting relationships four times within 2 months. - Can be a fair amount of politics across teams, although no worse than I've seen at other companies.

Advice to Senior Management
Recommend that leadership continues to candidly address the direction of the company and ongoing changes. Since change is inevitable, maintaining the open dialogue and giving insight into the thinking of the leadership team will be important to keep employees focused, happy and moving in the same direction.

From Cisco Systems Systems Engineer III (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 11 Apr 2016

Compensation is good, still many talented teams within the company.

Cons
Annual turned quarterly layoffs (~5%), no loyalty to employees or contractors. No innovation outside of 2-3 key products. Outsourcing. Company is becoming politicized and pushing things such as H1-B visa expansion.

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Business Analyst III says "Old School"

From Cisco Systems Business Analyst III (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Thu, 7 Apr 2016

Pros
This is a large company with great benefits. They love to hire from within and there are lots of opportunities.

Cons
Cisco has gone to the layoff model to management. Their people have become disposable while middle management continues to grow and protect each other. There are too many managers with an inconsistent message. Half of the managers appreciate their employees and work with them to help them advance in their careers. Others want people that are going to stay in the same job forever.

Advice to Senior Management
Start showing your employees they matter instead of just disposing of them.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, April 05, 2016 4:18 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco Life"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco Life"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 5 Apr 2016

Pros
Excellent benefits that allow for flexibility. Working remotely is supported and made possible by our amazing collaboration technology (WebEx, TelePresence, Jabber, and more). You're encouraged to innovate in your job and try something new if it will benefit a program. People are very open and friendly to newcomers. I've found that people are generally willing to share their career journeys and lessons learned. Plenty of internal development opportunities (stretch assignments, rotations, internal reqs, etc).

Cons
It's a big company, so it takes a while to know who to contact to get things done quickly.

Comments (1) <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10166080.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10166080.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, April 05, 2016 12:44 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Mechanical Product Engineer says "Cisco Employee Feedback"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Mechanical Product Engineer says "Cisco Employee Feedback"

From Cisco Systems Mechanical Product Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 5 Apr 2016

Pros
Helping Culture, Flexible and collaborative communication tools. Empowerment to achieve best customer experience. Changing physical environment to promote morale.

Cons
Took away our stock options, felt like abandoning us from feeling ownership in the company. For the veterans that have been there since year 2000, many feel that our underwater stock options should have been replaced with new ones, since we stuck it through supporting the company in the ups and downs. Lack of salary adjustments for veterans who have been in the company 15+ yrs

Advice to Senior Management
in the recent 3 years. Management has really changed and are open to making changes to boost morale. I think this is great and should be continued to stay competetive in the valley. Bring back some more small perks, like soft drinks, more team lunches, etc.

Comments (1) <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10163463.htm>

From Cisco Systems Intern (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 5 Apr 2016

Pros
Great field experience and exposure to a fast pace corporate environment. Impossible not to learn something about work or yourself every day. You will have stuff to do all the time.

Cons
Bureaucracy and rigid even though some of the "start up" perks are trying to be thrown in to make the place seem hip.

Advice to Senior Management
Youths are more interested in working in a place that thinks like a start up rather than one that desperately tries to look like one. I think some organizational changes could be made to lessen the burden of hierarchy. Maybe the culture will change on its own over time.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, April 05, 2016 10:56 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Systems Engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Systems Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 5 Apr 2016

Pros
The company is more open to teleworking than most. The products are solid and the technology is interesting. Benefits are competitive.

Cons
Career opportunities are limited. If you don't live near a corporate office, you'll be limited. If you are an account manager, you can become CEO. If you are an engineer, you'll always be an engineer. Very few are allowed to escape the title.

Advice to Senior Management
The company seems more reactive than it has in the past. It has compensated well for previous missteps but I don't know if future challenges will be avoided or not.

Pros
Great employee support, ancillary benefits and encouragement to explore and participate in all areas of the business to help network cross-functionally. Cutting edge technology, excellent management, feels like family.

Cons
Large company any way you slice it. My group seemed excessively political leaving control in the hands of someone that should not have control.

Advice to Senior Management
Continue cross-fertilizing of ideas and making every effort to make the company feel small--this will help when competing against smaller more nimbler companies for employees.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, April 03, 2016 8:16 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Bad engineering has its cost"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Bad engineering has its cost"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Sun, 3 Apr 2016

Pros
Good pay, good benefits. Free coffee.

Cons
Whatever you do avoid the projects that manage large numbers of servers. Poor engineering of products. Documentation is lacking. In my job the debug / edit / compile cycle was approximately 1 hour (versus a few minutes at most other companies). This is due to bad choices made in engineering, and the cost on current employees is very high. Cisco does not "eat its own dogfood." So the complex task of managing hundreds of servers is not deployed at Cisco. Furthermore, the company isn't willing to invest much in hardware. You'll be forced to use "simulators" to debug things, being that there is no big set of hardware to use. Also, if you are not Asian you may not "fit in". Don't expect the other employees to be very friendly or helpful.

Advice to Senior Management
Hire managers with integrity.

Comments (1) <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10140621.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10140621.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, April 03, 2016 10:44 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Hi Tec Innovator"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Hi Tec Innovator"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Sun, 3 Apr 2016

Pros
Investment and focus on innovation makes it an exciting place to work. Culture from top management of respecting individuals flows down and across the company.

Cons
Many managers lack the management skills to truly develop their teams. Company has the people process but not a culture that promotes excellence in management of people. Too much of the innovation investment and energy is wasted. Don't always see the tangible results delivered.

Advice to Senior Management
Strengthen the link between excellence in management, measurement of results and the innovation investment.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, April 02, 2016 10:38 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Senior Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Senior Manager"

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sat, 2 Apr 2016

Pros
Big company, a lot to learn. Complex business processes, good place to polish your business and management skills. Prepare yourself to be worked to death since everything is around California time which makes it very tough for employees outside the US to take on calls, TPs, etc at normal hours since they will have to adapt to Pacific time.

Cons
Too political. Corporate is not fully aware of what happens in the regions, same people have been running the regions for years and have formed silos and closed environments that make it impossible for other people to move up.

Advice to Senior Management
Investigate what happens in the regions and make sure you rotate the key positions to allow fresh ideas to come in and benefit the operation.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10133400.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10133400.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, April 02, 2016 2:58 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing says "Good Company with Some Issues Around Upward Mobility and Stuffiness"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing says "Good Company with Some Issues Around Upward Mobility and Stuffiness"

From Cisco Systems Marketing (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sat, 2 Apr 2016

Pros
Cisco provides good compensation, benefits, and (with many positions) flexibility to work remotely. The people who work at Cisco are intelligent, respectful and nice.

Cons
As an older tech company the culture can be a bit stuffy. Cisco is trying to fix this and encourage young people to come/stay but there is still work that needs to be done.

Advice to Senior Management
Upward mobility is limited by the fact that there are so many people that have been at Cisco for 10+ years. This is a good thing in terms of showing the loyalty that employees have, but is not good for keeping new employees around.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10131020.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, April 02, 2016 9:45 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "Very Good work culture"

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, April 01, 2016 11:12 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Precarious for contractors"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Precarious for contractors"

From Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Fri, 1 Apr 2016

Pros
Good people, good resources, good projects. The contract pay was quite good. I had some excellent managers and team members.

Cons
Apparently there is some sort of rule that the Cisco manager you report to cannot provide any type of feedback. My manager seemed to be great. Every time we met on the phone, he acted as if all was well. He never provided any feedback or coaching. He was very friendly. I was offered a full time position many times, but had to turn it down because the pay was nothing short of abysmal. Then, a very hostile customer complained about me for a rather invalid reason. My project manager and team had my back and were in my corner. They all explained to my manager that I was not at fault. Suddenly, my contract was terminated. No explanation, no communication. I tried to talk to him just to understand, but he completely cut me off and wouldn't talk to me. If you are thinking about contracting at Cisco, then I strongly caution you. If you are perfect, then all will be well. If you do anything that causes the slightest bit of concern, then your contract will be terminated. They won't warn you, they won't talk to you, they'll just give you the ax. There is a very stark difference between contractors ("Red Badges") and employees ("Blue Badges"). Contractors get a paycheck and absolutely nothing else. That is to be expected in many situations, but I wanted to make it clear for those less experienced in contracting.

Advice to Senior Management
Would it kill you to provide feedback to your people? Even if they are contractors? Can you not provide the slightest bit of coaching? Can you not talk frankly to your teams and give them the knowledge they need for improvement?

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10120979.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10120979.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, March 28, 2016 11:32 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Sr Product Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Sr Product Manager"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 28 Mar 2016

Pros
Lots of smart people around Great company to learn how to handle complex business problems Very flexible work culture even when you have lots of deliverables to handle Competitive salary if you do not compare it to the top 5% highest paying companies in the valley

Cons
Cisco is in the middle of lots of leadership changes; lots of confusion around company direction Switching business, which is 1/3rd the entire companies business is going through a lot of confusion

Advice to Senior Management
There are lots of great leaders in the company as has been the case for couple of decades now. Some of the higher management people are trying to do the right things for the company whereas some of them are too worried about their own growth within the company. That is creating a lot of struggle for the company to have a solid overarching vision and execution of that vision. Please unite.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10074169.htm>

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "New Product Program Manager"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 28 Mar 2016

Pros
Great daycare program and convenient health center. On-site gym for employees to use from 6am to 9pm. Year-end shutdown across the company for one week. Most managers are open to working from home 1-2 days a week.

Cons
Compensation package is low compared to other companies in the valley. Company does not have a well promoted career development program to allow rotations for individual contributors. Hence not enough opportunities within the company for rotation to get experience outside of your domain.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, March 28, 2016 6:07 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Cisco"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Cisco"

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Mon, 28 Mar 2016

Pros
Cisco is a well-established company. It has a solid stock value. The company has a strong footprint in all six continents. Its brand is well-known internationally.

Cons
Cisco portfolio is not focused and is all over the map. They try to compete in niche markets that are not well-suited for the company core business. They do not have much potential for growth.

Advice to Senior Management
Focus on core deliverables and less on all the shiny new objects. When it comes to initiatives, Cisco is known for now following through, ending up with half-baked internal products that suffer from lack of funding. There is a continuous focus on the new shiny objects rather than perfecting what is already there.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10071530.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10071530.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, March 28, 2016 8:18 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "So far so good"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "So far so good"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 28 Mar 2016

Pros
Plenty of resources, intelligent people, nice campus. If you're smart and capable, and can network (people-wise), you'll be fine here. If you're coming in from a jack-of-all-trades background and going in to a silo, make sure you understand that you're in a silo now and some things are not your responsibility.

Cons
You're in a silo where you're not allowed to fix things you might know how to fix. Like other big companies, some tasks are outsourced to folks that follow a script, which can make troubleshooting slow and onerous.

Advice to Senior Management
None right now - most of what I've seen has been positive. There's a drive to improve things internally, to recognize hard works, and provide the right kinds of resources.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10064147.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10064147.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, March 27, 2016 1:05 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer says "poor management, great opportunity"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer says "poor management, great opportunity"

From Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sun, 27 Mar 2016

Pros
Great company, lots of online training and equipment you can borrow and setup labs.

Cons
Working with other department is difficult. Most TAC try to avoid taking ownership. Everyone cares more about closing tickets than customer service. Most engineer do the bare minimum to close the ticket. This is probably due to management and their concerns with metrics.

Advice to Senior Management
Metric is not everyone. Just because someone have less service request doesn't mean they are doing the right thing, vice versa. Last, expectation from Cisco Manager and Contractor is not on the same page. One care more about certifications, while the other care more about metrics.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, March 25, 2016 5:48 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Love Cisco!"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Love Cisco!"

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Fri, 25 Mar 2016

Pros
Great outlook, great opportunity, will be the #1 IT Company in the world (if not already there), a super-survivor, awesome & super-smart colleagues, great benefits, global presence, aspiring to given women more opportunities (and half the Senior Leadership team is women), conveys great San Francisco Bay Area values and respect for people

Cons
Can end up working off-shift or after hours due to the global nature of the IT Industry, however this is balanced with mostly accepting & flexible managers -- to be honest, there are no real "Cons" in working for Cisco, unless the commute is killing you...

Advice to Senior Management
Consider more streamlined marketing messaging, ie focus on a few top-level campaigns, with other messaging supporting these -- not sure that the general public can speak to what a great company Cisco is based on current messaging.

Comments (1) <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10046116.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, March 25, 2016 3:02 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Acquire and Destroy"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Acquire and Destroy"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 25 Mar 2016

Pros
Compensation is higher than normal for Greater Atlanta Area IT sector. If you're in the right group, you can be shielded from most of the upper level management shenanigans, politics and bad business decisions. If you're not in the right group - all bets are off.

Cons
Cisco has a habit of acquiring companies and then destroying them. This is certainly the case with their acquisition of Scientific Atlanta, all traces of which will certainly cease to exist within the next two years. Upper level management is a revolving door and there is a high level of chaos as folks scramble to maintain employment - often working on projects that have very little chance of succeeding.

Advice to Senior Management
Streamline and focus on doing a few things well, rather than doing a large number of things badly.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10044973.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10044973.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, March 24, 2016 12:45 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Marketing Manager says "Incompetent Marketing Leadership"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Marketing Manager says "Incompetent Marketing Leadership"

From Cisco Systems Senior Marketing Manager (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 4 of 4 found this helpful — Thu, 24 Mar 2016

Pros
Flexible schedules, telecommuting, and great people to work with. Some employees truly know their stuff and interested in making a difference.

Cons
Lots of politics as middle managers who have been with the company for years try to hide their inadequacies. No discipline or accountability. Check-list marketing approach as opposed to trying to understand and build relationship with customer. Constant layoffs of very capable people. Lots of employees do the minimum to get by. Management tries to be hip by offering "bring your dog to work" pilot, free snacks, and one free lunch/week.

Advice to Senior Management
Quit the cheerleading, focus on accountability, and make things happen.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10032364.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW10032364.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Business Analyst says "Cruise Control"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Business Analyst says "Cruise Control"

From Cisco Systems Business Analyst (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 22 Mar 2016

Pros
The most comfortable job you can get - especially in operations. Very few deliverables, low expectations and option for remote work allows for unrivaled work life balance.

Cons
Not a lot of direction or unity. Powerpoint and politic-driven culture. Incentive is to identify a problem, build a team, and then drag it out as long as possible.

Advice to Senior Management
Trim the fat and pay half the people twice as much. Give up on the RTP location strategy - costing top talent.

Pros
Great people, great compensation, great job security. A big company with the possibility of transferring to other areas of the business.

Cons
Your input is minimal. Upper management change the strategy as often as they are changed. Don't expect to have any real impact on the products.

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Test Engineer says "An old company with no where to go but down"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Test Engineer says "An old company with no where to go but down"

From Cisco Systems Network Test Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Sun, 20 Mar 2016

Pros
Company has lots of different technologies to pick from. If you have the opportunity to get in, it's a great place to start a career, but with the intention of leaving 1-2 years into the job.

Cons
1) Tons of red tape 2) Processes for everything. If there isn't a process, it can't be done and changing the process is nearly impossible. 3) Seemingly yearly layoffs 4) Not particularly innovative. 5) Depending on your management, YMMV.`

Advice to Senior Management
My management was awful. I would advise that Cisco work on providing leadership to their teams, or allowing those in the team that can lead the ability to do so.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, March 20, 2016 2:16 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Database Performance Tuner"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Database Performance Tuner"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — Sun, 20 Mar 2016

Pros
Good entry level position at a prestigious company. The people are friendly and there perks here that help enhance the working conditions.

Cons
Most of the workers in my department are non-citizens from either India or Pakistan, who tend to know very low skilled. Many contractors are laid off or retained on a quarterly basis, depending on the quarterly budget. This creates a tense atmosphere since many workers worry if they'll still have a job in a couple of months. No one should have to work with a sword constantly hanging over their heads like that. So, I'm not thrilled with Cisco's abusive hiring practices, which prioritizes low cost over qualified workers.

Advice to Senior Management
Invest more resources and time in training up your workers AND in maintaining their skill levels.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9977817.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9977817.htm>

Do not loose talent people as part of re-organization

Pros
Lots of networking opportunities as an intern to learn about various departments and functions at Cisco.

Cons

Perhaps it may have just been bad luck on my part getting an internship on a team that did not value giving projects to MBA interns that would be challenging.

Advice to Senior Management

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, March 17, 2016 1:18 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Low Level Engineer Doing the Work says "Low level management Apalling"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Low Level Engineer Doing the Work says "Low level management Apalling"

From Cisco Systems Low Level Engineer Doing the Work (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 4 of 4 found this helpful — Thu, 17 Mar 2016

Pros
Good pay and benefits. Can be interesting work in the write department. Top level and bottom level workers are good at what they do. If you have good social skills and want to climb up the ladder then there are good opportunities if your face fits.

Cons
Lower management is a joke and more like a boys club. Priorities are themselves, then the project then if there is any time/energy left their staff. They lack of knowledge on how to handle exceptional engineers/people, the ones who come with side effects, so good is the best they will get/keep. The top people at the bottom (i.e. the engineers doing the work) often do not have great social skills and management can't handle them no matter how good they are at their job of for the project.. You have to spend more time looking after your career than doing the job if you want to climb, it's not a place to survive at the bottom level for long. If you want to stay hand's on then Cisco isn't for you no matter how good you are.

Advice to Senior Management
Look at the lower management. Promote moral of workers. Stop looking for faults in the staff and look/exploit their good points.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9954284.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9954284.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, March 17, 2016 10:19 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer I says "Campus Hires are paid more than Engineers with 3-4yrs experience"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer I says "Campus Hires are paid more than Engineers with 3-4yrs experience"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer I (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Thu, 17 Mar 2016

Pros
Work is chilled out, not very challenging... Even if it was challenging/engaging at any time, i never had to move beyond my comfort zone to meet expectations. Cab service is good. New buildings are good (BGL17,18). Older buildings look like 10yr old govt offices

Cons
Pay is pretty low compared to market standards. They don't seem to normalize salaries. New campus hires are paid more than Software Engineer-II (3-4 yr exp band) annual increments are usually around 10% and on promotion around 5-10%.

Advice to Senior Management
Management needs to address growing attrition rate. pay is much lower than market value for the ppl working in cisco. The only place where they make an effort to correct it is in campus hiring (they do this only for the fear of not getting enough candidates from NITs and IITs, as companies visiting their campuses offer much more) but the problem is they hire college freshers paying much more than existing employees in cisco, like college freshers who have joined 3-4 yrs ago. Management is doing a very poor job when it comes to normalizing pay, and there exists vast disparity in pay within the organization. 3yrs exp person getting lower pay than a fresh college hire in the same team is fundamentally wrong. No self respecting engineer will continue to stay in the organizations after learning about this kind of disparity. However the management seems to be ignoring this issue and i didnt get a proper response when i raised it. Ultimately, there is very high attrition rate in the 0-8yrs experience bracket, primarily due to low pay.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9951849.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9951849.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, March 16, 2016 8:09 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Watch your back"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Watch your back"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 16 Mar 2016

Pros
The people and benefits at Cisco are generally good. The company is highly focused on areas of strategic importance and growth. You want to work in one of these areas of the business.

Cons
Not unique to Cisco, a high percentage of managers and above are only interested in promoting themselves. Managers truly interested in developing members of their teams are rare. If you are in an area of the business that is stable or declining you need to watch your back. Limited Restructuring has become the norm for cutting headcount (costs) on a regular basis. With few exceptions, senior management exempts themselves from such accountability resulting in productive people being cut. Very little opportunity for advancement.

Advice to Senior Management
Leadership sometimes requires developing emerging technology and business models that compete with the status quo.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9936115.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9936115.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, March 16, 2016 6:54 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Service Delivery Manager says "Service Delivery Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Service Delivery Manager says "Service Delivery Manager"

From Cisco Systems Service Delivery Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 16 Mar 2016

Cons

Advice to Senior Management
Improve hierarchal communication throughout the company, and better determine how to position new services in the marketplace.

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 15 Mar 2016

Pros
I worked in the Bangalore office. - Great Campus and a lot of activities/extra-curricular that one can involve in - good cafeteria, gym, TT, air hockey, massage chair and what not! :D

Cons
I worked in one of the teams under NOSTG (Network Operating System Group). I had joined as a fresher. The work was boring as hell. It was a 15 year old legacy product and the work involved bug fixing and responding to customer issues. No development work as such. Would never recommend a fresher to join the company.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, March 13, 2016 10:58 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Engineer says "Hire/Fire, Rename portfolio, Change team names, Change managers, Rinse and Repeat"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Engineer says "Hire/Fire, Rename portfolio, Change team names, Change managers, Rinse and Repeat"

From Cisco Systems Network Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sun, 13 Mar 2016

Pros
You have a job until you can find a new one. Your colleagues all know the game there, it is just a job for now...most people will be gone within a year, that is usually everyone's plan. The contract agencies like Apex and Insight just keep billing Cisco 40-50% more than you are paid so at least you know up front there is no loyalty or expectations of a long-term career here.

Cons
You will be asked to work "off the clock" as an hourly employee. I have lost count of how many times I have heard this happening in all different departments (Telepresence, activations, security, foundations, etc.) Any questions about this violation in law and ethics will be perceived as you "not being a team player" and you will be getting a call from your agency asking you to lock your workstation and turn in your badge. ***READ your contract agencies fine print *** you are giving up time and a half ("overtime"), you are paying about 7% more in payroll taxes, you are basically forced to accept a dispute resolution waiver that prevents you from suing them when they ask you to lie on your time card each week. You probably won't get to work during the last 2 weeks of December b/c of their shutdown period, which means red badges don't get paid. No agency provides PTO or sick time, their 401Ks and medical benefits are horrible horrible -- be careful what you accept, you will be sorry you didn't ask for a lot more on your hourly contract if you don't consider these things ahead of time. Every tool, ticketing system, support team, account team, technical team you work with will be excessively difficult, broken and unwilling to change. They prey on the young/recent grads and people new to IT. They are stuck in the 90s on pay and have the highest turnover rate I have ever seen. I watched over 30 people either quit, get laid off, or let go in just 12 months.

Advice to Senior Management
Management changes so often it won't matter. This company is living off their past and their big contracts from big fish companies who are run much in the same way who simply can't un-hook from the chains of their past Cisco investment (for now). How about take a long look at all the PMs, engagement managers, delivery managers and other people who can't even spell a single technical word -- who work remotely almost 100% of the time, yet produce nothing for the teams they supposedly represent. I know first hand many who play video games all day at home, forward a couple of emails and call it a day. Must be nice. Meanwhile those of us who have engineering degrees, certifications and over 20 years experience are dumped on all hours of the day, night, weekends and don't get anything in return for it. Once again, people with no technical skills who try to dress nice, use MBA jargon are running something that used to be great (because of R&D/technology -- you know, actually PRODUCING something of value instead of putting lip stick on a pig) right in to the ground. But fear not, Cisco will just do mass layoffs once or twice a year to try to hide the reality of this once great company now sinking away. Go white box networking startups! Put the nail in this now IBM-like company so technology can actually move forward again.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9900172.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9900172.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, March 12, 2016 5:23 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great big company with good startup agility"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great big company with good startup agility"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sat, 12 Mar 2016

Pros
For a public giant, Cisco makes a noble effort to stay current with industry standards and best practices with its team org and culture. Mature company with a healthy drive among its senior-level leadership to run with the kids.

Cons
Changes can still be a bit slow within the massive machine. Lots of established processes and playbooks, so coloring outside lines can be at own risk ( not to say you can't, just do so with aware caution ).

Advice to Senior Management
Don't buy to kill competition but maybe take a lesson from the Starbucks / La Boulange transaction and try to merge and coexist or spin back out for happier resolution.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, March 10, 2016 8:33 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great work/life balance, not so great transparency"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great work/life balance, not so great transparency"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Thu, 10 Mar 2016

Pros
Truly flexible work culture. Majority of meetings conducted virtually, means you can work from anywhere in the world, and that's actually OK. Work load is average overall, and team members and leaderships are very understanding different circumstances.

Cons
Very thick layer of mid-manager level. Very difficult or long years to be promoted. Frequent org. changes, many cases no direction in business decisions.

Advice to Senior Management
Seriously revisit the competitive edge in current talent marketplace, and implement retention strategy to keep and pull top talents.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, March 09, 2016 12:41 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer Director says "Systems Engineer Director"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer Director says "Systems Engineer Director"

From Cisco Systems Systems Engineer Director (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 9 Mar 2016

Pros
I joined Cisco in 1995 and left in 2014. The company I joined was not the company I left. The culture of family existed in the 1990's and early 2000's. The products, technologies, and people were fantastic and still are very good.

Cons
Cisco now does what large companies do, which is annual layoffs. Sometimes these layoffs are actually ongoing just aren't reported as they are below 3% of the total employee population. This systemic issue leads to a culture of CYA and backstabbing, especially at executive levels.

Advice to Senior Management
Bring the original values back to life. Treat all employees as family and focus on performance vs style...aka managing up rather than leading the team and business.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9858076.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9858076.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II says "Software Engineer II"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II says "Software Engineer II"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer II (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 7 Mar 2016

Pros
Flexible work hours Process driven Employee oriented policies Work anywhere in the campus Obviously, this is applicable for employees working as Cessna.

Cons
Slide in the personal growth - Easy to climb two or three steps up the ladder, but after that it is all downhill. One constantly needs to indulge in stuff other than work to go up the ladder faster than others. Less hike - If not for promotion, the yearly hike is pretty less. The management does not listen to the employee qualms and queries. Often I kept hearing that only when you put your papers down, they will listen to you And these things are also not for employees working in Cessna, this is part and parcel of people working at RMZ Ecospace

Advice to Senior Management
Please heed to the employees' qualms and concerns, they are the building blocks after all. It is not as much as about the hike as it is about the appreciation and recognition some times.

This is the perfect work environment for someone who doesn't want to be challenged or noticed, and just wants to show up for a 9-5 job and get paid.

Cons
- Way past any exciting work left to do. - Packed with older people with old-school work habits (complete opposite of a startup) - No growth/challenges

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, March 06, 2016 3:38 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Company"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Company"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Sun, 6 Mar 2016

Pros
Diverse opportunities -supports career moves across functional silos Competitive compensation and benefits Good people - little to no tolerance for empire builders and leadership by fear Collaboration culture - supports flexible working, virtual collaboration, etc

Cons
Big company - takes a while for anyone to connect all the dots. You will likely find people in different organizations trying to achieve the same goal not knowing about each other Work hours - global company means working across time zones, partly compensated by flexible working, but if you need a 9-5 job this may not be for you.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep doing what you are doing - but need to emphasize e2e vision more, and put more investment into the future of the company, even if it means diverting investment from the "good enough" legacy business
