From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, March 06, 2016 12:04 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Project Manager says "Sr Project Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Project Manager says "Sr Project Manager"

From Cisco Systems Senior Project Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sun, 6 Mar 2016

Pros
Work from home Good health care option Short term disability pays 100% with 3 month job protection End of year shutdown requires Christmas and New Years off Work with some bright people Little travel for most projects

Cons
-Long hours depending on client -If you are good, they will often require you to work as a program manager with no promotion or salary increase -RSU are seldom given expect to top 5% with a subjective selection process -Internal movement is difficult - directors don't want to lose headcount so they often hire externally or utilize contractors which does not promote career growth -New CEO replaces ~75% of senior leadership which has resulted in a FY16 being a year of transition where middle management and those below are not informed of the direction of the company - are we a product company? Are we a software company? Are we a solutions company? -Cisco promotes the IoT World a Forum which relies on "things" needing to be connected yet executive management says we are not a solutions integrator....makes little sense. -Yearly restructuring and workforce reductions make It difficult to have any company loyalty or have insight into the direction of company - a company that constantly restructures, yearly, is a company unsure of its direction. -Unless you work out of one of the large offices (San Jose, Boxborough, RTP, or Richardson), executive management will not get to know you and you are excluded from doing any team building. I've worked on the same team for 4 years and never met any of my teammates or boss. -Salary is 15-20% below the market average. Pay raises are seldom given. - All this for a company with a world class brand and not knowing if you will be affected every year by the restructure or layoffs. - Internal back office systems are horrible for a "leading" IT company. They are beginning to get better, but back office work accounts for 30% of your time when it should be spent taking care of customers. They are constantly changing the systems we use.

Advice to Senior Management
Reverse the cons listed above. Care about all your people and they will move mountains for you. Don't neglect the majority of talent that work from home.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9813791.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9813791.htm>

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Thu, 3 Mar 2016

Pros
decent salary, good brand name, great on resume.

Cons
ucs group has tight schedule and high turnover rate, those who stay long at the group as a result suffers and overworks. the manager has no concept of advising and promoting employess that is long forgotten. management will listen but whatever told em will come-in in one ear and comes-out the other ear. Each project comes with a unbelievably tight deadline and either project slip is common or deliver with questionable quality. Too many ignorant, dont care engineers with great job title but lost a common sense. Some engineers can not even configure basic networking and incapable of communicating in simple english language. As a result of all these mishap, technical clarity, know-how suffered and confusion, bias and complacency prevailed.

Advice to Senior Management
Hire more and quality engineers instead of engineers-would-be who stays on the job 1-2 years and leave everything in mess.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, March 01, 2016 11:25 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software QA Engineer says "Excellent employer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software QA Engineer says "Excellent employer"

From Cisco Systems Software QA Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 1 Mar 2016

Pros
* The pay is above the average comparing with other R&D center of similar size foreign companies in China. * Unlike most other Chinese companies, overtime work is not common. * It is a pleasure to work with professional colleagues. * Managers are supportive.

Cons
* Strict with travel cost. Used collaboration tools heavily to avoid traveling. * No travel allowance if travel abroad. Just cover all the actual cost of accommodation, dinner and transportation. * Career opportunity for software QA engineers is not as good as software engineers.

Advice to Senior Management
* Be more realistic with transitioning from waterfall development process to agile process. The best practices of other companies do not always apply to this company. Listen more to first line engineers about how to work in the agile way that fit them the best.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9766007.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

From Cisco Systems Product Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — Tue, 1 Mar 2016

Pros

Cons
Rapid management turnover while there. Consultants running amok. Company was looking to deep dive into their customer usage data to pull out lots of insights. Probably a privacy concern for companies that use Webex for sensitive meetings...

Advice to Senior Management
Hire nice people. Retain nice people. Don't rely on contractors and consultants to run your business or develop your product. Treat your customers right. Don't abuse their trust.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, March 01, 2016 1:44 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Cisco software engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Cisco software engineer"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Tue, 1 Mar 2016

Pros
Good work life balance. Allow you to work remotely

Cons
I joined with a good salary 5 years ago as a new grad out of college, and I have seen only ONE increment of 5% in the last 5 years. It was not like I was not doing good. They kept doing re-orgs and rotated me under different managers. Each manager said I needed to establish myself with him. And each one promised me a promotion next year which didnt happen. I saw other people in other groups getting promoted or salary hiked much faster and here I am slogging under one manager after another, sometimes doing junk work that the technical leads themselves do not want to take. I stayed on because they gave me flexibility to work from home which I needed as I was facing some family issues. I looked outside and landed up with an offer that directly gave me a 45% hike. Happy to get out of here finally! I would not advise young people to join Cisco unless they know they are getting the right pay, the right recognition and growth in their careers. Each group is different, not every group need to be like mine. But move out as soon as you find out you are stagnating or you are not being just-fully rewarded/promoted, within 6 months.

Advice to Senior Management
Please do not do ratings based on the peers in the same grade, but based on individual's performance and what is needed for that project. Promotions and salary hikes become too political, especially when you are under a new manager vs a seasoned manager who might have a good rapport with the director.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9760255.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9760255.htm>

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Channel Account Manager says "Channel Account Manager"

From Cisco Systems Channel Account Manager (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 1 Mar 2016

Pros
The company provides good benefits, home office is almost for everybody and the management is accessible all the time. The medical plan is very good.

Cons
It is not usual to receive an up date of salaries. The promotions are very pointed for internal team and there are not an really open processes of selection.

Advice to Senior Management
To the first level managers i advice them that they have to be more part of the business not only to be resource manager.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, March 01, 2016 4:53 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Sales Manager says "A good company to work for"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Sales Manager says "A good company to work for"

From Cisco Systems Sales Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 1 Mar 2016

Pros
Cisco is a good remunerating company which allow you to grow a lot. If you are a curious guy this company provide you internal and external training, access to a big database of technical resources, access to research companies reports, a really powerful community to rely on, Benefits and pay are above the average. Knowledge is well spread around the company.

Cons
Employment selection is hard. Sometime the glory doesn't go to the guy who did the job. This company will never manage a pension application. A sales force renewal process is always ongoing.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, February 29, 2016 12:17 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II says "Contract jobs are bad"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II says "Contract jobs are bad"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer II (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — Mon, 29 Feb 2016

Pros
Good work life balances in case placed in good team. Earlier, used to be good organization with lot of WFH benefits and good technical career. But now a days some Leads/Managers are not allowing WFH due to work pressure where there is challenge to hire new resources. Good brand. Also, not allowing remote workers now a days for many teams. Taking leaves also challenge in some teams.

Cons
Nowadays after Chuck Robbins taken charge most BU's/teams has went with reorg and lost many c-workers due to same. I was waiting to be converted for more then 1 and half year but never got converted as team was running on limited budget. FYI, contract jobs are first hit in these re-orgs, it happened almost every quarter of 2015 and 2016. In San Francisco complete floor was removed, i guess 500 folks. In Bangalore in our team itself 7-10 people got removed. It has crazy hire and fire policy. Also, for c workers there is no future plan for long term career for many managers, they just hire to do daily tasks as such. They will promise to convert after 6 months or so but they will postpone it like any number of years. I have seen people working c worker for more then 8 years who got survived enough.

Advice to Senior Management
You need to financial supports teams in order to grow in technical front or innovation. Moving innovation in IOT doesnt means you need to rem voe c-workers at all other teams and BUs. Also, pls have some plan to hire c worker in short term if they are working good for you.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9738326.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9738326.htm>

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Sun, 28 Feb 2016

Pros
Annual layoffs (or even more frequently), no annual pay raises, overly political, age discrimination, and constant, un-ending reorganization across all levels of the corporation.

Cons
Meetings, meetings, more meetings, even more meetings, still yet more meetings, and after all of that? MEETINGS. Low pay, no raises and management's inability to listen to the rank and file are omnipresent, too.

Advice to Senior Management
keep on with the repeated re-orgainizing strategy, so nobody on the outside will ever get a clear picture of Cisco's actual state

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, February 26, 2016 1:58 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Job---but...."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Job---but...."

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 26 Feb 2016

Pros
Great Pay, Industry leader, great benefits, great autonomy and world class people...you are working with the key people in the industry....you are a leader...you are driven and love it....plenty of off sites, volunteer events....you will learn more and drive major initiatives...a truly great job..

Cons
Be careful of believing in your own propaganda. they boast of the business unit and then lay off 40%....there are great leaders...and there are weak ones...and the weak ones will do anything to stay on...and they will ask for your thoughts...but really do not want them...agree with them or leave. This company will reorg and layoff every quarter...and then hire on new grads to replace the seniors....a great experience comes with severe issues. I saw the best mangers...and the worst at one company--and there is a bit of a loyalty issues from those managers.

Advice to Senior Management
you have created a great company....and lay off the seniors who stay on...

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Hardware Engineer says "Overall good place"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Hardware Engineer says "Overall good place"

From Cisco Systems Hardware Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Thu, 25 Feb 2016

Pros
Good work, IEEE standard setting groups, lots of different work opportunities and groups. Company pays for a lot of training (courses at Berkeley or Stanford are free if you get at least a B)

Cons
Company mood highly correlated with stock price. Your experience depends on the group that you are in. Cisco is really 20 different companies joined as one.

Advice to Senior Management
Management turns over way too quickly so reorgs are always happening. Just having stable management is a good plus

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, February 24, 2016 11:55 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Software QA Engineer says "Solid Company"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Software QA Engineer says "Solid Company"

From Cisco Systems Senior Software QA Engineer (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 24 Feb 2016

Pros
Cisco is a nice place to work for the most part. It really depends on the group that you are. Some BU's people work like crazy and products have huge revenue. "you want to be in one of these BU's". If the BU you are working has little or low growth forget about any career advancements or innovations. Compensation is fairly OK

Cons
If you are in a stable BU, not much happens and if you are not careful you will end up doing the same tasks everyday. After 5 years working for Cisco everyone outside of this company will be reluctant to wire you. Compensation is almost direct of how many years you are in Cisco.

Advice to Senior Management
Do not keep engineers doing the same jobs without innovating all the time. Cisco engineers after 10 years working there are really out of touch with the Market.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9696147.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9696147.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, February 23, 2016 9:34 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer says "Great Tech Company w/ Typical Large Co. Issues"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer says "Great Tech Company w/ Typical Large Co. Issues"

From Cisco Systems Systems Engineer (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 23 Feb 2016

Pros
Great Work/Life balance; great work from home option; great at-home communication equipment; good benefits and ESPP program; good overall compensation and generally good people, especially the newer folks; Cisco is still a great resume builder

Cons
Cisco is a huge company, so your experience will vary depending on your team and your position; Some departments & managers are great and you'll love your time there, but with the constant change and restructuring there's a good chance you'll be shuttled to different teams and management; Internal movement is difficult unless you're in the cliques; The culture and climate deteriorated during my tenure; Employees at the larger campuses seem to have better experiences; Some managers are only interested in managing up and not managing their teams; The stereotype of Cisco SEs and AMs being arrogant still holds true for a lot of the old guard

Advice to Senior Management
Speed the adoption of cloud services and MSP models to stay relevant. And stop the yearly August Shuffle of departments. It's still a great company with great products, technology and market share, but don't rest on your past successes and don't get caught napping.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9680687.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9680687.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, February 22, 2016 10:01 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer says "Legendary reputation...some BU's have serious issues..."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer says "Legendary reputation...some BU's have serious issues..."

From Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — Mon, 22 Feb 2016

Pros
Nice perks. Everyone gets access to the fitness center and issued this nice towel. Shame you're not in a frame of mind to USE them unless you're in the right groups. There's no cafeteria One of the buildings had one they shuttered- but they have this nifty self-serve convenience store stuffed in part of where they had the caf. Debit card only. Security monitoring since you're not on an honor system with it.

Cons
Pros end with what I describe. Management's clearly lost, with nobody sound at the helm. The mass layoffs you hear about are partly due to their insistence on being multicultural, partly because many of the people involved with anything other than their original core businesses, switching and routing, have this disturbing and shocking lack of understanding of general networking, IP networking, or the like. They're "good" with things like 802.11 OTA/OTW frames, but behaviors due to spanning tree and the like? Forget it. And it shows. Look at the reviews of their WAP371AK9 1200AC AP. If you're doing something simple, it works reasonably well. Try to use the claimed features? Whooo... Simply put, if you're in anything other than the Unified Communications or Switching and Routing BU's, you're in for a trip into hell and they have as high as a 10% attrition rate from regular *ANNUAL* RIFs. Worse, you have to scrape and scrounge for almost ALL hardware you need to do your job, including the PC's. NOT what I would consider to be a good thing with a company such as Cisco.

Advice to Senior Management
Surgically remove your heads from your backsides. Your name is about to quit carrying you forward and you're going to flush the company down the crapper. Meraki's being treated as "GOD, come down to earth" and they only do "well" in mesh WiFi work from the spun off RoofNet project (which, by the by, any fool can turn around and obtain that code core from MIT...)- they *DO NOT* have the answers regarding much of anything else and unifying the codebases...heh... GUT your Wireless BU and START OVER.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9657541.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9657541.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, February 19, 2016 11:37 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Professional says "Changing competitive environment causing management uncertainty"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Professional says "Changing competitive environment causing management uncertainty"

From Cisco Systems Marketing Professional (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 19 Feb 2016

Pros
Cisco offers a comparatively stable work environment with some very talented folks. There is a strong customer-oriented point of view across the company which has held up over the years.

Cons
Cisco is a huge, incredibly profitable firm facing competitive forces from powerful new adversaries attacking from market perspectives never seen before. That evolved landscape is leading to uncertainty, which is in turn leading to variability in the way the company is managed.

Advice to Senior Management
Don't mistake swift, assertive action for intelligent management practice.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9636126.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9636126.htm>

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems IT Program Manager says "Good family gig."

From Cisco Systems IT Program Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Fri, 19 Feb 2016

Pros
Flexible working location and schedule for a lot of roles. Some people are awesome. Genuinely tryng to improve the employee experience. Great leadership in IT at the moment (Diaz).

Cons
Some people epitomize the political culture endemic in large corporations to the extreme. Salary for some people seriously lags SV housing costs. Lack of gender, age, and race diversity in some areas is startling.

Advice to Senior Management
New direction(FY2016) is great, let's see a salary readjustment that reflects Cisco's performance, and wealth to IC's.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, February 19, 2016 10:43 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Project Manager says "The greatest place to work."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Project Manager says "The greatest place to work."

From Cisco Systems Project Manager (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Fri, 19 Feb 2016

Pros
Amazing people, tightly focused on delivery of best products to fit the needs of our clients.

Cons
Long hours, often weekends, with a lot of stress from the clients to achieve their goals. Often working with clients who were not fully educated with the strengths of the systems. The pressure was to "Get it now exactly like it used to be" rather then taking the time to Do what is Best. As some jobs grew more complex, the pressures increased.

Advice to Senior Management
Be patient with the people you have. And make better use of your In Country resources, rather then depending on Out of Theater resources.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9629899.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9629899.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, February 17, 2016 9:26 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Awesome place to work!"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Awesome place to work!"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 17 Feb 2016

Pros
People. Values. Culture. Top. This are the 4 keywords I want to use to describe Cisco. All the people I've ever met at Cisco are awesome. The company culture is very strong for a company that grew so much in so little time. Every single Cisco person is willing to help you and, if they can't, they always redirect you to someone who might have the solution of your problem. Cisco is top, market leader, it gives you the access to the latest technologies and the opportunity to develop you career path both vertically and horizontally.

Cons
Sometimes you get lost in the corporate governance chain. Cisco can be a complex machine sometimes and you can forget for whom you are actually working for. Home office plays a very important role in Cisco, which is awesome. Nevertheless, virtual teams have their own pros and cons, but without the proper management downsides can easily take over the benefits of VT.

Advice to Senior Management
Micromanage less. Give straight answers in response to straight questions. Sometimes guide more your employees. In Cisco every person is captain of his/her own career, no manager will ever tell you what to do. Though, sometimes people need being told what to do or what would be best for them.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9599900.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9599900.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, February 13, 2016 6:54 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager IV says "Great for new grads and insiders. Everyone else is dirt."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager IV says "Great for new grads and insiders. Everyone else is dirt."

From Cisco Systems Program Manager IV (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 4 of 4 found this helpful — Sat, 13 Feb 2016

Pros
I worked at the company for fourteen years, starting as an intern. I must admit the first half of my time there was great, and Cisco had many lateral opportunities in San Jose to try new things. I was proud to work at Cisco, and it was a name that was respected world-wide.

Cons
Outside of the business units, operations jobs in both software and hardware were a living hell. My specialty became training and moving jobs overseas, saving money that was enjoyed at higher levels. Working with and in other time zones was required, and I worked with India, Europe, Asia, and Mexico. Travel was usually reasonable but not at the end. When our team was identified to be off-shored, management was ruthless. Those who weren't let go in the beginning were tortured in my opinion. Some were moved into roles requiring 50% travel. I tried to lateral out of such a role and was told by the senior director that they were looking at moving a younger person in the role I wanted. Rather than letting them torture me further and then lay me off when I was done moving my career path off-shore, I quit and found a better paying job elsewhere. I literally could not believe how they repaid service and loyalty at the end.

Advice to Senior Management
Break up the cliques. Fire directors with few or zero reports. Be a leader on reasonable executive compensation. Find ways to keep jobs in the USA

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9561048.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9561048.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, February 13, 2016 9:31 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Manager, Global Manufacturing Operations"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Manager, Global Manufacturing Operations"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sat, 13 Feb 2016

Pros
I had enjoyed working with Cisco and the teams. It was rewarding journey from learning and career perspective. I liked the company in many aspects: great culture, transparent communications from executives, ethical, collaborative and inclusive working environment and superb talents community. If you show good potential, are passionate to take bigger responsibility and take initiative to advance career, I have found management is always willing to provide mentoring and coaching and development opportunities. I also felt proud about the fact that the company put lots of efforts in social responsibility.

Cons
I generally worked long hours and sometimes stayed up late to get connected with team from other countries. Headquarter centric, there were moments that regional team needed to fight for decision making.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9557566.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9557566.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, February 12, 2016 5:16 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems New Product Project Manager says "A good company to work for"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems New Product Project Manager says "A good company to work for"

From Cisco Systems New Product Project Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 12 Feb 2016

Pros
A solid company that overall treats its employees well. Good benefits, with ability to work from home every now and then. A lot of smart and talented people, both in Development and in Supply Chain organizations. Lots of challenging and interesting projects. Employee recognition methods are changing for the better.

Cons
For a new product that has not yet "proven" itself in the market, resources are often minimal, so people get spread pretty thin. The hours can get long for long stretches of time. The top management can sporadically change direction, and years' worth of work can go down the drain. Cost-cutting has led to a lot of churn with contractors and off-shoring.

Advice to Senior Management
Those "start-up" BUs would work out better if you fund them properly and have the strength of conviction to see them through. Disruption for the sake of disruption is not a good idea.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9552885.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9552885.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, February 12, 2016 3:08 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior User Experience Designer says "Sr. User Experience Designer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior User Experience Designer says "Sr. User Experience Designer"

From Cisco Systems Senior User Experience Designer (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 7 of 7 found this helpful — Fri, 12 Feb 2016

Pros
Great work life balance. Work from home is a major plus (they own WebEx). Smart capable people. Amazing benefits including a full week of paid leave for charity volunteering. Love how much the company gives back to society.

Cons
Very rare to get a salary increase, so be sure you're OK with the salary you accept. Lots of churn in mid-management, I've had 13 managers in seven years. Tough to get your ideas heard, unless you're politically minded. Since the company is so large, there are a lot of slackers who coast along just under the radar, which can be de-motivating. Very engineering driven with design, and user experience, as an afterthought. There is also no clear career path for designers. Design is not handled in a traditional manner, so collaborating with fellow designers is rare- instead you're assigned a product and become silo'ed in it.

Advice to Senior Management
Implement a more detailed review of managers, and management, by their staff- in an anonymous method so that real feedback can be delivered and received. Current "Pulse" surveys are lame in that they are so high-level they fail to be actionable. Also, if you intend on continuing to talk about how important user experience design is to the company, you should update your human resources systems to include the job title "user experience designer" and "designer". Instead, we are all labeled engineers, which is not accurate and is somewhat insulting.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9551968.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9551968.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, February 11, 2016 7:37 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Limited Restructuring"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Limited Restructuring"

From Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Thu, 11 Feb 2016

Pros
Relentless sales machine with a no lose attitude.

Cons
No where near the same company I started with 16 years ago and not moving nearly quick enough to keep up with the competition. Limited Restructuring (fancy name for layoffs) now a quarterly event. Many of us who brought in millions for the company have left or been forced out when a theater goes through a down cycle. BU's are not consistently held accountable for failure to deliver on commitments and staying competitive.

Advice to Senior Management
Look harder at your talent going out the door. You may be able to hire younger staff for half the cost but you cannot replace veterans with years of experience in this industry nor replace the long term customer relationships that are lost. Come up with a better internal placement program.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9533660.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9533660.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Partner Development Manager says "Have to leave to get promoted"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Partner Development Manager says "Have to leave to get promoted"

From Cisco Systems Partner Development Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 10 Feb 2016

Pros
Very flexible environment and you can work remotely which is great. Never had a bad manager and the culture is very strong.

Cons
Path to promotions are nebulous and personally, I had to leave and come back to get a promotion. Several colleagues have said the same thing. A more defined path and transparency would be better.

Advice to Senior Management
More transparency on promotions and compensation in general. These are very complicated topics at Cisco!

Pros
Was an Intern. Good Events Good managers Good Teammates. Enjoyed the experience, conversion to full time should not be very tough if you show potential.

Cons
Company is in a transition. Takes some time getting used to the internal platforms and softwares. But is a good experience in general. Need to find referrals to get interview calls I feel. Feels bureaucratic at times.

Advice to Senior Management
I feel the company would do better if there were more younger people and also women. I feel they would bring in fresh ideas and different perspectives which combined with experienced employees would yield a lot of good things.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9509800.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9509800.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Escalation Engineer says "Cisco Pros and cons"

From Cisco Systems Escalation Engineer (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Mon, 8 Feb 2016

Pros
Great pay, great benefits, great bonus. Collaborative environment. Top notch talent. Challenging work. No day ever the same. Networking leader.

Cons
Long hours, layoffs every fall. Last several years has seen the same restructuring and RIFs every fall. Many people in constant fear for their jobs.

Advice to Senior Management
Please dont continue the restructure cycle every year. Here one minute, gone the next is not what people are looking for in am employer. Need to do some damage control.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, February 05, 2016 3:02 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems User Experience Designer says "Where great people go to retire into mediocrity"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems User Experience Designer says "Where great people go to retire into mediocrity"

From Cisco Systems User Experience Designer (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 5 Feb 2016

Pros
I moved between a couple of teams during my time at Cisco. I guess that's a pro that you can do that. Cisco has the resources to hire excellent people. I never lacked for anything. Vacation allowances were pretty good, healthcare was convenient. Always more work to be done than people to do it, but never felt too overloaded in the long run.

Cons
Cisco in general does not like to fire or otherwise diminish the effects of poor performers. Combined with bureaucracy, you get folks in formal or informal leadership positions who've been around for a long time but who aren't actually up to par with new tech/methods/advancements. On two of my teams, the 'bad egg' was the manager--one was actually eventually laid off/let go after most of the team had already quit or moved to another team, another used the team as a front/stepping stone to further their own advancement... and advanced (unfortunately for the company, I think). On the last team, everyone both excellent and mediocre had gotten so used to the overall mediocrity that I was terrified of slipping into the same cadence as the rest so I left. It wasn't the worst, but you have to be ready to accept the clocked-out-while-you're-clocked-in life, and while I think that's actually an ok choice, I didn't want it. While benefits were good, compensation was pretty lacking.

Advice to Senior Management
I don't know. I understand why everything is so slow and difficult and bureaucratic so I don't blame anyone. It's just that there's so much that could have been prevented/accomplished by removing a few key individuals who bring down the team.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9464021.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9464021.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, February 04, 2016 8:18 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Still Great Company, Needs Shift Back to Maker Culture"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Still Great Company, Needs Shift Back to Maker Culture"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Thu, 4 Feb 2016

Pros
Lots of great people. Cisco products and solutions are in just about every company and government in the world! Get to work in so many areas of tech and see things sometimes years before end customers. Can have a huge impact for good on many people because Cisco is so far reaching and IP networks plus communications are so critical to modern life. Because they make all the tools and solutions to enable telecommuting, you can work from just about anywhere just as effectively as being in a traditional office.

Cons
Has become very corporate. Too many blazers are being worn. Needs to get focus and priority back on engineers, creatives, and makers to compete in the very fast paced tech world. Has cut cut cut away all the little perks that used to help define the culture. Too many lay offs which are killing morale and loyalty.

Advice to Senior Management
Don't let Cisco become another HP or IBM. Ditch the blazers and be tech execs. Hire more experienced engineers and makers to leadership positions.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9461655.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, February 04, 2016 3:43 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Not what it once was"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Not what it once was"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Thu, 4 Feb 2016

Pros
Lots of flexibility, was able to telecommute and work part time for a couple of years. Way back when, most everyone got stock options and felt ownership. That's not a pro anymore.

Cons
The process people took over. Sometimes we had to change perfectly functional code to satisfy a tool that identified a possible problem, even if we could prove it couldn't happen. Too much focus on reducing headcount rather than retaining and motivating good performers.

Advice to Senior Management
Find a way to bring back the entrepreneurial attitude Cisco used to have. Cut the layers of VPs that just get in the way. Reward managers for getting things done rather than cutting headcount.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9458997.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, February 04, 2016 2:25 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Company lost in transition"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Company lost in transition"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Thu, 4 Feb 2016

Pros
Cisco is a giant and a brand people trust. For good reason they make some of the best network related products on the market. Customers pick up the phone when they hear your from Cisco.

Cons
Cisco has lost its way in terms of their sales efforts. They have become so effective at marketing to themselves they've lost perspective on the world around them. They're so focused on selling for the now they frustrate customers of the long term relationship.

Advice to Senior Management
Slow down and look at building long lasting relationships rather than the immediate sale.

From Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer IV (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Thu, 4 Feb 2016

Pros

Cons
A toxic work environment built on perceived visibility and contributions rather than recognising individuals for what they really are contributing. This promotes a culture of pretending to work rather than really working. Too many mid level manager , most have nothing to do and abuse corporate travel and expensess.

Advice to Senior Management
Go back to being an engineering company , change the toxic culture you'be cultivated over the years and make HR be more useful than just processing hire and fire forms.

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Product Manager says "Political Organization"

From Cisco Systems Product Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 2 Feb 2016

Pros

Cons
Very political; you'll have to learn how to use political skills to get things done; not a lot of data-driven emphasis regarding decision-making; "socializing" ideas is very important. Slow in making decisions and executing.

Advice to Senior Management

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, February 02, 2016 1:34 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing says "Mixed Bag"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing says "Mixed Bag"

From Cisco Systems Marketing (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 2 Feb 2016

Pros
Generally speaking people at Cisco are nice and respectful, especially compared to other high-tech companies where I've worked. They encourage and enable job and even entire career changes within the company, so there are lots of people who have been there 10+ years (which is a pro and a con actually). From my experience elsewhere I find they pay well, especially at the more junior levels, and the bonuses have been pretty healthy. Chuck is one of the most sincere CEO's in the Valley and deeply cares about doing good as a company.

Cons
The company is going through lots of change right now with an almost entirely new exec leadership team. They seem to be finding it hard to make decisions so important things seem to be stalled (especially in marketing). Chuck says he wants to move fast and faster yet, but we seem to be moving so sloooooooowly. It's excruciating. They also are pretty open about wanting to get rid of people at the more senior levels to bring in lots of young employees. And they want to reduce hiring in San Jose in favor of less expensive locations. So job security for senior people in San Jose is dicey. And finally, they're trying really hard to be cool and hip to bring in those younger people, but it verges on embarrassing how they go about it. Wearing jeans and doing video profiles called "meet our millennials" doesn't do it. It's well intended though!

Advice to Senior Management
Consider settling down all of the re-organizing and layoffs for awhile so work can actually get done. Some execs need to stop trying to consensus build and impress their peers and start making decisions.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9427856.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9427856.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, February 02, 2016 1:14 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Data Center Engineer says "Data Center Engineering Intern"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Data Center Engineer says "Data Center Engineering Intern"

From Cisco Systems Data Center Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 2 Feb 2016

Pros
Most intelligent and social professionals you will ever meet. Learned the most I've ever learned at an internship. Everything you learn is so applicable to any career path (how the internet works, OS, basic coding, troubleshooting, etc.)

Cons
As a data center engineer, you're reliant on people telling you what to do. Sometimes you're sitting there with your feet up. Other times theres you have five top priority tasks to complete at once. Very chaotic nature at times.

Advice to Senior Management
Understand the crazy nature of working in a data center and give those team members a heads up of big upcoming tasks.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, February 02, 2016 2:23 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Director says "A great company where change truly is the only constant"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Director says "A great company where change truly is the only constant"

From Cisco Systems Director (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 2 Feb 2016

Pros
Clear vision and strategy supported by strong leadership with the ability to execute. Constant innovation across a broad portfolio of solutions, services and go-to-market strategy. Excellent colleagues with high standards of performance and integrity - and the ability to have fun - several have become personal friends. Flexibility in terms of work life balance and leveraging technology to work wherever you are.

Cons
High performance culture with freedom and flexibility may also lead to a 24x7 working schedule, so it requires a level of maturity from each individual, and a clear line of communication with your immediate manager, to ensure that the ability to work anywhere/anytime does not consume you.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep hiring and developing top talent with a view to balancing out the workforce. My personal experience was that Cisco is extremely well run. Make sure that the level of professionalism does not kill the passion and enthusiasm around "changing the way we work, live, play and learn". Continue to invest in managers to develop their people skills - not just their core skills.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, February 01, 2016 11:44 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Human Resources Manager says "Reinventing how we work.....it is real at Cisco"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Human Resources Manager says "Reinventing how we work.....it is real at Cisco"

From Cisco Systems Human Resources Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 1 Feb 2016

Pros
Cisco is capturing the transition of the changing work place and workforce. Never in my career have I been a part of a company that has been able to capture the market transition with a view and ability to translate the change and impact on everyday work for employees. The concept of digitization and automation is real. I am watching groups like Supply Chain and HR open the gates to their employees to rethink how work is done. They are not asking people managers or senior leaders to do this - they are asking employees. The are looking at full day experiences to break old processes and use new tools to re-invent work. We are telling Cisco how to work differently, using the tools and best practices that we see. We will learn together. We get to take simplification and speed to another level. Every demographic in the workplace can join in to reboot work. In this digital world the walls must come down, employees must work together to solve problems, motivate each other and bring in the talent to continue the wave. It is real - Cisco is doing it! We are connecting everything, benefiting everyone and innovating everywhere! The culture at Cisco is evolving...Human Resources is standing up in a bold way to be a driving force in how the company evolves. We all have to step into the conversation and be a part of this change. Relationships still matter but you also have to think differently - real time. Nothing remains the same....this is fantastic.

Cons
In order to be a part of the transition, you have to have time to think and solve the problems in a new way. We work hard and smart. In this time of change - you must do more. Work life integration is getting harder. So remember wherever you are, you must take time to reflect and rest, or you will not be able to see the changes you must make.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, February 01, 2016 8:52 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Sales says "Restructuring is gettting old"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Sales says "Restructuring is gettting old"

From Cisco Systems Sales (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 1 Feb 2016

Pros
I loved working for Cisco and recommend it to anyone. It is a fast paced environment but there are great products and great people to work with.

Cons
Every six months there is another restructuring and the people they are letting go are often some of the best performers. Cisco used to be one of the higher paying sales jobs you could get, but now the comp plans are hard to blow out and if you do, your number for the next year will make it difficult to repeat.

Advice to Senior Management
Every six months you put another batch of qualified people on the street, many of whom end up working for the competition. When the first big layoff hit several years back, it felt like the whole company was in agony. Now they happen and people don't seem to notice. The reason given is that Cisco is restructuring to better address the market and that may be true but reality is that reflect the short sightedness of management. Chuck Robbins should start thinking like the basketball player he was and get rid of coaches when they have a bad season, not the team.....

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, January 31, 2016 8:24 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Avoid if you can"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Avoid if you can"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Sun, 31 Jan 2016

Pros
The onsite medical facility, medical benefits, and the gym were excellent. Probably the only good thing about the place

Cons
Contributions only acknowledged if you are part of the right clique AND have been at the company for a million years. Not many subject matter experts and lots of things done in a very primitive fashion because management will not spend money to get things done. Executives seem to spend lavishly on themselves and seem overly compensated as individual contributors don't get so much as a cost of living raise and it is not uncommon for people to be at the same salary/grade level for years and years.

Advice to Senior Management
You won't keep any real talent with non-competitive salaries and lack of career progression for people who have less than 20 years at the company. Very unattractive for millenials and younger Gen-Xers who expect to be compensated and rewarded for the work they do as opposed to watching older Gen-Xers and Baby Boomers take all of the money and the credit.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, January 30, 2016 9:07 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Extreme caution - Trending negative in multiple areas"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Extreme caution - Trending negative in multiple areas"

From Cisco Systems Program Manager (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Sat, 30 Jan 2016

Pros
Many Perks for "some" select positions. Nothing others do not offer. Work from home. Flexible hours but heavy load and long days. On campus medical and gyms now. On Campus cafeterias. A good manager is rare but if you end up with one they will let you guide your career. Employee stock purchase program.

Cons
Hostile work environment. Job Titles are diminished and not factual. As of 2015 reverting back to political structure of "good ole boys" network, VERY Political and NOT customer focused. Power hungry managers prefer to strip down the inside. Nortel Mentality has set in. Unable to execute any concepts advertised , smoke and mirrors. Focused on hiring Very low wage college graduates at sub par salaries- expect 30 to 40k less at Cisco. Inclusion and diversity is failing by taking unqualified employees and rising them to high pay , high ranking positions simply based on race and or sex. This is having a horrible impact on the customer and the business. If you like to keep the same salary forever, never move up , just lateral and you enjoy being stripped of your confidence, and you like to worry monthly about being laid off or fired then this is the gig for you! As of 2016 Cisco is failing hard. The new CEO is not business or tech, he is a ,math major. The original CEO still on the board runs the business via proxy. Cisco has had a history of success through acquisitions, that is why they are the Borg. This is failing now. Expect massive layoffs in FY16 and FY17 as they outsource more and cut staff. Internal training has dried up. The internal rating system is fixed and the employee has little if any say.

Advice to Senior Management
Wake up! There are serious internal problems that are starting to bleed out. These are having a direct impact on the business and the customer. Cisco does not just need technical innovation it needs leadership and a focus on services. The routing and switching market is dying, Hang on to that and become Nortel, Fix internal issues. Bring back a fair rating system. Cisco has positioned itself to strong arm the employee. Shameful

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9396549.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9396549.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

If you are in routing and switching, it is the top of the food chain good pay, good benefits, good work environment (if you are in routing and switching)

Cons
If you are not in routing and switching, you are expendable Yearly 5% layoffs, with no thought of re-positioning - even for senior people with multiple skill sets

Advice to Senior Management
Find a way to cross pollinate the various BUs - to many fiefdoms, and very limited cross BU mobility

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, January 29, 2016 8:27 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Engineer @ Cisco"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Engineer @ Cisco"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Fri, 29 Jan 2016

Pros
Allow employees to work from home. Very loose direct management styles allow a lot of creativity in our jobs.

Cons
High level management has no idea what their teams actually do. Severe disconnect between reality and working process. High stress levels at times and constant concern about job security. Long hours. Very little thought to work / life balance. If you don't work 100 hours a week, they will find someone less qualified who has no qualms about the hours.

Advice to Senior Management
Higher level management needs to spend time with the "boots on the ground" and understand what they do and how it's getting done. It's impossible to understand need when you don't understand process and what the teams are going through.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9381395.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, January 28, 2016 6:41 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Cisco Systems direction"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Cisco Systems direction"

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Thu, 28 Jan 2016

Pros
Cisco is literally the company that made the internet - so it has some smart people and a huge customer & partner base. Work culture varies from group to group so it is hard to characterize it any one way.

Cons
The culture for Cisco has changed significantly from the 90s when it was a technology company singularly looking to get more market share with a variety of different technologies. Now the culture is primarily focused on politics. This feedback is primarily focused at Services and the culture there. A lot of the management is not barely familiar with the technology. When they get barely familiar with the technology, they are playing catch with where the market direction may be headed. Then there is complete ignorance of where the industry is heading with technologies such Virtualization, Analytics and Services in general. Management rewards each other with pats on the back and results of Services performance is not reviewed and weighed as a metric for evaluation. WIth the result innovation is stiffled.

Advice to Senior Management
Look at performance of Cloud & Managed Services introduced and see whether you should be rewarding leaders who are bringing these services to market and investing in them.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9375822.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9375822.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, January 27, 2016 9:48 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software/QA Engineer II says "Quality and Assurance Engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software/QA Engineer II says "Quality and Assurance Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Software/QA Engineer II (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 27 Jan 2016

Pros
Flexible working hours with great work-life balance Work from home option is one of the biggest facility this company provides and there is hardly any micro management

Cons
Hard to manage work life balance Very big company with constant changes

Advice to Senior Management
In my time at Cisco I was a part of 3 different and distinct business units. I enjoyed working for each of them and found that I was able to contribute value in every role I held. What was painfully obvious to me was that the company is (or was) going through a bit of an identity crisis. Consumer vs no consumer. Social media vs no social media. AWS like cloud offering vs Cisco cloud offering. My advice to the leadership team is this. We (Cisco for life) are *Cisco*. *We* develop the standard for networking, infrastructure and cloud.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9355046.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9355046.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, January 27, 2016 5:56 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Overall Good Experience"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Overall Good Experience"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 7 of 7 found this helpful — Wed, 27 Jan 2016

Pros
Have worked there for 10 years. Good pay and benefits. Lots of good people to work with. The best thing I have enjoyed is the flexibility, i.e. the ability to work remotely, flexible schedule.

Cons
- You can move laterally as much as you want but upward progression can be very difficult. Making it past Grade 11 and 12 seem to be very political. - Cisco relies on its bonus structure for retention. They do not give annual pay increases. I came in at a good rate and sat at that rate for 7 years before getting a raise. Negotiate a good salary coming in the door because that's all you'll get for a while! - The company still goes through an annual layoff cycle. Good people with lots of years with the company are usually let go without the opportunity to find another position internally. This is starting to make a lot of people anxious. There is a big push to move US employees to their Raleigh NC (RTP) campus.

Advice to Senior Management
- provide more opportunities and transparency around upward/forward promotions vs. lateral moves

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9351939.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9351939.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, January 27, 2016 5:22 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Senior Product Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Senior Product Manager"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Wed, 27 Jan 2016

Pros
lots of room to play, lead and drive the product road map, good opportunity to gather requirements from customer directly

Cons
Hardware products are impacted by Open source and other open projects

Advice to Senior Management
product strategy should be more open and well communicated

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, January 26, 2016 7:04 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Day of life as a Cisco Systems Engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Day of life as a Cisco Systems Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 26 Jan 2016

Pros
Overall - Best technologies in the ICT market. Too many technologies to learn from. Flexible work schedule. Possibility of sales commissions multiplier. Company representation. Travel.

Cons
Some technologies can be easily challenged by its closest competitor. No retirement benefits. Meritocracy is subjective. Tendency to be drained-out easily. Tendency of people managers competence issues. Tendency to be have low trust environment, depending whom you are working with at that moment. Business offerings are highly dependent on Cisco Local Partners. Medical/Dental Benefits are not top of the line compare to other similar multinational company offerings. No car plan.

Advice to Senior Management
Train up management to be a real people manager.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9337590.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9337590.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, January 25, 2016 8:23 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Too big to feel a part of"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Too big to feel a part of"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Mon, 25 Jan 2016

Pros
Huge company means plenty of resources to set up meetings and conferences, and so on. Suppliers return your call every time. Corporate resources library on the intranet is unbelievably huge. Smaller divisions like cable BU do some interesting technical work.

Cons
The size of the company is so big that you rarely feel a sense of empowerment. In the grand scheme of things, your work hardly matters. Or so it feels like. Somewhere, 6 levels above you, some EVP makes decisions and sends you an email, mostly congratulating himself on what a wonderful email he has written. The new centralized organization chart makes things even worse than before.

Advice to Senior Management
Find meaningful ways to let employees control the outcome of the group. Let them make decisions.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9333685.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9333685.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, January 25, 2016 7:29 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer says "Great company, too much middle management"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer says "Great company, too much middle management"

From Cisco Systems Systems Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 25 Jan 2016

Pros
Access to some of the smartest people in the world, great salary, remote work culture, and great customers

Cons
Too much internal focus and time spent on "beauty pageants" where SEs are asked to present back to management. It's really a way to prove you're good at your job, but in my opinion a good manager should know without burning valuable time that should be spent focusing on customers.

Advice to Senior Management
Re-focus efforts on delivering the best products, services, architectures, and sales experience for customers. Cut out the internal BS, flatten the management structure, and the results will follow.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9333134.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9333134.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, January 25, 2016 6:27 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Virtual Operations says "Cisco Contractor in Regional Operations/Business Transformation Office"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Virtual Operations says "Cisco Contractor in Regional Operations/Business Transformation Office"

From Cisco Systems Virtual Operations (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Mon, 25 Jan 2016

Pros
Having a big name like Cisco on your resume was great. Helped me get my next position. The campus is great, 3 cafeterias, 4 basketball courts, tennis and sand volleyball. There is an onsite gym that is very nice.

Cons
Working as a contract employee you feel a little left out of the fold even though its about a 60/40 split. Cisco is about the bottom line and our jobs were transitioned overseas as soon as it was feasible (even after consistent discussions from management that that would not be the case).

Advice to Senior Management
Care about your contract employees a little more. They help run the company and keep Cisco's operations moving. Do not lie to your employees.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, January 25, 2016 11:33 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great company but size has downfalls"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great company but size has downfalls"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 25 Jan 2016

Pros
The most fair and caring company I've ever worked for. Legitimately care for their employees and customers. The lengths at which they go to please customers I have never heard or seen of before..sometimes to a fault. Have been able to navigate tricky market transitions and still stay relevant. Its a $50B company with small company feeling as the command and control structure is well thought out and cared for.

Cons
$50B companies don't move fast enough to stave off market changes/competitive threats. Internal politics - as you can imagine - are alive and well. Have a challenge in front of them as market moves to cloud based IT - not only in products but in positioning/marketing. Hard to distinguish and reward the right behavior given 'core technology' upgrades bring in more revenue then a more strategic - higher margin - business outcome sale. Although they preach work-life balance continually - its up to the individual to maintain.

Advice to Senior Management
continue being aggressive in Cloud. Find those technology areas that are REAL customer led, business focused, AND are moving to the cloud - i.e...Contact Center and invest in the products as well as people in those areas because they have already gone through the transition, sell business outcomes, and understand software and customer driven engagements.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9326856.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9326856.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, January 23, 2016 3:42 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer Manager says "Great company for techies to learn and grow"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer Manager says "Great company for techies to learn and grow"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Sat, 23 Jan 2016

Pros
A great company that gives wonderful opportunity to learn diverse technologies for techies upto Tech Lead. Cisco is market leader in many areas in networking and telecom. Company gives great emphasis to learning, development, empowerment, development of technology etc. Campus in Cessna Business Park has got great facilities including food and sports.

Cons
Lately growth is slowing causing stagnant in salaries and layoffs. Company laid off a few thousand people in the last two years. For managers growth is almost zero. Salaries are average not that great.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, January 21, 2016 4:19 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Fallen upon bad days"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Fallen upon bad days"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Thu, 21 Jan 2016

Pros
Decent work life balance, some great people and a real commitment to CSR. Bunch of nice, if slightly clueless people.

Cons
Incredibly political, not a meritocracy. Lots of good people but degree of passive aggressive behavior is increasing every year. Promotions in lower grades based on merit, mid level onwards it's all based on who you know. Lack of innovation, playing catchup every where. Still a very top heavy company, way too many dead weight VPs that ought to have been fired long ago. Too many fiefdoms and groups. Terrible organizational design

Advice to Senior Management
Acquire some decent talent with product chops. Get your cloud strategy straight, you know you are playing catchup. People need firm direction, so enough of the touchy feely people deal. How can you compete in the world of fast moving startups led by digital natives with hopelessly backdated executives, clearly uncomfortable in social media. Abandon the culture of the celebrity CEO and really, really listen to your front line, not after its filtered by several layers of management.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9287987.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9287987.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, January 21, 2016 3:56 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Decent benefits, frustrating day-to-day existence"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Decent benefits, frustrating day-to-day existence"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Thu, 21 Jan 2016

Pros
Been a while since I looked around but the salary and benefits seem competitive and the company embraces flexible working hours and locations. Being a huge company, the market listens to Cisco giving opportunity to work with a variety of customers all over the world.

Cons
Software projects are distributed over too many global sites leading to inefficiency and frustration in taking and acting upon basic decisions. Proliferation of management layers leads to disconnect between those setting strategy and the rest of the organisation. Continual restructuring and an inability to redeploy workers appropriately leads to regular bouts of talented workers being let go (with corresponding impact on morale).

Advice to Senior Management
Cut out the buzzwords when presenting to staff. Install corporate tools which are less wasteful of staff time.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9287726.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, January 21, 2016 7:26 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Business Transformation Consultant says "Cisco great company, in great market"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Business Transformation Consultant says "Cisco great company, in great market"

From Cisco Systems Business Transformation Consultant (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Thu, 21 Jan 2016

Pros
IMO Cisco is positioned as the number 1 company in the world in IT. We have innovative products across the spectrum of IT infrastructure - data center, collaboration (i.e. phones, webex, business video), networking (route/switch) and security. It is a constantly growing, dynamic company with great leadership. It gives back and does the right thing. A very high integrity company. We have great work flexibility and are able to leverage the best collaboration tools in the world to stay connected and aligned with our mission. We provide strategic solutions that can help solve business challenges of all companies around the world - i.e. speed, agility, flexibility, productivity.

Cons
It's a big company. With that there is a degree of complexity to the business. Some of our services business is a bit more difficult, giving our historical "box selling" orientation. But that is changing a lot.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep going on our digitization path, and investing in our business orientation. Invest even more in services processes and digitization. Keep the information flowing.

From Cisco Systems Customer Service Representative (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 20 Jan 2016

Pros

Cons

Advice to Senior Management

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, January 20, 2016 10:08 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Looks Good on the Outside, Inside not so much"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Looks Good on the Outside, Inside not so much"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 20 Jan 2016

Pros
Flexible work option. The employees who work on the business side (program managers, business analysts, ops mgrs, etc) are very intelligent and committed to getting the job done and doing what is best for Cisco, not themselves.Lots of great personal perks, i.e. on site health center, doctors, gym, personal heath coaching. HR is trying to make Cisco "fun" again and they are making good progress. The new CEO Chuck Robbins is really nice as he looks and he will be a good leader for Cisco. He is focused and committed to making Cisco great again.

Cons
If you are 30+, I suggest you look for another company because Cisco is interested in a younger employee base (even tho all the Sr. Mgmt except 1) is over 40-50. There are little career advancement for people in this age range. If you are under 30, expect a lower pay base because of your "lack of experience." They like your new ideas but will not pay you for them. Over the past 5 years I have seen Cisco lay off thousands of "old timers," people who have been there for 10+ years and who are in the 30s/40s. Focus has been on the new blood, the newly graduated. Avoid IT because their culture is focused on looking good to their management and ignoring what customer and internal tech/users requirement are, very dog eat dog organization. In San Jose the cafeteria food is expensive and you can get a better meal off site for the same price with better quality.

Advice to Senior Management
Relearn how to appreciate employees who have chosen to stay with Cisco through their "glory" days. The "old timers" have contacts within Cisco due to their tenure and get the job done more quickly and/or efficiently versus new people. They are the ones who have refused interviews with more successful (& better stock price) high tech companies. Secondly, really, truly be strategic in business opportunities and investment. The past 15 years has been a mismanagement of new product implementation that ends up failing resulting in laying people off; the lack of strategy is failure on Sr. Management.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9266930.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9266930.htm>
