From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, January 19, 2016 10:31 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "plusses and minuses"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "plusses and minuses"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 19 Jan 2016

Pros
Great environment where you are encouraged to take a risk. Also, great work/life balance with a strong corporate culture of working from home. And, the benefits are excellent.

Cons
Promotions are very hard to come by and are voted on by committee. Makes it hard to grow your career. Salaries are below market. Annual layoffs are disruptive.

Advice to Senior Management
Adequately recognize top performers (salary/stock compensation, as well as career progression) and offer a better career path options.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9251976.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9251976.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, January 18, 2016 12:36 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Business Operations says "Great company if in the correct organization, and or program."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Business Operations says "Great company if in the correct organization, and or program."

From Cisco Systems Business Operations (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Mon, 18 Jan 2016

Pros
Challenging if in the correct group and, or project. Opportunity exists to learn about global business and current industry trends an challenges impacting long term global expansion and corporate sustainability. There is much groundbreaking initiatives on the radar or in progress and an willingness to do it right. Sense of urgency is present regarding these efforts and within the LOBs associated to the work.

Cons
Bloated. Not everyone is doing their bit. Significant passing the buck, and for every achiever, there are multiple non achievers. A significant degree of complacency, which includes biding time for longer term employees. People are staying for the wrong reasons, sapping energy and motivation of those that care. Too many contractors with core knowledge covering for SME roles. Allows the FTEs/SMEs ability to cruise and internal business knowledge is being diluted.

Advice to Senior Management
Weed out the slackers, monitor performance better particularly the WFH culture. Transfer (pullback) core knowledge from contractors and consultants and redirect to Cisco employees. Hold Cisco employees accountable for knowing, and understanding core versus context.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9239543.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9239543.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, January 18, 2016 11:38 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Director Software Development says "Senior Director Software Development"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Director Software Development says "Senior Director Software Development"

From Cisco Systems Senior Director Software Development (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 18 Jan 2016

Pros
Good company to work for. Excellent benefits and compensation. Very flexible with corporate policies and procedures and the culture.

Cons
As long as the Business Unit is bringing good revenue, you are good. The moment BU revenue goes flat or negative YoY, the jobs will be sent to Low Cost locations. Some bad elements always look for building empire and better stay away from such BU's and the leaders.

Advice to Senior Management
When selecting top leaders, always take feedback bottoms up on what challenges the Org is going through so you can pick the right level of leadership. Bring in fresh blood from outside for leadership positions.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9238609.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, January 16, 2016 4:57 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good for regular employee (Blue badge). Avoid joining as a Red badge especially if you are experienced."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good for regular employee (Blue badge). Avoid joining as a Red badge especially if you are experienced."

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sat, 16 Jan 2016

Pros
Multinational environment, high quality jobs. Good and flexible working time, work from home.

Cons
clear distinction between Red badge and Blue. Red badges are considered as a Temp workers and mostly hired for short term jobs and to support Regular employee/manager support. if you are experienced then never join as a red badge otherwise just for few bucks you will loose your dignity and don't be surprise when you have to leave the job in 2 weeks.

Advice to Senior Management
Stop the culture of Red Vs Blue.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9221234.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9221234.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, January 16, 2016 12:26 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Technical Leader says "Tech Lead 2"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Technical Leader says "Tech Lead 2"

From Cisco Systems Senior Technical Leader (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sat, 16 Jan 2016

Pros
Some groups have challenging work and professional environment where one can grow technically. The management encourage the team to innovate and come up with new product ideas. Benefits are decent.

Cons
Most of the groups have lot of middle management which is not aligned to the top management. Sometimes, the middle management is very opaque and it gives the impression to the team that there is lot of politics is at play.

Advice to Senior Management
There should be regular skip level meeting between the engineers and top level management. The action items from the skip level meetings should be tangible and have a fixed deadline for closure.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9219358.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, January 15, 2016 8:22 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems World Wide Sales Intern says "World Wide Sales Intern"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems World Wide Sales Intern says "World Wide Sales Intern"

From Cisco Systems World Wide Sales Intern (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Fri, 15 Jan 2016

Pros
- feeder program for best sales training in the industry - great pay, housing and amenities in Boston or San Jose - primary job is working on top company accounts supporting sales engineers and account managers - great introduction and training to the company technology, sales, every aspect of the business - work next to top talent

Cons
I found no con of this internship. I recommend it to anyone

Advice to Senior Management
Keep investing in this program.... best professional experience of my life

View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9206232.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, January 15, 2016 7:16 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader I says "Mix of hot and cold"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader I says "Mix of hot and cold"

From Cisco Systems Technical Leader I (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 15 Jan 2016

Pros
Good environment for work Healthy knowledge driven ecosystem Decent non-cash employee benefits Well managed facilities Job rotation encouraged

Cons
Sub par pay compared to peer firms Excessive cliques and internecine politics Some projects/managers/BUs demand insane work hours, upsetting work-life balance Overselling company benefits to employees causes disgruntlement

Advice to Senior Management
Be coherent in communication - line managers speak a different language from official communication Significantly improve pay across board, and specifically at mid level (G-10 to G-12) grades. Entry level salaries look bloated in comparison to mid level pay. Yet, middle level grades are made to look like aspiration to ran and file.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, January 14, 2016 10:28 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior User Experience Designer says "A great learning experience"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior User Experience Designer says "A great learning experience"

From Cisco Systems Senior User Experience Designer (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Thu, 14 Jan 2016

Pros
The San Jose campus is huge and often feels like several small companies rather than a large on. Your experience can therefore vary greatly depending on your Business unit / Department. That said, there are some very sharp folks working at Cisco, folks you can learn from provided that put in the effort to reach out and show interest. Depending on your field, Cisco will give you the opportunity to work on groundbreaking projects and technologies. I found benefits and salaries to be competitive

Cons
As it is often the case in large companies, you will bump into folks content with Status Quo. They typically have held their job for many years and are not interested in change, even when shown it is necessary and beneficial. Quite often, those folks have not kept their skills up to date, giving you the impression to step back in time. Changes in the organisation often mean changes in priorities, when they occur faster than it takes to ship a project, some of your work might be wasted.

Advice to Senior Management
Support managers and teams who deliver results and have the company's success in mind rather than their own.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9193409.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9193409.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, January 13, 2016 8:27 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Director says "Lots of leadership change...but still a good company to be in."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Director says "Lots of leadership change...but still a good company to be in."

From Cisco Systems Director (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 13 Jan 2016

Pros
Excellent vacation (20+ days), extremely flexible attitude to telecommuting. Very collaborative culture (in marketing, at least). Very strongly profitable company, and overall reasonably well-run. Good top-down communication and transparency.

Cons
Pretty chaotic at senior leader levels since new CEO Robbins was announced. A lot of layoffs, executive departures...tried and trusted people, processes thrown out without much regard for whether they were effective or not. Either good (tough) decision making, or leaders doing whatever they think they need to do to curry favor with the new CEO. Hard to know which currently.

Advice to Senior Management
Don't throw the baby out with the bath water.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9185490.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9185490.htm>

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Poorly Managed Marketing Department"

From Cisco Systems Marketing Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Wed, 13 Jan 2016

Pros
Work from home. Little management and little work to do. It's like getting paid full time to do a part time job from home.

Cons
Poor management and poor understanding of the technology being marketed. Little appreciation for employees and very few opportunities to grow your career. Low pay. A lot of jockeying for position rather than doing any work. Your colleagues will likely be taking their kids to soccer practice while on a WebEx meeting with you.

Advice to Senior Management
Learn about what each employee is responsible for. Recognize talent rather than aggressive power plays from employees trying to get ahead.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9178192.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9178192.htm>

From Cisco Systems Software Engineering Manager (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 13 Jan 2016

Latest and greatest for network equipment and 40Gb+ optical stuff.

Cons

Advice to Senior Management
Acquiring companies to avoid having to invest in engineering is a valid strategy, but boy it sucks when you are one of the engineers that get acquired.

Pros
Fabulous access to technology. Can have a flexible schedule. Meet people from all over the country.

Cons
They centralized customer service in NC to detriment of quality. They let go of proven long time remote contract workers to hire local teams who lacked the experience and desire for the positions.

Advice to Senior Management
If you are going to sell a suite of Telecommuting products actually use them internally. Please keep in mind your experienced workers are more likely to be loyal to company.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Senior Product Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Senior Product Manager"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 11 Jan 2016

Pros
Great Company, good benefits, great people

Cons
Takes too long to get anything done. Too many managers doing too few things. Upper management has a tendency to not write anything down. Expectation is to get consensus from bottom up all the time so that the management do not have to make any decision

Advice to Senior Management
Simplify the decision process. Management needs to make decisions sometimes that is not based on consensus. Management needs to write things down on a piece of paper so that it can be tracked and they can be accountable for the decision they make.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, January 10, 2016 11:12 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Leader says "Marketing leader"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Leader says "Marketing leader"

From Cisco Systems Marketing Leader (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Sun, 10 Jan 2016

Pros
Big company, areas of potential growth, good company to get some experience working for. Nice perks, great benefits, good pay.

Cons
Not growing except thru acquisitions means it doesn't innovate itself or its core. Stock price will be largely flat/steady, so don't expect a lot of value there. It creates profit and Wall Street positives by cutting costs, which means people are often laid-off and program spending is often cut. The politics are especially harsh. The marketing and communications team is especially dysfunctional due to a terrible CMO surrounded by her lackluster band of mediocre talents.

Advice to Senior Management
Dump the current comms and marketing leadership and get some real talent in there. New CEO Chuck Robbins should pay more attention to the level of talent he has chosen to put in place, and the political moves and broken trust beneath his inner circle.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9139950.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, January 08, 2016 8:29 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Best Company for hard workers"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Best Company for hard workers"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 8 Jan 2016

Pros
People who work hard and are committed, is show equal commitment from the company as well. Job satisfaction is more if you are equally invested in what you are doing. Lateral movements is possible if you prove your worth. Work culture/Benefits depends on the BU you are working in.

Cons
Since it is a large company, sometimes your hard work is rated from among the teams accross CISCO. Benefits also might depend on how well the company does in that quarter which is not directly influenced solely from your team's work. But having said that, it depends on the team/BU you are working.

Advice to Senior Management
More focus on developing in house talent pool and recognizing the best efforts more pro-actively.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, January 08, 2016 4:07 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Work Hard and Deliver Results"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Work Hard and Deliver Results"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2016) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Fri, 8 Jan 2016

Pros
Cisco is a great place to work, and as long as you're willing to work hard and deliver results for customers, you will be rewarded for the work that you do. There have been concrete changes to streamline management in order to facilitate Agile development, with an emphasis on iterative development and continuous integration. I have been impressed with Cisco's adaptation to today's challenging environment and as long as Cisco continues to act on feedback from both customers and individual contributors (i.e. employees), I am positive for Cisco's future. Cisco provides ample opportunities for promotions and career advancements as long as you deliver results and meet or surpass expectations. At least the managers I have worked with have been very professional and will work hard to support you and your professional goals. Overall, my experience at Cisco over the years has been very good. Cisco has gone through some tough changes in recent years. However, I am positive Cisco has come out on the other side much stronger and resilient.

Cons
There are secular market trends working against Cisco, and competitors are causing disruptions to the company. The Cisco of today is markedly different from the Cisco of yesteryear, so hopefully they will be able to turn things around.

Advice to Senior Management
I have been impressed by management's boldness to make concrete changes in management structure and proactively communicating them to everyone in the organization. The transparency is much appreciated.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9125347.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9125347.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, January 08, 2016 10:42 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer says "Wonderful company to start and grow with"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer says "Wonderful company to start and grow with"

From Cisco Systems Systems Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 8 Jan 2016

Pros
Depending on your team and your customer(s), you will have very different experiences. I've been lucky enough to come in through their new hire program (CSAP - Cisco Sales Associates Program) and consistently be part of very young, energetic teams. I love the aggressiveness and go-getter mentality prevalent within my team, and my organization as a whole. It matches very well with the energy we experience working with our customers in Silicon Valley. I've also had great luck with managers -- they are caring and involved, notice the work you as an individual contributor are putting in, and really show their appreciation.

Cons
Cisco is of course a very large company, and with it comes the extensive red tape that makes significant change difficult. So, although you get incredible stability and perks working with such a well established organization, it is also very hard to instigate change. Trying to change how a particular product platform works or add significant feature improvements across multiple platforms will take a very long time.

Advice to Senior Management
Please listen to what we are saying from the field! Competition, especially in the Bay Area, is extremely intense, and we need to innovate more quickly and respond to field feedback more quickly to stay ahead.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9121698.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9121698.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, January 06, 2016 5:08 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Best Internship by far!"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Best Internship by far!"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Wed, 6 Jan 2016

Pros
Cisco Systems at RTP by far has been one of the best experiences. The University Experience team and made the process seamless. As an intern, onboarding week made me feel comfortable and welcomed with open arms. The opportunities at Cisco Systems are endless. With the love and support of my colleagues, I was given the opportunity to learn about myself, team work and why Cisco Systems is the #1 Technology company in the world. My projects were challenging and one-one-one sessions with key stakeholders in the company were engaging as well. I was given the opportunity to solve one of Cisco's problems and present my findings to management, and the VP of my org. Definitely my best internship by far and would recommend the company to others. I have chosen to stay at Cisco for my first post-college career position.

Cons
Not so much of a bad thing, but Cisco is what you make it! It is completely up to you on how your career will be at the company. I have learned this very quickly in my internship and will be keep it with me as I begin full-time.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, January 05, 2016 6:07 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Intern says "WWS Summer Internship"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Intern says "WWS Summer Internship"

From Cisco Systems Intern (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 5 Jan 2016

Pros
This internship was such an amazing opportunity! In one summer full of fun & learning, with new experiences each and every day, Cisco Systems and employees taught me more than I ever imagined. I had access to industry professionals, the work was meaningful (I never was the coffee runner), the pay was VERY COMPETITIVE, built upon skills and gained new skills I could use on any job, and the whole summer was full of networking and personal and career building tasks. I would recommend this internship to anyone who is willing to have a team of managers and personal mentor who will see their flaws and help you build upon them, also someone who is hardworking and never gives up!

Cons
They gave us Mac laptops, I didnt know how to use it in the beginning but I caught on fast and LOVED IT!

Advice to Senior Management
Management was great, I have no words other than Cisco ROCKS!

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, January 05, 2016 4:14 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Communications Manager says "Internal Communications"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Communications Manager says "Internal Communications"

From Cisco Systems Marketing Communications Manager (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 5 Jan 2016

Pros
My team had a very close collaboration culture. Lots of interesting work with the ability to implement leading best practices in digital marketing. Emphasis on aligning with other teams and making sure that activities were coordinated between groups.

Cons
Political maneuvering at the top meant lots of reorgs and layoffs. That was hard on our team, which had cultivated deep friendships and trust over the years. Really devastating, because cuts were made not based on skills but based on $$.

Advice to Senior Management
Methodical business planning and implementation would enable more strategic staff reorganizations and improve morale. Stop with knee-jerk management and listen to your employees!

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9085039.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9085039.htm>

Pros
Cisco allows for flexible hours and has a Good work life balance. It recently launched a paid paternity leave program

Cons
As any big company there is always the layoff threat as a response to stakeholders expectations or changes in the financial markets

Advice to Senior Management
It looks like in every restructuring there is not consideration to the talent that is being let go since the decisions are based on business areas instead of individual performance. If a restructuring needs to be done, keep the good talent and move it to a different area

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, January 04, 2016 11:41 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer says "Ok, if no other opportunities"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer says "Ok, if no other opportunities"

From Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Mon, 4 Jan 2016

Pros
+ Good pay + Good exposure to technology + Good colleagues

Cons
+ If you are from good institute, expecting good companies, and you get this offer from out-campus with job as contract employee, be aware that it may delay your career growth + Conversion from contract to full-time employee is long, even though manager proposes as few 6-8 months + Slightly politics plays it's role while getting promote or convert + You will have to spend at least 3 years to get out with experience in your hand, make sure you can work as contract employee till then + Even after conversion, you will have to spend one year as promised, so delays you again. + Concluding: If you don't have any other opportunity then without looking twice accept it.

Advice to Senior Management
+ It's better to expect the work, as you pay.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, January 04, 2016 1:27 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Technical Sales Engineer Intern"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Technical Sales Engineer Intern"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 4 Jan 2016

Pros
Fantastic culture - culture will vary from team to team, but from what I've seen the teams are close. Everyone supports each other. Furthermore, everyone is extremely smart and NICE. As an intern, everyone in the office was willing to chat with me about topics ranging from career advice to the World Cup. Market leaders - it's not a startup culture where you're going to have to convince a company to set up meetings with you so you can pitch your product. The people at Cisco have been cultivating these relationships with companies for years. Thus, when I would sit in on sales calls and meetings, I was truly learning from some of the industry's best reps and engineers. Executive speaker series - I got to learn from people who have been in the industry for decades and how to go about navigating my career. Their wisdom is invaluable and they picked some truly inspirational people to talk to us!

Cons
The EIC program was new so there were some issues that need to be worked out, such as correspondence with the account managers whom we were assigned to work with. Sometimes the accounts were not high priority for the AMs at the time. There was almost too much down-time for my liking, as we were assigned an account every 1.5 weeks and most of the account research and presentation would be done before then.

Advice to Senior Management
Perhaps for the EIC program, as it continues to grow, assign more than one person to help manage the program. When there were pressing questions/issues and the program manager wasn't available it was frustrating to wait. Please assign more projects and assignments other than account research.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9070039.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9070039.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, January 02, 2016 12:14 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager says "pros and cons"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager says "pros and cons"

From Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sat, 2 Jan 2016

Pros
Large Corporate that is not easily going to be out of business soon. Their portfolio is quite complex and that allows diverse and resilient business opportunities. Their stock is stable and does not go through many up and down turmoils as of lately

Cons
Duplication of initiative is a major concern when you compare it to a smaller firms that have more control over what is going on and insight into it.

Advice to Senior Management
spin off some of the firm assets and business so that there is focus on what the core businesses. It is not a bad idea to discontinue some of the businesses

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, December 31, 2015 9:39 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Solutions Architect says "Great Experience, great company."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Solutions Architect says "Great Experience, great company."

From Cisco Systems Solutions Architect (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Thu, 31 Dec 2015

Pros
Access to great minds. If you network, you have a lot of access to people that can help and help you advance positions. You can get a position that requires travel to stay in your preferred area. Training is always available for free for Cisco products, but I always had training for other company products as a choice.

Cons
It's harder to advance if you are in the technical side and not in a major city where Cisco has a presence. Big company politics (just like any other). Lots of organizational changes. Sales organization is favored over other divisions.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, December 30, 2015 3:13 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Social company but management skills lacking"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Social company but management skills lacking"

From Cisco Systems Program Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 30 Dec 2015

Pros
Many social activities, employees are treated very well (bear in mind that's around 50 - 60% of all the staff, rest are contractors)

Cons
Culture affected by 40% of contractors around - not such a 'family' feel as could otherwise be the case. Management, people management and leadership skills of many managers lacking - possibly no training for them from HR and many people stay at Cisco for a long time and therefore move up without coaching, etc. No job descriptions - I might have been unlucky but both my jobs came with no or poor job descriptions. This resulted in being asked to do things that were not agreed during my interview and me needing to defend my role. It also resulted in a new manager being assigned to us without any prior experience in our area.

Advice to Senior Management
Be smarter with putting the right people with right skills into the right jobs (that's what JDs tend to be for) + invest into training of your leaders and managers + get feedback from both employees and contractors about how their management is doing since your pool of contractors is certainly not small

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9030804.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW9030804.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, December 24, 2015 12:39 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems ASIC Design Engineer says "It is What You Make of It"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems ASIC Design Engineer says "It is What You Make of It"

From Cisco Systems ASIC Design Engineer (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 5 of 5 found this helpful — Thu, 24 Dec 2015

Pros
Generally speaking the work environment is very flexible, as long as you're producing quality work. The compensation was reasonable, but it varies widely based on what group you're in and what projects you're working on. The newer projects obviously get priority when it comes to budget, as well as the workload.

Cons
As said in another review of Cisco that I read, it is very easy to slowly get sucked-in and end up working 14 hour days. Generally speaking, you will be rewarded based on what you put into it. So if you choose to put up boundaries and stick to a 40-hour week, you'll be comfy and cozy. If you choose to put in 60-80 hour weeks, you're likely to be elevated in the long term (provided you're not in a group that's approaching "sustaining-mode" where there is very little new development). If you're lucky enough to get into the "in-crowd" and you're a hard worker that puts out quality product, you're set for life. Cisco has a very elite group of people that jump ship every few years, create a new start-up (i.e. ensime, nuovo, andiamo), work their tails' off, get purchased by Cisco making tons of money, and repeat. But getting into that group is extremely difficult even if you're good at what you do. There's a bit of class-ism in the Cisco HW department.

Advice to Senior Management
I don't have any advice. Cisco is a giant machine that is fiercely loyal to it's shareholders. It's no longer a place for good people to grow into great ones. It's just a place where a few great engineers hold reign over lots of good/average engineers. I was there for 8 years. I would do about 60% of it over again, but I wouldn't stick around as long. If you're standing still there, you're moving backwards.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8994336.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8994336.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, December 23, 2015 4:11 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Cost Center Manager says "Great colleagues. Smart people. Future thinking company."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Cost Center Manager says "Great colleagues. Smart people. Future thinking company."

From Cisco Systems Cost Center Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 23 Dec 2015

Pros
Thriving on its ability to continually outperform competition and markets, Cisco is an establishment where you can learn fast, be independent and grow according to your capability to adapt and change.

Cons
With its consistent culture of providing the best for full timers and senior management, it becomes tricky to know how to navigate your way. Watch who you see as a leader and who you think is a mentor. Never judge a book by its hierarchical cover. Advise to do deep checks on who your hiring manager is and negotiate well on your salary and benefits.

Advice to Senior Management
No one is perfect, kudos so far. Might help to go back to basics of grooming your people to provide what is good to partners and customers.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, December 23, 2015 2:56 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "IT Engineer Intern"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "IT Engineer Intern"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Wed, 23 Dec 2015

Pros
1st Week of Orientation, they really take care of you well. Catered lunches, tossing around a water balloon, Dave N' Busters party. Big Companies have fun events / orientation. The rest of the summer you get paid well for not being too useful. Interns generally are not of much use from what I observed, the learning curve takes a month or so, and so your potential productivity can only be a few weeks. They're not hiring you for your work-output, but to entice you to come work there full-time. I'm glad I interned here, it was great to try a big company, the pay was good, and it served as a great stepping-stone on my resume.

Cons
Your experience is highly dependent on your mentor / manager. They're the ones assigning you work, and they'll be the ones deciding whether you get a return offer. If your manager is non-technical, then your mentor will almost exclusively decide himself/herself. This isn't so much a con as much of a warning. I know other interns in my program who weren't happy with their mentor/managers and didn't receive any guidance from them. One definitive Con is that I wasn't integrated very well with my team. I talked to them a handful of times over the summer but I think they barely knew who I was, so I didn't get a great inclusive-feel. I only got to know the contractor sitting directly next to me.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8991860.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8991860.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, December 23, 2015 9:51 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Project Manager says "Cisco Unplugged"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Project Manager says "Cisco Unplugged"

From Cisco Systems Project Manager (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Wed, 23 Dec 2015

Pros
Cisco is an international powerhouse that has significant presence in almost every country in the world. They strive to stay on the cutting edge of technology as they compete against all comers in the international network technology space.

Cons
Cisco is a "tale of two cities" having a smaller full-time employee force of around 25,000 full-time employees worldwide that is complemented by a much larger outside contractor workforce that they turn over very quickly based upon a contractor's length of contract. As an outside contractor, it is very apparent that you are treated as a second class worker that is thrown into a large pool of other outside contractors. Consequently, contractor morale is very bad and as such Cisco's work environment is quite toxic.

Advice to Senior Management
Cisco senior management needs to make a strong effort to examine the horrendous work environment they've created and take the steps necessary to ensure that all workers, both permanent and outsourced are made to feel as though they are working for the same team.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8989711.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8989711.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, December 22, 2015 12:29 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Female friendly benefits, but not managers"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Female friendly benefits, but not managers"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Tue, 22 Dec 2015

Pros
Flexible work hours Interesting projects Training opportunities

Cons
Not wholly welcoming of women.. out of our small office, one woman was fired for "being too aggressive", one woman (single mom) quit because she was counseled for taking too much time to take care of her kids (none of the wives of the male managers work), and two were counseled and told they needed to be "warmer" and "nicer" because they were offending their male colleagues. All in the span of 30 days.

Advice to Senior Management
Mandatory gender bias training for middle managers, at the very least.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, December 22, 2015 8:28 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Solid Company with great Bene"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Solid Company with great Bene"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 22 Dec 2015

Pros
Great culture to work in. Overall Management is good with some pockets of "how did they get here?" Fun place to work with really good benefits. Pay is pretty good for industry, but movement can be restrictive by HR red tape. "We will promote you for your same current pay" kind of stuff.

Cons
Don't get stuck in non essential roles. Every October, they clean house at or around 10% of workforce.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep the culture small, with customer focus and doing the right thing at the forefront. Focus where the market is strong and don't spread the portfolio so thin.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8980566.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8980566.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, December 22, 2015 8:06 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "CSCO from a Gen Y"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "CSCO from a Gen Y"

From Cisco Systems Account Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 22 Dec 2015

Pros
Market leading products, world class engineers, and loyal customers. The best product support in the industry, and the biggest reseller channel in the world.

Cons
There are so many products that you need to understand. From video surveillance to wireless to communications, there are lots of niche competitors that have a single pitch against Cisco.

Advice to Senior Management
Fix the commission structure for selling advanced technologies. It takes 5-10X the cycles to sell full-scale ATs, and the deal sizes are 50-90% less than full-scale switch refreshes.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8980348.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

From Cisco Systems Product Manager of Cisco-SB (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sun, 20 Dec 2015

Pros
Fantastic Networking technology is Cisco company. People in Jammaz distribution people are friendly and collaborative; grew fast in the past 10 years and got a lot of chances to switch between different roles.

Cons
Organization is too stable, turnover rate is very high. None of colleagues in my departments left over last 5 years because wages is highly paid than industry average.

Advice to Senior Management
There will be all kinds of ways that you and your staff could spend your time, many of them quite worthy. But some will have more of an impact than others, and those are the ones you need to focus on—which means saying no to the others.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, December 18, 2015 4:47 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "It used to be a great"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "It used to be a great"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Fri, 18 Dec 2015

Pros
Company benefits are outstanding, the tops in the industry. Highly competitive environment, flexible scheduling, with some of the most talented people in the industry.

Cons
Lots of redundancy between teams in the same business unit as well as the rest of the company. This is due to the company treating all teams as their own startup. The good is that it allows teams to build and identity and business for themselves, the bad is that when resources are scarce, the political games begin and rather than collaborate, you end up with multiple versions of the same product or service with varying degrees of quality. Lack of structure or structure that is not properly defined. Your success is dependent on the manager you get. No longer looking to hire experience, only looking to rent it.

Advice to Senior Management
Management needs to bring in a little bit more structure not bureaucracy. Rather than having a someone come up with an idea, building it themselves, and attempt to take it to market - have them actually use teams specifically for those tasks.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8951726.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8951726.htm>

Cons

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, December 17, 2015 10:09 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Human Resources Intern says "HR Intern"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Human Resources Intern says "HR Intern"

From Cisco Systems Human Resources Intern (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Thu, 17 Dec 2015

Pros
The HR internship was a phenomenal experience. I got to work with different areas of Cisco and had real ownership over my projects. The program itself is constantly improving because the senior leadership is willing to listen to us on how to improve. Love the flexibility within Cisco as well. My co-workers were awesome too!

Cons
Because Cisco is such a huge company, it can be difficult to find people or fun events to participate in. Unlike some of the start ups around, there isn't a happy hour after work every day to make friends and get to know people. That's the trade off for being at a more established and stable company.

Advice to Senior Management
Use young people more in Cisco We might not ave the technical skills yet, but many of us are overflowing with new and creative ideas to change the status quo.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, December 16, 2015 2:39 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly says "A fun experience with a traditional software company"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly says "A fun experience with a traditional software company"

From Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 16 Dec 2015

Pros
Cisco is an established company who knows what they're doing. They are serious about their image as a family oriented company. It really feels like you are part of a community, although I'm sure that view changes wildly based on your team.

Cons
They are a large corporation, with a large and strange bureaucracy at times. Everything moves slowly and requires quite a bit of fighting to get pushed through.

Advice to Senior Management
Don't lose the culture. Remember what makes Cisco different from other companies. Don't be afraid to make the hard decisions.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, December 15, 2015 9:54 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Re-Energized"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Re-Energized"

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 15 Dec 2015

Pros
Exciting new leadership - at all levels of the company - so the company feels very energizing and focused. Spending a lot of time and attention on investing in people - engagement, recognition, performance as well as salary and merit money. Good bonus structure and benefits.

Cons
The biggest challenge is the ability to change jobs within the company. Creating or influencing change is also difficult - like moving a battleship.

Advice to Senior Management
We cannot develop if we cannot find new opportunities in the company. If the organization does not focus on finding ways to create internal movement, they will continue to see talent leaving the company.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8929734.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, December 15, 2015 3:00 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good Company"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good Company"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 15 Dec 2015

Pros
Good benefits. For the most part management open to teleworking. Good technology, top in their field. Stable Company, money in bank. Salaries competitive.

Cons
Promotions difficult to get. Will try to bring you in at a level or two below what you are worth -- don't bite. Aggressive acquisition strategy leads to yearly layoffs which they disguise as limited restructuring. Say they want you to be innovative don't believe them, they buy their innovation, and when it comes down to it not appreciative of it. People management skill level low.

Advice to Senior Management
Back up what you say. People will only believe you for so long.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Good employer, good pay and benefits"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Good employer, good pay and benefits"

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 15 Dec 2015

Pros
Cisco payscales are very good. Benefits and Bonus are great too. If you are in senior mgmt you get good RSU's which are icing on the overall compensation package.

Cons
Cisco is not the same company it was 10 years ago. No more the IT bell weather stock company it was a few years ago. Still a good place to work mainly because of the compensation. But overall, there is no clear direction of where the company is heading..

Advice to Senior Management
R&S is going to slowly lose its significance. Have a clear strategy for Data Center or Security and go full steam ahead.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, December 14, 2015 6:51 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Cisco India - Bangalore"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Cisco India - Bangalore"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Mon, 14 Dec 2015

Pros
Work Life balance. Opportunity to interact with big names in industry (if you take the initiative), you get to learn a lot from such experiences. Fairly open management. People are helpful. I loved working with the people here.

Cons
Opportunities to grow are few. Cisco is a sluggish mover. People tend to be on cruise-mode. Lack of innovative initiatives from within the company, to be fair, there are platforms created, but, somehow the products/ideas which come out of them die (again, a lot of times, because of the bureaucratic, sluggish nature of the process to productize it.)

Advice to Senior Management
Need to be more nimble. There are certain products which are cruising, move the best engineers out from them and put them in more challenging roles. If a good engineer is not challenged enough, either he/she would get rusted or just move on. Need to work to bring back the "COOLNESS" back in Cisco. From being the most sort after company to work for, it has turned into an archaic old-school company to work for.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8911187.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8911187.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, December 14, 2015 6:46 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Not for career-oriented"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Not for career-oriented"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Mon, 14 Dec 2015

Pros
Excellent Bonus, Good work life balance, flexible timing, work-from-home, No desktops at all, everyone gets laptop. Great resting place between two demanding jobs, may be for an year or two People including Managers are very good, treatment of employees is very good Cafeteria facilities are very good, at least in Cessna Business Park which houses Cisco's own campus. Transport facility is there at a reasonable price for permanent employees, contractors can avail of it but pretty expensive for them. Easy hiring for contractors, the process is tougher for permanent employees

Cons
Not a great place if you are career-oriented. Things move too slowly, and hardly anything ever gets done Vision and Strategy is missing for most BUs. No long-term thinking. Stay longer, and employability outside decreases phenomenally Ad-hoc, difficult-to-explain firings (not necessarily bad performers) Promotions are very difficult. Un-organized hierarchy, nobody know which designation is senior or junior, or who falls where. No HR involvement once you get hired, they only recruit you after that they never check on you. Contractors to Permanent Employees ratio is approx 8:2 (this could be BU specific), and hiring of contractual workers is very lenient, so you end up with lots of poor performers.

Advice to Senior Management
Get a vision

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8911138.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8911138.htm>

Management team is great, always work together with the team and also encourage them to put their opinion during the meetings.

View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8897284.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, December 11, 2015 11:59 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Consulting Systems Engineer says "Good but the machine gets in your way"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Consulting Systems Engineer says "Good but the machine gets in your way"

From Cisco Systems Consulting Systems Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Fri, 11 Dec 2015

Pros
Cisco is a fun place to work, at least if you're in the sales part of the business. You can usually work from home and take flexible hours provided you're serving your customers well. Career options are great, you can move around the business relatively easily. Opportunities to move to different countries are frequent and often encouraged. Lots of opportunities to do side projects and define your own activities. Very little 'micro-managing'. Rewards outside of base pay are encouraged and easy to distribute, creating a good culture with positive feedback.

Cons
No inflationary payrises. Very difficult to get promotions without being a skilled political operative. Managers powerless to help employees in this area as they don't control any budget. Everything goes through a big HR machine. Everything and everyone is a number and cost to be reduced. Managers are usually looking upwards focussed on their own careers, not paying attention to their employees. Can go months without a performance review or any guidance as to your own career. Promotions, payrises etc all shrouded in secrecy. Leavers usually not replaced, or replaced slowly. Being 5 heads down is common and workload thrown to employees without any consultation or apology. This in turn affects sales commission. Technical strategy is weak in areas due to massive in-fightning between business units. Huge egos run parts of the business. Fear is a frequently used motivational tool.

Advice to Senior Management
Look after employees better, focus on their careers (their success will make your success). Spend the time needed to help them with reviews, pay and so on. Don't be opaque about it salaries. Be honest when people leave and address the team; don't let everyone find out on the grapevine. You've got the fun down well, now make it rewarding and focus on our careers!

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8896691.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8896691.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco is in a period of dramatic change"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 11 Dec 2015

Pros
The CEO just turned over, and the new CEO is showing signs of positive change, which are already showing throughout the organization. A focus on cloud, a desire to for organizational agility. Smart, aggressive people get rewarded.

Cons
Not everyone has gotten the memo that things are changing at Cisco. It gets difficult to rally the entire organization, because the entire organization is so massive.

Advice to Senior Management
Communicate the changes in Cisco outside of Cisco. I wouldn't have believed it had I not lived it.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, December 11, 2015 9:40 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Business Analyst says "Like a tree that looks fine from the outside but has rot in the center"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Business Analyst says "Like a tree that looks fine from the outside but has rot in the center"

From Cisco Systems Business Analyst (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 11 Dec 2015

Pros
Wonderful people: smart, capable, caring, and fun to be around. The Cisco employees I worked with are friends as well as as work-mates. Cool products: Cisco usually has products at the front edge of technology and they have the money and influence to make things happen.

Cons
Lack of clarity about the mission, incoherent execution. Probably because of it's R&D-by-acquisition approach Cisco has internal silos and no coherent, cross-functional, operations capability so it is inefficient and has difficulty focusing on a clearly defined objective.

Advice to Senior Management
Efficiency and effectiveness will become more of a differentiator and without a strong enterprise operations capability margins will continue to erode.

Pros

Cons

The route through preferred suppliers can create an unhealthy, complacent work environment, lacking motivation. Poor decisions and lack of productivity can be very costly in the long run.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, December 08, 2015 4:57 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Account Manger says "Great Company... needs to evolve fasters"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Account Manger says "Great Company... needs to evolve fasters"

From Cisco Systems Account Manger (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Tue, 8 Dec 2015

Pros
Great culture, everyone happy to collaborate and help each other. Management hierarchy is relatively flat and most managers are very open to conversations and getting stuck in at all levels of the business. Packages are competitive, and the commission get's exciting when you star to overachieve.. Cisco of course carries a big brand into a lot of accounts so getting in front of customers is never a challenge...

Cons
Still a hardware vendor first, massively needs to look at becoming more software driven, and refining the cloud proposition - and fast. Work needs to be done on Cisco's business relevance to IoT, digitization and the move towards applications and software.

Advice to Senior Management
Focus on the future of the business, not the short term weekly forecast/hardware sales.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, December 06, 2015 10:57 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Manager, Software Development says "Good Opportunities"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Manager, Software Development says "Good Opportunities"

From Cisco Systems Manager, Software Development (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sun, 6 Dec 2015

Pros
There's always opportunities within Cisco to learn and grow. The environment is for the most part supportive. Work is plentiful and the competitors keep the work interesting.

Cons
Offshoring and hiring H1B workers is abused by Cisco. There's a lot of benefit in having a diverse workforce and the org chart in engineering is almost entirely indian or asian. It's difficult to attract new grads in the US in this type of environment.

Advice to Senior Management
Understand the impact of the H1B program and how it hurts the company in the long run. Restructuring is typically a good thing, but having yearly layoffs and hiring offshore instead results in bad morale and an indifference to making cisco successful.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8841679.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, December 06, 2015 10:44 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer, Security Sales says "Systems Engineer, Security Sales"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer, Security Sales says "Systems Engineer, Security Sales"

From Cisco Systems Systems Engineer, Security Sales (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Sun, 6 Dec 2015

Pros
Cisco remains a challenging environment, driven for excellence. For those able to keep up, you're rewarded well, and surrounded by expert peers, managers, and senior managers committed to your success. Training, lab equipment, peer support are readily available for any assignment or task. The mutual respect and support make Cisco a wonderful place to work. The good pay and excellent benefits add icing to the cake. Working from home is a huge plus! The customers are also very easy to work with because they recognize and respect the level of expertise Cisco engineers bring to the conversation. I love my customers!

Cons
The demand for your expertise is constant. You have to know how to delegate responsibility to other teams, and learn how to use your resources, the sales team, and partners to get the job done. Otherwise, you'll end up working 12 hour days constantly. (My colleagues who don't delegate are probably accusing me of only working half a day!)

Advice to Senior Management
Cisco's broad technical expertise and product completeness win deals all day long but customers complain about the level of expertise needed to manage them. We should continue to expand our managed services portfolio, and offer regular 'health checks' to ensure customers are up to date in software and configuration.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8837594.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8837594.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, December 05, 2015 11:02 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Account Exec"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Account Exec"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Sat, 5 Dec 2015

Pros
Was once a great company when I started. I call this Cisco 1.0. A lot of momentum and product is very sticky. Powerful company that owns their partner community. Some very good people

Cons
Many of the managers think their customer is their boss. They sell up and forget that the real Big C customer can fire them instantly unlike the managers who don't have real Big C customers. They missed two huge transitions, cloud and virtualization. ACI is an attempt to put the cat back into the proprietary bag similar to IBM with Micro Channel. Customers do not want lock in and also want quicker feature delivery which means software.

Advice to Senior Management
Get out, get down in the trenches and talk to the people who are on the front lines. Encourage them to be honest and don't punish. Tell all managers that if you don't have a Big C customer you support directly your Little C customer is then most important. Your boss is not your customer, he will watch how you support you big C or little C customer and reward you accordingly. Without this approach you are quickly heading to the same result as IBM. I saw that movie as well and it didn't end well.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8831914.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8831914.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, December 04, 2015 12:47 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader says "Poor management and antiquated technologies"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader says "Poor management and antiquated technologies"

From Cisco Systems Technical Leader (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Fri, 4 Dec 2015

Pros
-Healthcare -Employee Stock Purchase Plan -3-year hardware refresh -Ability to telecommute

Cons
-Horrible funds for the 401k in addition to a very low match -Employees are not awarded based on their performance, but rather who ingratiates themselves with management the most. -Managers are inept and often generations behind in their understanding of technologies. -Promotions are awarded based on who directors/VP, etc. like not on true performance. -Micro management nightmare

Advice to Senior Management
Get rid of the bloat within middle and senior management. You are no longer innovative and continue trying to catch up to more innovative companies (Palo Alto for example). Those currently employed in middle and upper management do not understand the current tech environment and are often former DBAs, etc.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, December 04, 2015 10:12 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Partner Marketing Manager says "Partner Marketing Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Partner Marketing Manager says "Partner Marketing Manager"

From Cisco Systems Partner Marketing Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 4 Dec 2015

Pros
World class company. Many Type A employees. $50B in revenue which makes it tough to grow significantly. Top compensation packages and benefits. Many interesting projects on routing and switching, cloud and IoT.

Cons
Frequent reorganizations and layoffs. Most of the business is stilled tied to routing and switching which are slow growing businesses. Disorganized and Constant budget pressure and the need to do more with less resources. Lots of hidden headcount with contractors which account for 70K heads.

Advice to Senior Management
Stop the continual reorgs and layoffs. More transparency on how the executive team is being measured and rewarded. Do a better job of setting budgets. Allow more time for impacted employees to find a job internally.

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "for the most part, a really good group of smart people"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "for the most part, a really good group of smart people"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Thu, 3 Dec 2015

Pros
Security sales. Good sales organization that might be losing its edge. Doesn't always understand how to leverage matrixed teams in a uniform manner. A-Player, smart focused sales and system engineers that want to get the job done.

Cons
Politics of a large company. The security team has lost focus since Chris Young left. High turnover among leadership team.

Advice to Senior Management
You are losing good people. Demonstrate you value your team.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, December 03, 2015 5:33 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Management confused"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Management confused"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Thu, 3 Dec 2015

Pros
People in general is friendly and easy going.

Cons
The manager(s) do not know what the requirements of a job are, interview and offer positions that does not match what must be done at job. A total chaos of processes and workflows, very disorganized documentation, fragmented. Too many politicians and no actions to correct evident errors. A lot of time lost in meetings that are not important or relevant to the job. Manager doesn't make follow up and doesn't know how to assign tasks because are not aware of what Io do. For more than 3 months there never was possible to get a working place, resources and real assignment. It was a waste of time.

Advice to Senior Management
Educate themselves in effective management. Minimize the meeting time. Assign and balance work and tasks to the team. Respect and do follow up meetings.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8810440.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8810440.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, November 30, 2015 12:37 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Great Benefits, Mediocre Management Decisions That is Leading to Poor Morale"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Great Benefits, Mediocre Management Decisions That is Leading to Poor Morale"

From Cisco Systems Marketing Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 30 Nov 2015

Pros
Excellent benefits (bonus structure, ESPP, PTO, Good work-life balance but it is up to you to set it and stick to it Great telecommuting options For the most part, good people at the individual level who just want to do good work in a positive manner Promotions and raises do come to those who fight for themselves Was able to grow career substantially but it needs to be under the right leaders. A poor manager stifles this

Cons
Disconnect between what the senior management (VP level) perceives and what is actually occurring within their org Frequent re-orgs means cutting great talent Changing directions and priorities make it a challenge to stick to one strategy for a sustaining period 401k match is good but could be better (currently at 4.5%) Cisco is a low/no growth company which means managing expenses to the tenth degree. This means budget cuts, lack of travel for customer engagements, no backfilling lost talent, etc.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8780349.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8780349.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, November 29, 2015 11:57 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good Company, but Much Room for Improvement"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good Company, but Much Room for Improvement"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sun, 29 Nov 2015

Pros
Good work/life balance. Employees are mature, reasonable, and professional for the most part. Good compensation and benefits. Company and senior leaders appear ethical. Some freedom to move laterally around the company.

Cons
Too much organizational shuffling is lowering productivity and morale. Too much emphasis placed on polished communication skills and politicking and not enough on results. Hierarchical management styles with lower grades not likely to contradict higher ups.

Advice to Senior Management
Provide avenues for high achievers to be promoted and recognized. Stability is also needed for many to feel fully vested in the company.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8771170.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8771170.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, November 29, 2015 9:39 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Great Company, Hard Work."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Great Company, Hard Work."

From Cisco Systems Program Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Sun, 29 Nov 2015

Pros
You'll never get bored working at Cisco and there are always new opportunities to chose from. If you take advantage of the internal "Glide" program, you can transfer horizontally to another job role (such as from Engineer over to Project Manager). Not many companies offer that kind of flexibility.

Cons
The work is hard and the hours can be very long. The pay is on the high end of average for this industry, but you won't get rich off of your base pay. Cisco is a meritocracy where contribution is rewarded (both by peers and by managers). Also, if the company does well, the annual bonuses can be quite nice.

Advice to Senior Management
Give up on ACI. It's a doomed product that I don't think could be successful even if everything worked perfectly as documented.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8770306.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8770306.htm>

From Cisco Systems Associate Sales Representative (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Sat, 28 Nov 2015

There is a cabana bar, a play to putt-putt, a movie theater room. Unlimited coffee, tea, snacks in lobby area. Everyone is friendly

Cons
I haven't started working at Cisco yet so I'm not sure of the cons...there are a lot of buildings so it might be difficult to meet employees in other departments!

Advice to Senior Management
Sometimes recruiters don't get back in a timely manner. More open communication would be beneficial

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great place for sales people"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sat, 28 Nov 2015

Pros
Autonomy if consistent performer Army of resources New products and services always being introduced Great network of partners Smart, quality, customer-oriented co-workers Wonderful team atmosphere

Cons
Politics of middle management Information management--"It's on the web." HR is absent--one of the most telling signs was that, outside of a few formal programs, there didn't seem to be much emphasis on personal development

Advice to Senior Management
Keep the good people. Partner with employees to help them achieve their career goals. Continue to acquire solid tech companies. Be more vocal in pushing a cyber security agenda.

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 25 Nov 2015

Pros
Decent work culture, zeal for innovation and solve issues differently makes Cisco a very good place to work. Teams are equipped with multiple technical capabilities. There is a bit of initiation on the innovation just stared.

Cons
Felt that Cisco needs to pay some attention on it's people.If you are a new hire, you may not complain but people stay for more than 5-6 years are not happy with what Cisco offers. Should push for more innovative ideas and adapt problem solving skills.

Advice to Senior Management
Explore new opportunities and encourage teams to purse different technologies. Apart from solving customer problems alone, leave some space for innovation.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, November 24, 2015 12:10 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Global Marketer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Global Marketer"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 24 Nov 2015

Pros
Great people with deep experience. Bench strength was phenomenal -- deep subject matter expertise in a broad array of capabilities. Mature org that meant it was rare to see a mandate without the resource plan to make it happen -- far different than many tech companies in that regard.

Cons
Going through a major re-org throughout most of my time there. I had three bosses and four roles in less than 18 months. Profesionally, that was invigorating but it didn't yeild as high a contribution that a bit more stability would have afforded.

Advice to Senior Management
John Chamber set a great course and a high bar. The next generation will need to be equally adept at pivoting the business as the speed of change keeps accelerating.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, November 23, 2015 2:57 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Sales Support Advisor says "Great "School""
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Sales Support Advisor says "Great "School""

From Cisco Systems Sales Support Advisor (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 23 Nov 2015

Pros
One of the best ''schools'' in the world for new technologies. It was like a river of knowledge that just kept on flowing and flowing, and would never run dry.

Cons
Some people feel frustrated when they see you succeed and get better results than them. So they will do all they can do make your life miserable, including bullying you and say all sorts of lies to get others to dislike you as well. It takes a lot of strength of character to handle that and come away with your Dignity intact, but it's possible, because I did it.

Advice to Senior Management
Learn to treat employees as human beings, such as yourselves. Treat them like you would like to be treated and maybe you'll be surprised with the response.
