Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager, Corporate Communications says "Chief of Staff"

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager, Corporate Communications (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 23 Nov 2015

Pros
great company with mart people! new leadership has big shoes to fill, that said - Mr Robbins knows exactly what he's dealing with and has a strong vision and support front he Board about what Cisco needs to do differently going forward, and lastly, i was the proudest employee when I worked for this company - in touch with the community and the humans that make Cisco strong, and Cisco takes and time and enables good things for its employees and the communities its in.

Cons
its a big company with some big company problems - and yes there are politics and BS that goes on - no different than most places. in my opinion, its an authentic place with a culture that has allowed people to have a POV and speak up about it without a problem if done productively. there have been lots of people changes since mr Robbins stepped in as CEO, good newws and some not so much.

Advice to Senior Management
take care of your people, manage your boss, and get the results!

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, November 20, 2015 1:59 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Content Manager/Writer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Content Manager/Writer"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Fri, 20 Nov 2015

Pros
Exciting company, you work for one of the best companies, strong market presence makes it fun to create content as great customers and business outcomes to include. Lot of flexibility, I work from home, love the freedom but I'm very productive. People you work with are very sharp and the best in the industry. Cisco is not a tech-first company as much as it was originally, very market focused.

Cons
Biggest downside is the unpredictability of having a job. I've been through a few layoffs, and recently got back into Cisco as a full-time contractor. They seem to like this arrangement so they don't have to pay all the benefits. But I find this aspect of it, plus the frequent layoffs, very disheartening. I keep waiting for the company to stabilize. Maybe with Chuck Robbins, the new CEO, it will.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, November 18, 2015 1:57 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly says "Early-in-College Summer Internship"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly says "Early-in-College Summer Internship"

From Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Wed, 18 Nov 2015

Pros
Cisco had a great collaborative culture. Every person I met was extremely helpful and wanted me to succeed. While all internships are at least partially geared towards the intern contributing something to the company, I found that at Cisco it was more geared towards making you want to work at Cisco. Instead of pushing me to my breaking point, this internship program made the summer an enjoyable one! The internship gave me the chance to shadow current employees and see what working at Cisco would actually be like, while having fun with coworkers and experiencing the company culture. There is also substantial freedom to move around in the company. Although I was interning in Sales, my boss encouraged me to shadow a coworker in finance, as I had voiced interest in that in the past. Cisco wants its workers to be happy with their job within Cisco, even if it means switching departments.

Cons
The company tends to be a little older than many tech companies today. Although this internship program is one of the ways they are trying to change that, it does make the culture a bit different from other tech companies.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8684854.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8684854.htm>

Cons

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, November 17, 2015 9:42 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems MARKETING PROGRAM MANAGER says "Marketing Program Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems MARKETING PROGRAM MANAGER says "Marketing Program Manager"

From Cisco Systems MARKETING PROGRAM MANAGER (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 17 Nov 2015

Pros
Innovative, flexible, can be fun and collaborative, quality people, high standards, cutting edge technology. Opportunity to learn processes valuable for a resume. If you keep in mind you are a contractor, and will be moving on, it is easier to weather the uncertainty of the department and org. As a full time person, benefits are incredible!

Cons
It appeared to me that often politics instead of work ethic gets you promoted; the good ole boy network lives. Often reorgs leave folks in a quandary with no direction for months, contractors can be left out of knowledge loop due to status with no leadership. There seems to be a clear divide between the 'worker bees' and management. Often full time new hire interns did not do much work. Reorgs every 2 years and that is challenging and demotivating without leadership.

Advice to Senior Management
What if management executed their vision and the reorg all at the same time without leaving people and departments hanging without a clue of direction for months on end? I loved my job, but when reorg came, working was depressing for months before many of us left. I'm hopeful that Chuck can get a grip on the situation.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8669051.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8669051.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, November 16, 2015 5:47 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader says "Technical Leader"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader says "Technical Leader"

From Cisco Systems Technical Leader (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 16 Nov 2015

Pros
Work on some great technologies that truly are reshaping how people work and play.

Cons
Management and processes are not aligned with company objectives. Executives tell you to focus on quality. But, middle management tells you to focus on arbitrary dates and timelines. End result: fighting customer fires over and over again as quality does not match promises or expectation.s

Advice to Senior Management
Cut it out with the "Limited Restructuring". When employees keep fearing for their jobs, regardless of their performance, they spend too much time focusing on the wrong things. Don't expect loyalty from your employees if you can't be mutual.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, November 14, 2015 3:36 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Automation Specialist says "Better move on..."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Automation Specialist says "Better move on..."

From Cisco Systems Marketing Automation Specialist (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sat, 14 Nov 2015

Pros
Not much really, perhaps to mention everything I recall, only highlight the chance of working from home and getting some sort of gold plated resume by typing Cisco's name on it... that's it. Nothing else.

Cons
No career path at all. If you ever have the chance to get to work at cisco, do it and get the most out of it as long as it lasts. But as soon as you can, you better go to any other place since there's no chance for promotion nor being valued as an employee. Only cheerleaders get upgrades, the harder they perform on their toadying the better they get promoted. The place is overloaded with slacker sponges, specially in middle management, soaking up knowledge from interns, contractors and new-hires so they can work on their upgrades (being the only task you can name when describing many of the people inside). I even had the chance to talk to a senior manager once and he told me that in order to improve my visibility, I needed to do nothing worth anything for the company but needed to pretend to be 'always busy and always lovely', which made some sense some time later, when a lady managing the team I was in told us there is no need to give your best on your daily job, you only need to show your *shiny eyes* -- and even threatened those who didn't follow her teachings with downgrades or being thrown out the hen house. Basically if you want to become somebody at cisco, understand this place values no work, and working is something frowned upon: you will have a career path if you behave like a clown, capable enough to tamper sales figures. Otherwise, if you try to perform like a pro, they will isolate you until you are bored stiff and play along until you get lr'ed. My advise: better skip Cisco.

Advice to Senior Management
Grab your bucks now and run as if there's no tomorrow... the whole place is a bluff. A real time-bomb you might want to be far away from it, few months from now.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8644382.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8644382.htm>

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Sales says "Great Company"

From Cisco Systems Sales (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 13 Nov 2015

Pros
You are surrounded by intelligent people and you are in a vibrant place for innovation and technology. Great culture and benefits.

Cons
Lack of focus on developing people, difficult to grow internally given the size of the organisation. In certain areas politics are more important than good work.

Advice to Senior Management
Train managers to be coaches and to build team spirit. Invest in young talents as well.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, November 13, 2015 4:20 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Director says "Director"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Director says "Director"

From Cisco Systems Director (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 13 Nov 2015

Pros
Cisco has very high quality senior management. High ethics and Fair play. Overall the Customer first culture helps Cisco win in the market place. It is an Open work environment, with lot of flexibility at work eg. Work from home. No one looking over your shoulder. Generally a mature culture at work. Very employee friendly policies. and a winning culture.

Cons
Cisco like any large Global is an ocean with slack. People at middle ranks are beginning to loose their way. There is too much room for one to be a Cog, and too many overlay roles and functions.

Advice to Senior Management
Embrace more Command & Control. When you see slack, stop it

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8631610.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8631610.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, November 12, 2015 1:03 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good company to learn, but promotions are scarce."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good company to learn, but promotions are scarce."

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Thu, 12 Nov 2015

Pros
Cisco is a great place to learn, rack certifications, and grow both technical, soft, and business skills. And then move on, vertically or sideways.

Cons
It's a bureaucracy, with petty office politics. It's easy to get buried under work there. You won't get a promotion unless you know the right people, and are on the right projects (advancement is earned more from visibility rather than merit.)

Advice to Senior Management
Recognize and promote people on merit, not on back-stabbing internal politics which you call visibility.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8625276.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8625276.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, November 12, 2015 6:59 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good place to work"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good place to work"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Thu, 12 Nov 2015

Pros
Strong technology leaders Get to work on latest and greatest in networking Huge breadth of talent and experience and active projects locally Opportunities to move internally Plenty of customer engagement

Cons
Some antiquated processes Some antiquated tools Projects are not globally filtered and ordered so determining which project to work on and when can be chaotic. Lack of a deep support team means many customer issues make it back to the designers - this could be a Pro but not usually

Advice to Senior Management
Keep the environment agile and adapting to new tools, and methods Keep employees motivated by clearing away the overhead of getting designs and code completed.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, November 11, 2015 9:00 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems CSE says "Good Giant Social-Loafing kind of place"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems CSE says "Good Giant Social-Loafing kind of place"

From Cisco Systems CSE (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 11 Nov 2015

Pros
A very storied and rich silicon valley company. To me, its all about your team and you manager. If you can have good folks in both regards - its an awesome place. Cutting edge on technology. Well respected. The leader. Good pedigree. Some opportunities to make money.

Cons
Too big. Should be three different companies (UC/Security/Enterprise Networking). Middle management still needs to be cleaned up - lots of ash and trash. Last manager was more in to managing up versus looking out for me or my teammates. Lots of lip service to careers and the ability to do different jobs. Managers usually earn their job by interviewing well and lining up connections to promote their advancement. Manager purposely did not support my efforts to earn CCIE.

Advice to Senior Management
Clean up management ranks.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, November 11, 2015 11:46 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great place to work if you manage your career and network"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great place to work if you manage your career and network"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 11 Nov 2015

Pros
There's a lot of opportunities at this enormous global company with fantastic benefits - but no one is going to hand hold you to develop your career. It's really easy to get paid well, work 9-5 and be at Cisco for a decade, if you want a mommy-track or low key job. If you want to learn, be challenged, move up fast, learn the org landscape, find the right sponsors and there are lots of interesting learning experiences to be had.

Cons
Political, big and slow in many parts of the org. Back channel negotiation and side discussions are required to smoothly get stuff done, and not doing so has career ramifications. That said, if you understand the landscape, you can do well. Had great experiences and career development, but ultimately I left because I wanted more direct impact than what I could see as a cog in the massive machine that is Cisco. That said, it was worth the tour of duty

Advice to Senior Management
Identify your high potentials below the Grade 13 cut off, you're losing the young ones with energy to faster, cooler places in droves!

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8612619.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8612619.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, November 11, 2015 12:44 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Support Engineer says "CSTG support team one of the worst places to work for"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Support Engineer says "CSTG support team one of the worst places to work for"

From Cisco Systems Technical Support Engineer (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — Wed, 11 Nov 2015

Pros
there are no positives to be mentioned

Cons
One of the worst ever teams to be a part of, I cant speak for the whole company, but whatever i have heard from several teams points in a very negative direction, the management has a very nasty habit of culling its head count annually, you walk around assuming the worst about your job and then there is the constant nagging fear in the back of your head saying "will they fire me this time?" . But lets stick to CSTG support team more specifically the cspc support team, them management is extremely poor, there is absolutely no work life balance, there was one instance when the manager actually called me to ask where i was when i was working from home sick, there is an overwhelming atmosphere of micro management, where threats of firing is hurled in your direction(not directly of course but its always implied).....but lets assume for a second that all companies have this problem and I am just a disgruntled old employee.......The team that consists mostly of linux administrators are extremely extremely extremely poor technically, they have a feeling that no company will hire them owing to there poor skills and they are absolutely right ..nobody will hire them..... but this is not their fault the company overburdens them with the same monotonous work every single day which sometimes takes more than 10 hours to complete(which literally kills their personal life) ... they are not allowed to learn anything new, because they dont know what to learn(they are sorrounded by self acclaimed technical leads who are actually idiots with no technical skills and are incapable of teaching or advising the other engineers about any new technologies),obviously if you spend enough time around an idiot you end up being one. This company is not preparing you for the future, it is lead by a management team that is stuck in the past and will only lead you in the direction that will eventually destroy your career and leave you unsatisfied and unhappy.

Advice to Senior Management
i cannot give you any advise because of your incapability to take it....i know eventually you will only sink yourself, i only hope to god you don't take the Engineers who might actually have a future down with you....

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, November 10, 2015 2:18 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Software Engineer 3"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Software Engineer 3"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 10 Nov 2015

Pros
Average government salaries are competitive with the private and nonprofit sectors. Pay can also increase fairly quickly for top candidates with strong education and experience. Federal benefits, including health insurance, retirement and vacation, are extremely competitive with, if not superior to, other sectors.

Cons
Where do you want to work and live? Whatever the answer, chances are you can find federal government work there. Most people think that federal government jobs are all in Washington, D.C., but in fact 84 percent of federal government jobs are outside of the D.C. area. More than 50,000 federal government employees work abroad.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "My review"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "My review"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 9 Nov 2015

Pros
Big company. Some people only need to work 2-3 hours per day.

Cons
Some real engineer need to work fully 8-9 hours per day.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, November 08, 2015 6:34 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "View from a current employee"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "View from a current employee"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sun, 8 Nov 2015

Pros
Can work from home. Management leaves you to do your job for the most part. There is a strict unwritten rule not to lose it (aka, yelling at employees, writing rude emails and etc...) no matter how hot the subject . It will not happen right away but, they will isolate and layoff those people. A very good culture requirement.

Cons
On call 24/7. Things that are normal for a big company aka watching management change direction randomly, people sending pointless emails to the entire company. You just ignore requirements and endless demands take mandatory training. At the end of the day they realize that you are very valuable in the customer's eyes and that is all that matters.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8581387.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, November 04, 2015 8:41 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Nothing But Politics"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Nothing But Politics"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Wed, 4 Nov 2015

Pros
Good overall benefits, flexible work from home policy (a necessity given one of the cons below), a great name for your resume

Cons
Feels like an old company trying unsuccessfully to change to a younger feel. Lots of politics, especially around headcount, which leads to continuous employee moves making it hard to move up. Constant change that leads to yearly layoffs. Limited visibility from management on the changes and moves that makes it difficult to effectively do your job. Open office space with no assigned space makes going into the office almost pointless and unproductive, since there's not enough rooms for you to make the calls you'll be on all day. Pay inequality, in certain situations, that's impossible to get fixed without leaving and coming back.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8535227.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, November 04, 2015 6:05 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Intern says "Worldwide Sales Internship"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Intern says "Worldwide Sales Internship"

From Cisco Systems Intern (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Wed, 4 Nov 2015

Pros
This was one of the best internships I have ever had. I have had experiences in several other sectors and internships and this was, hands down, the best summer job I have ever had. The work we did was nothing like any other internship. We did meaningful research, presentations, and strategic planning. Cisco taught us how to be effective doing consultative tech research and planning. I learned an incredible amount about business, networking, and strategy. On top of that we had a great amount of exposure to the senior management of the company. The CEO himself spoke to our class, and a lot of the senior staff opened up to questions and provided advice on how we could be successful in careers. Cisco really hooked it up. We had great out of office - sponsored - bonding activities that was a great for getting to know our coworkers. They also paid for our housing! We were able to live in one of the best apartments in Boston - at no cost! Cisco really put together an unbelievable summer experience. I learned a ton, did great work, met some unbelievable people, lived in a palace, and had it all sponsored by Cisco. This was it. I highly recommend this internship. Also - this is a feeder program into one of the best jobs in the industry, and they want to hire you, so ... it is a great way to get your career going early on. And if you choose to go somewhere else, Cisco has a powerful name that will help you anywhere.

Cons
I was turned off by the internships name of "Sales" - I was a computer engineer in college and never thought I would go into sales. This is really not a sales role - there is not cold calling. This is business consulting and account management with a focus on technology. So I think the name, with sales in it, should be changed.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep doing whatever you are doing. They were constantly looking to improve and make the internship better. They reached out to great kids and put together a great program.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8533353.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8533353.htm>

From Cisco Systems Sales (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 4 Nov 2015

Pros

Good opportunity to travel with job. Most people been their long time over four years so culture is a place where people happy with working for Cisco

Cons

Advice to Senior Management

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, November 03, 2015 2:20 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Well Paid Mediocrity"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Well Paid Mediocrity"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 3 Nov 2015

Pros
Excellent Benefits, Reasonable access to in-house technology, reasonable Work-Life balance

Cons
Company is caught in the IT technology vortex, attached to the wrong end of the customer. Innovation is through acquisition only at this point, technology and understanding take a distant third to sales, and business process.

Advice to Senior Management
Consolidate now. Split off the software business to sink or swim on its own. Don't wait for Wall Street to extract its pound of flesh. Flush the lines and instigate a more innovation driven - less sales centric culture.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, November 03, 2015 12:05 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Associate Systems Engineer says "Associate Systems Engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Associate Systems Engineer says "Associate Systems Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Associate Systems Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 3 Nov 2015

Pros
First and foremost: the people! The amount of training and support is phenomenal. Going into the CSAP program I had high expectations. 3 months in, every single one of them was exceeded: some of the best instructors, IT tech courses that are geared toward the practical and relevant for the job, lab always open for "getting the hands dirty", sales training made fun. Did I mention the people? Everyone form my CSAP co-workers to experienced systems engineers to management (at all levels) is really supportive and approachable. Also, I had the chance to interact with people outside of my local office and they did not seem far at all. The pay is great, there is relocation support, I am happy with the insurance provided.

Cons
The training program is very engaging and intense. If not careful, maintaining a work-life balance becomes a struggle.

Advice to Senior Management
From my experience so far, feedback is valued and taken into account so: keep doing what you are doing.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8524636.htm>

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Sales Field Intern says "Inside Sales Internship"

From Cisco Systems Sales Field Intern (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 3 Nov 2015

Pros
AMAZING culture - had heard about this in the internship interviews but really saw it come to life, everyone here is excited to be here which was not the case at other large IT companies I looked at Right Direction - Cisco is extremely well positioned in the market while the industry is going through massive consolidation (i.e., Dell/EMC) Incredible Benefits - Great pay, onsite fitness and health center with wide variety of doctors, birthday's off, solid PTO, stock options, etc.

Cons
There is a lot to learn on the tech side as a sales rep as Cisco is in almost every market, but it does become manageable after a couple months.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep investing in security and software, great job with 'The People Deal!'

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, November 02, 2015 7:07 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Account Manager says "Account Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Account Manager says "Account Manager"

From Cisco Systems Senior Account Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Mon, 2 Nov 2015

Pros
Salary, sales commission program + benefits. Brand and name has an excellent reputation, great talent working for the company worldwide. Opportunities to grow for ambitious people.

Cons
Staff moves around a lot, very political inside large companies. Lots of internal selling to make with different levels of people to move things forward. Too slow at launching new products or technologies, smoke and mirror syndrome is hurting the sales team credibility (finance and legal weigh more than marketing and sales). Lay offs are inevitable (almost each year) - highly competitive culture among staff due to this pressure.

Advice to Senior Management
Less bureaucratie to move things faster (from product development to approval of deals). Walk the talk with involvement, communication and empowerment of your sales teams.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8507684.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8507684.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, November 02, 2015 4:40 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II says "Don't join CISCO"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II says "Don't join CISCO"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer II (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Mon, 2 Nov 2015

Pros
Still finding the pros from past 2.5 years

Cons
At the time of offer letter, HR told that the work type will be Development but its totally Sustenance(Bug Fixing). Cisco is not doing good it doesn't have enough money to give hikes to their at least 80% of their employee. Even many of the employees are in CISCO Bangalore who doesn't get the hike for past 2.5 years. If employee asked their managers or higher management they try to scare it by saying that they will fire you and put the bad remarks in your relieving letter. As every year, there is a culture in Cisco to fire the employees. So manager take benefits of it and as there are few networking companies so they are always try to harassing the employees. If anyone joined, managers directly told them that you will not get the hike even if you performed well because you switched the company so you get good amount of hike in comparison to the previous employer. Dirty politics in Cisco. No career growth.

Advice to Senior Management
Higher management is worst. Many of the employees don't know who are the HR for their Business Unit.

Pros
Cisco has very competitive pay and a strong brand. I have (mostly) high-quality co-workers. Senior management (on my team anyway) does not micro-manage, employees are empowered.

Cons
Cisco is a very large company and you can sometimes feel lost in the fray. Communication and cooperation between different business units could certainly be better.

Advice to Senior Management

From Cisco Systems Systems Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 30 Oct 2015

Pros
Cisco is fast paced environment and a fantastic talent pool and will only enhance your career and CV. You have a freedom to shape your role as long as it yields results expected. A very personal company and will go out of their way to help you with both work and non-work related issues.

Cons
There are many employees in Cisco you need to do more than your day job to get recognised and promoted.

Advice to Senior Management

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Thu, 29 Oct 2015

Pros
Most people you'll work with are impressive, professional, and approachable. The company is so large that it's easy to move around - as long as you know someone. Having the flexibility to work from home when needed is terrific.

Cons

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, October 28, 2015 2:06 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "System Administrator"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "System Administrator"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 28 Oct 2015

Pros
Great environment, beautiful campus, friendly people, huge cubicle space, smooth and easy communication via Jabber and WebEx, not too stressful, up-to date tools/software that makes work so much easier. There is at least one huge event every year (Cisco Rocks!) and many fun social gatherings biweekly near the site I worked at (site 5).

Cons
Slow paced work in the sense that you can't get your work done until someone is finished with their work. On a daily basis, I am mostly waiting 2-3 hours for someone to finish their work so I can work on my part of the project. It was great at first, but after a while I found it rather annoying and I didn't find myself as productive as I wanted to be.

Advice to Senior Management
Went in for a performance review and my manager tells me great and I pretty much told me I should gauge myself. What kind of performance review is that?! How am I supposed to determine how well I am doing in terms of performance if I don't get any productive feedback?

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8464417.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8464417.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, October 28, 2015 12:52 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Lots of Pluses, Lots of Minuses"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Lots of Pluses, Lots of Minuses"

From Cisco Systems Marketing Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Wed, 28 Oct 2015

Pros
I was at Cisco for four and a half years and left a couple of months ago. Here's my perspective: - Great company to have on your resume. - They offer fantastic work-life balance and flexible work options. I worked from home almost the entire time I was there and loved it. They provide the tools you need to work from anywhere. - Excellent benefits; employee health insurance premiums are really low. - They employ some incredibly smart people, and I believe that the new CEO is going to do great things. - It's a fantastic company for engineers; they are the star employees.

Cons
- They have a difficult history of annual layoffs, and the dust is still settling with the new CEO in place and the changes he's making to the organization. - Cisco is not generous with merit increases and promotions are difficult to come by. - Cisco is a behemoth of a company. As such, processes for getting anything done are complex and slow. - Don't expect a lot of handholding as you start your job. Cisco prides itself on being a "self service" company. That means you have to figure out how to get things done.

Advice to Senior Management
Live up to the promises you've made about doing away with stack-ranking employees; don't overlook the "workhorses" in favor of the people who always seem to get the plum, high visibility assignments. There is a lot of great work being done, most of which never gets recognized.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8463381.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8463381.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, October 28, 2015 9:52 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good Company, Great benefits"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Good Company, Great benefits"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 28 Oct 2015

Pros
Great benefits, good work. The company is a market leader in its line of business. The networking industry is under pressure due to SDN and white box. Cisco is trying to keep up with the new technologies. So there is a lot of good work and learning opportunities.

Cons
Due to the race to build new technologies there is a lot of work that needs to be done in short time. Consequently work life balance is impacted.

Advice to Senior Management
Be cognizant of the life of employees outside of work and plan projects and work accordingly especially for employees with family and children.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, October 27, 2015 8:22 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Needs to be more agile."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Needs to be more agile."

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 27 Oct 2015

Pros
Lots of money and lots of bodies thrown at difficult problems. Some reasonably forward thinking from senior management. Their product is still their main benefit. Good reputation for the devices and stable operation make for a great product.

Cons
Too much money hides a multitude of middle manager sins and contractors providing no benefit and getting in the way of technical projects. Too many good "red badges" are not motivated to stay with the company by being hired full time. There seems to be some selectivity in the hiring of the IT teams that doesn't seem aligned to competence and as such, the IT support outside of mainline tools is ... challenging.

Advice to Senior Management
Review the performance against some KPI for contract staff.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, October 26, 2015 10:39 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager says "Contracting for 10 years"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager says "Contracting for 10 years"

From Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 26 Oct 2015

Pros
Like any job, if you can find a good manager and a good team to work on, you will like your work. Being a contractor provides the advantage that you should be able to not buy into political positioning since you are not an employee and don't have reviews that affect your salary and promotions. Of course, diplomacy is always a key. Hopefully, the changes that the new CEO is making will elevate the company back to the industry status that it had during the boom.

Cons
As at any company, employees are sometimes promoted to management positions who should really remain as individual contributors or who should have more management training in order to make the transition. Otherwise, micromanagement becomes an issue for people like contractors who work autonomously. Employees can spend more time projecting their jobs than focusing on completing their work. Yet, that is why contractors get hired - to get the work done.

Advice to Senior Management
Ensure that only qualified individual are promoted or that they are trained appropriately. Don't promote to just get employees who are barriers out of the way of progress.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8433708.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8433708.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, October 26, 2015 9:39 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Too Many Layoffs and Politics"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Too Many Layoffs and Politics"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Mon, 26 Oct 2015

Pros
Pay, Bonuses, 401K matching, ESPP, medical, dental, vision, tuition reimbursement, internal training programs.

Cons
Constant layoffs and in fighting between departments. It's not what you know, it's who you know to survive and move up.

Advice to Senior Management
Focus on taking care of your good employees and not just your shareholders. Practice what you preach including being transparent. Take the improvement areas from the customer surveys and act upon them in a timely manner.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, October 26, 2015 3:01 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software QA Engineer says "Work Life Balance"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software QA Engineer says "Work Life Balance"

From Cisco Systems Software QA Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Mon, 26 Oct 2015

Pros
Good for work life balance. I never had too much work. * to 4 job, sometimes had to attend interviews at night. Awesome campus. AC innova cabs for transport. Loads of events to win goodies. Training sessions at company's cost.

Cons
Everything is in manager's hand. If you are in good terms with manager, you get good work, otherwise end up with junk work always. Very tough to get promotions. Salary hike is almost never. If you are joining, negotiate a very good package, joining bonus etc while joining itself. If you take sabbatical leave, you need to find a team on your own and need to go through 6+ rounds of tough interview again, though you are still an employee.

Advice to Senior Management
Use employees skills properly, everyone might not perform every time. Give a chance to prove the capabilities.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8429371.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8429371.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, October 26, 2015 2:48 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems IT Analyst says "Pretty on the outside, not so much on the inside"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems IT Analyst says "Pretty on the outside, not so much on the inside"

From Cisco Systems IT Analyst (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Mon, 26 Oct 2015

Pros
Great cultural diversity, company perks in terms of dental cover and stock plans, etc.

Cons
Cisco is still built on the 'progression is based on time served, not merit' model, where the longer you've been here, the more you'll get. For young people starting out, out-performing their colleagues, not the greatest motivation to have. Also, for new fields, it's harder to define your career. Avoid if you're young.

Advice to Senior Management
Realise the market is changing, and if you're really for talent retention/management - then change your age old performance management system.

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Sun, 25 Oct 2015

Pros
the working environment is good and people are nice

Cons

Pros

Cons

Multitasking is an understatement and long days are the norm. Although I enjoy this type of environment, it is demanding and should be considered - else your team suffer's!

Advice to Senior Management
I am encouraged by the follow through with the goals Cisco has in place. Keep that spirit going!

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, October 24, 2015 8:09 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "Toxic Environment - Worst Place to Work"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "Toxic Environment - Worst Place to Work"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sat, 24 Oct 2015

Pros
Good Health Insurance, Dental, Vision Benefits. HSA Health Plan is very good Good 401k Match Onsite Gym is Awesome in San Jose Onsite Doctors and Pharmacy (15% discount) provide most common services Bonus Structure is very good in the Compensation. Many folks get fantastic target bonus % and dollar amount if Cisco performs good in the last quarter. IT Services are Good. Latest version of Thinkpads and MacBook Pros and Latest version of Software used across organization.

Cons
- Engineering Organization is one of the worst in the the industry. You will definitely not get a good job outside of Cisco if you stay for many years. You will forget coding and you will not learn any good practices or gain knowledge outside of Cisco specific technologies. Do not stay here for more than 3-4 years. - Hiring Standards in Engineering is one of the lowest. Most engineers follow bad coding practices and do not have fundamental computer science knowledge. - Outdated Processes and Tools and it takes weeks to commit a simple code change. - Unit Testing Framework is one of the worst in the field. A single line code change needs to be only tested on the real platform and it can take days to build, load image and test it on real device. - Development Test Engineers are one of the worst in the Silicon Valley - They do not understand software and are only focused on filing x number of bugs since their performance is tied to this metric. - Still riding on the innovations done 25 years ago. No Innovation Happening. Many smaller and mid-size companies are innovating and moving fast. Many smart people have already left. - 99% of Engineering Management and Engineers are from only one sub-continent in the world. There is no diversity. - 75% of Technical Leads are Arrogant, Rude and do not do any sort of technical work. They act like managers and talk loudly and don't do real work. They either got there because they act like yes-men to their directors or they were either a close buddy of them in a previous company. - Extreme Politics - Nepotism and Cronyism run rampant. Impossible to get promoted without playing politics and feeding to the ego of their Directors. Promotions are not based on merit or technical work. There is no transparency in Performance Reviews. - Lack of Recognition of Any Kind. Only director's favorites get any RSUs and Awards and everyone else are treated like slaves. - Technical Leads get credit for delivering features even if the don't write a single line of code or contribute anything. - 95% of 1st Line Managers and 2nd Managers should be fired. They are extremely corrupt, inhuman and one of the worst people managers. They are neither technically good nor good people managers. Most people came in to Cisco as Contractors with Fake Resumes and became managers claiming x years of experience. They play politics and favoritism and outright lie to the face of employee. In Summary, if you ever dream of becoming a good software/hardware engineer, do not come here. If you are type of person from a country in Asia where you can stab your peers and stomp on them get ahead, you can survive here very well. Be warned! You cannot get a good job in a Startup or other places even remotely like Google if you stay in Cisco for long. Many employers in Silicon Valley know that Engineers from Cisco do not do any coding and only do the talking like they invented TCP/IP...

Advice to Senior Management
You should be ashamed of yourself to come to work every day. Do not talk about innovation and great culture if you know very well none of that is true. Do not Play Politics and Favoritism. The only way to save Cisco is to uproot the entire 1st and 2nd Line Managers and re-hire from places where they do real engineering

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8419449.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8419449.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, October 24, 2015 1:15 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems IT Director says "Great place to learn, not a place to stay"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems IT Director says "Great place to learn, not a place to stay"

From Cisco Systems IT Director (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sat, 24 Oct 2015

Pros
Worked there for over 10 years. They have a great flexible working schedule in most job roles. Lots of learning opportunities. Global company with a global presence. Great place to start a career right out of college.

Cons
The company values management. Individual contributors who do most of the work are not valued, are given no equity, and promotions are few and far between. They'll tell you there is no money for raises for hard working individual contributor, then a month later several vice presidents will be promoted to senior vice president. This happened over and over when Chambers was CEO. Layoffs are constant (called limited restructurings). In their IT department, where I spent part of my time, they push out anyone who tries to innovate or disrupt. The entire IT organization is run by the same people who've been there since 2000. The broken reward system made it impossible for me to keep my best workers.

Advice to Senior Management
Get rid of the bloated middle management layers. Completely reboot the IT department. Develop compensation programs for individual contributors that actually compete with the rest of silicon valley, because you're going to need those individual contributors in order to compete, much less win.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8417346.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8417346.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, October 24, 2015 10:55 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Team Leader says "Great benefits but work not so exciting for a senior Java developer at Cisco, Bangalore"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Team Leader says "Great benefits but work not so exciting for a senior Java developer at Cisco, Bangalore"

From Cisco Systems Team Leader (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Sat, 24 Oct 2015

Pros
Amazing facility. Employee benefits are excellent. Flexible working hours. Option to work from home.

Cons
Not exciting work for atleast Java. Not a true Agile shop. When tried to escalate issues in project to onsite scrum master, the offshore manager and leads were not happy. Feedbacks are neither encouraged nor considered. Managers come up with inefficient, complicated, very artificial, not so practical or friendly process for team building. They hardly understand that it does not add any value to the member / team / company. Too many incompetent contractors continue because of Manager preferences.

Advice to Senior Management
Managers need to be made practical and sensible when creating or adopting process. Managers need to be trained to accept feedback and introspect. Please train team on Agile and especially Managers.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 22, 2015 5:31 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Constant Layoffs. Company undergoing transformation."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Constant Layoffs. Company undergoing transformation."

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Thu, 22 Oct 2015

Pros
Pays well. Excellent benefits and lots of perks (including local gym). High integrity. Very flexible (work from home at times)

Cons
Constant layoffs. Company is going thru a transformation and several people have been laid off over the last few years. Managers do not work as hard, and keep their jobs. Engineers are usually those that end up being laid off.

Advice to Senior Management
Get more involved in the day-to-day activities of engineering. Management could actually be more proactive in terms of helping engineers relocate to other departments/teams before giving layoff termination to employees.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8400108.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8400108.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, October 21, 2015 4:33 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineering Intern says "Software Engineering Intern @ Cisco"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineering Intern says "Software Engineering Intern @ Cisco"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineering Intern (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 21 Oct 2015

Pros
Great training; Cisco employees are often real domain experts in their fields. The company throws lots of events for interns. Flexible, can work from home. People are friendly. Good place to go for first internship to learn lots about a crucial area (networking), not a great place to go to work on production features and have a big impact.

Cons
Pay per hour is 1/2 of what the top industry players pay! It's also been 6 weeks since my internship ended and they haven't gotten back to anyone in my intern cohort about return offers - HR is overwhelmed. It's an older company, so culture is a little stale/unexcited. Work from home policy makes for an empty/dead office sometimes.

Advice to Senior Management
Upper management seems to have a good handle on market transitions and places to take the company, but their excitement and vision is not getting to ordinary engineers.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8386310.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8386310.htm>

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Service Manager says "Service Manager"

From Cisco Systems Service Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 20 Oct 2015

Pros
Open and eclectic work environment. Not much guidance with work product, but the expectation is for top-flight results. Additionally, it is a very team-team centric environment and peers are always willing to assist. Nice. Last, you can practically interact with anyone and any level. No gatekeepers.

Cons
There is no going home so the hours can be brutal depending on the department in which you work.

Advice to Senior Management
Needs to have more qualitative contact with the grunts on the ground. They have the answers.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, October 18, 2015 9:02 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "Good Company, with a huge user base"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "Good Company, with a huge user base"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sun, 18 Oct 2015

Pros
An excellent company to learn routing, switching and computer networks. Interesting work. Many opportunities to learn and apply technology. Cisco's following in the Networking field is widespread and equal to none, making it a very nice addition to the resume.. -Many opportunities to innovate. Good compensation, Good benefits, A flexible work environment.

Cons
Recently there have been too many senseless changes in direction causing turmoil. Too many layers of middle managers and vice presidents imposing their own personal agendas on the development and engineering groups,

Advice to Senior Management
Keep your eye on the ball. Avoid wasteful reorganisation which might impact design and product support. Sometiimes re-org is necessary (by product or by function) but don't change direction 180 degrees at every turn and back lest it impact product quality and supportability.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8341419.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8341419.htm>

Cons

Continue the good work and sharing the vision. Those were really helpful to the individuals who want to understand how their work contribute and align with those visions and goals.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 15, 2015 5:33 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior IT Program Manager says "A lifetime career in technology"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior IT Program Manager says "A lifetime career in technology"

From Cisco Systems Senior IT Program Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Thu, 15 Oct 2015

Pros
Very easy to move around internally between, engineering, development, IT and other functions. One can build their career and move upwards, there are a lot of resources one can leverage to seek a mentor, network internally and build relationships.

Cons
Too big and too bureacratic, sometimes gives the feeling you are working in government, takes a lot of time to convince and do the right thing. Despite the soundbites, management only likes quick wins and their career focus. As a result people management is often overlooked in place of technology management.

Advice to Senior Management
The pervading view of every employees are responsible for their development needs a lot of support from management and proper guidance.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8316805.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8316805.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 15, 2015 1:09 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "SDE Intern"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "SDE Intern"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Thu, 15 Oct 2015

Pros
The projects you get and how you work on them largely depends on what business unit you end up on and who your manager and mentor are. Some will give you specific tasks and/or ways to do them, others will give you more opened ended objectives and/or leave it up to you how you want to do them. Quite a bit of freedom

Cons
The work culture is somewhat different from that of the other bay area companies. I would say Cisco's workforce is, on average, much older than those of Google, etc. and as a result, it's much more serious and less "fun".

Advice to Senior Management
Not the most challenging projects are given to interns as it depends on the needs of manager and also the duration. So you might not necessarily get what your interested in. But one thing at Cisco is you learn a lot with respect to networks so I enjoyed that

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8313900.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8313900.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 15, 2015 11:46 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Information Technology says "Best place I've worked thus far in life"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Information Technology says "Best place I've worked thus far in life"

From Cisco Systems Information Technology (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Thu, 15 Oct 2015

Pros
Great Benefits and Bonus. People are hard workers and goal setters. Lazy people are not kept around. ESPP is a pretty awesome program. High Ethical Standards. I've worked at jobs where Integrity and ethics were talked about but the company did not act accordingly. Time and time again I am impressed with Cisco's Integrity and Ethics.

Cons
401k matching could be a little higher. Giving it a 4 star rating because the 401k matching is a pretty big deal to me. Since we do not get a pension, then somewhere around 6-8% 100% match would be a lot better. Other then that the Benefits are pretty awesome for me. I cannot speak for those with dependents if the benefits are better or worse then other companies.

Advice to Senior Management
Connected Rewards are an awesome way of giving feedback to employees. Along with Employees giving feedback to each other. I would encourage Management to use it more often and also recommend employees recognizing each other when they go above and beyond what is required. I wish we could use them for Red Badge Employees too. Some Red Badges do a fantastic job and it would be nice to reward them. I would like to see 6-8% 100% 401k match.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8312619.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8312619.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, October 14, 2015 11:49 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Business Analyst says "Not Good for College Hires"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Business Analyst says "Not Good for College Hires"

From Cisco Systems Business Analyst (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 14 Oct 2015

Pros
Large company with the opportunity to experience different aspects of working for a technology company and a Fortune 100 company. Depending on your manager, you can have cool opportunities to take ownership of projects.

Cons
Because the company is transitioning from hardware to services, they have other (arguably greater concerns) then creating a coherent program for college new hires.

Advice to Senior Management
Focus on professional development opportunities for employees and encourage managers to not stand in the way of those who want to enhance their careers.

View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8298024.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, October 14, 2015 11:21 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Director says "New Leadership Has Some Glaring Weaknesses"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Director says "New Leadership Has Some Glaring Weaknesses"

From Cisco Systems Senior Director (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 14 Oct 2015

Pros
Cisco is a solid, steady, if somewhat un-interesting company in terms of growth. It's sheer size and breadth will help it win many market segments. In mid-2015 it began the transition to a new leadership team at the c-level and then downward, as it replaced its CEO for the first time in 20 years and the new CEO plus his new c-level leaders (CIO, CTO, CMO, CDO, etc.) are all refreshing their leadership teams. Cisco has a good strategy and intends to focus on the hot topics du jour (mobile, digital, data / analytics, cloud...).

Cons
Cisco is spread across so many diverse topics that it is difficult to imagine it leading any one of them, let alone all of them. In particular it has some serious deficiencies in the new leadership team. The new CMO is particularly weak and has surrounded herself with second-rate leaders - bets are rampant within the company that she will not last more than 12-18 months in the job. Likewise, the new CDO (digital) has little experience of digital, has never been in such a high-profile and critical role in the past, and while he talks a good game, just a bit of scratching shows that he's mostly talk and no ability to execute. Other areas are stronger, such as COO and CIO. But watch for gaps and weakness in key leadership areas that are certain to delay the company's leadership or ability to execute for about 2 more years.

Advice to Senior Management
Re-think key weak spots in the leadership (c-level) team including CDO and CMO - and if serious about leading in these or other areas, then back it up with more than talk and promises and vision without execution.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8297549.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8297549.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, October 14, 2015 8:20 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly says "ASIG Summer Internship (Knoxville, TN)"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly says "ASIG Summer Internship (Knoxville, TN)"

From Cisco Systems Intern - Hourly (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Wed, 14 Oct 2015

Pros
Really friendly staff. Employees get cubicles, with more social work-spaces available during the day. Management frequently converses with employees. Company makes an effort to keep employees in the loop on where the entire company is headed and what kind of difference the employees are making. Great compensation for an internship.

Cons
Even though this is a security internship, we spent the first half of the summer on a software engineering project. We did do more security related projects towards the end, but it would have been nice to be doing security from the beginning.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep doing what you are doing! My experience in Knoxville was so pleasant that it's hard to recommend any new advice. The communication was strong, the projects were fair, and the overall morale of the interns was very positive.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, October 12, 2015 5:24 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Analyst says "The Darker Side of being a Contractor at Cisco"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Analyst says "The Darker Side of being a Contractor at Cisco"

From Cisco Systems Analyst (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — Mon, 12 Oct 2015

Pros
As a contractor, work totally remote to mitigate the "challenge" of being treated as "invisible" by Cisco full time employees.

Cons
Contract job descriptions that do not match the reality when you start; Inconsistent communication, feedback and direction by Cisco mid-level management; Contract work used by Cisco staff who "make it their own" giving no credit and creating false impressions to upper management.

Advice to Senior Management
Clean up your inconsistent practices (varies by BU) towards contract workers that give you one of the worst reputations in Silicon Valley. Your management does not have to be indifferent, insensitive and show contemptuous disrespect towards talented contract workers. Some day each of you could be in the same position and many contractors would find it hard to share your pain.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8272958.htm>

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "They don't value you if you're over 40."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "They don't value you if you're over 40."

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Mon, 12 Oct 2015

Pros
There used to be plenty of them

Cons
If given a choice between giving you a raise or a promotion, they'd prefer you just leave.

Advice to Senior Management
Get real. There's a tremendous amount of talent out there that's over 40 years old. You aren't twitter, you aren't google, you aren't amazon. You reward devotion, quality work and loyalty with some arbitrary comments about how you're not adding value because you haven't learned a new technology (even though you've been working 50 hours a week) just shows that they've become GE. It's not a mystery why they're no longer near the top of the "Best Places to Work" surveys.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 08, 2015 6:29 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "Account Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "Account Manager"

From Cisco Systems Account Manager (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Thu, 8 Oct 2015

Pros
Great culture and technology. Cisco is a very driven but also caring culture. I loved the time I spent there and it was very hard to leave.

Cons
As an account manager, it is very hard to build a long term business because you have a limited number of accounts and are given a growth goal every year on the same set of accounts. After a couple of years, it becomes impossible to meet the number with the same set of customers. Even though Cisco has a large portfolio of solutions, not all of these drive large sales volume. This comp structure model drives folks to change territories or roles about every 2 years or so which makes it difficult to build long-lasting customer relationships.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8231949.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8231949.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 08, 2015 4:31 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer III says "Great first job, but nasty politics !!"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer III says "Great first job, but nasty politics !!"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer III (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Thu, 8 Oct 2015

Pros
* Lot of new things to learn. * Scale is huge, big customers. * Great courses are offered to keep skill up to date. * Good benefits - Health Insurance, 401K match, PTOs (1 on your birthday). * Few great minds around to leverage the knowledge.

Cons
* Dirty politics, VP changes then he brings all his people and let go great minds. * Lay Offs and Lay Offs, bad hiring policy. * Average Compensation. * Really bad managers who are not technically sound, how can this happen in a product company.

Advice to Senior Management
Cisco is just great and has the name which will last for sure. However please stop the bad hiring policy and dont randomly lay off great people who are the real assets of the company. Please make sure atleast the first level managers are technically sound. Revisit the compensation structure its definitely not on par with others in Bay Area now.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8230787.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8230787.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, October 07, 2015 10:21 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great company, hindered by politics"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great company, hindered by politics"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 7 Oct 2015

Pros
Decent benefits, nice pay, great people to work with

Cons
Politics, and job security. Due to local employment regulations in my country, contractors cannot renew a contract. Hence my manager requested for a regular conversion, and was approved by VP, but the conversion did not fall through. Cisco has NO idea who to hire/keep. A single account that I deployed in Thailand provided our sales team with enough information to upsell an additional 132 million USD in products, and another 2 million USD in services. I deployed many impossible accounts throughout Asia, and significantly improved all metrics and performances across the the region. The new budgeting control guy still had his doubts, and decided to just pick another contractor and train him from the ground up. Great idea.

Advice to Senior Management
You need a better system to evaluate who needs to stay and who doesn't. Also, I'm not sure about other Cisco Services, but your product management for SNTC is not good. Some examples include: major, super obvious bugs in the program "after" release. Improper or non existent training until a long time has passed since a service goes live. No clarity when it comes to issues raised either internally or externally. No sense of ownership, even when our VSEM is to make the end user happy

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8220320.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8220320.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, October 06, 2015 3:30 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineering Intern says "Overall Positive Internship"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineering Intern says "Overall Positive Internship"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineering Intern (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 6 Oct 2015

Pros
Full-time employees are more than happy to help; they seem to appreciate young blood in the office. Very flexible work hours/days; if you have to miss a day or two, managers are very flexible. Company makes an honest effort to socialize you with fellow interns.

Cons
Pay is nothing to write home about, at least for an internship in the Bay Area. Intern events are probably the only significant socializing you'll ever do; most full-timers only come into work and then immediately go home. Projects are typically a very small, minute component in an otherwise enormous system; no "cool factor" and the skills you learn don't seem to be transferable. Projects can also be mind-numbing, such as writing a series of JUnit tests or making several SQL calls to a server.

Advice to Senior Management
There's really nothing a lone manager or set of managers can do to remedy my complaints. While Cisco has pretty great full-time benefits and a very flexible work-life balance, the culture lends itself to employees being isolated and non-social. It's a great company to work for if you have a family, but for young people looking to build relationships with fellow employees, it's sub par.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8201943.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8201943.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, October 03, 2015 9:10 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Technical Program Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Technical Program Manager"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Sat, 3 Oct 2015

Pros
Been around for a long time, not going anywhere soon.

Cons
Too big to fail? This place has a reputation, and well deserved, for hiring contractor/consultants for a year and letting them go for any small reason irrespective of how valuable they are to the program or project. Many regular employees just punching the clock and collecting check but not really adding real value. Lots of management who has "survived" many years simply by being hard nosed, right or wrong. Has evolved into the BIG company that does not change direction well and has a difficult time attracting and keeping top engineering talent. Many people in power dont know much about technology except buzz words. Small wonder losing top software talent to startups doing much more and rewarding employees with actual rewards, not just pat on back.

Advice to Senior Management
find some real intelligent engineering minds to run the operations, not a bunch of people who have simply been around awhile and have never done actual engineering work.
