From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, October 03, 2015 5:19 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "Account Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "Account Manager"

From Cisco Systems Account Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Sat, 3 Oct 2015

Pros
Great, broad product family, TAC and Engineering Support is world class. The company is customer and sales focused, so if you are on an account team, you can do what is needed to build win-win relationships with your client. There are a ton of opportunities to move around and lots of opportunities to innovate. Cisco is moving fast to a flexible, highly mobile work environment. You can get your work done from any place, device or screen that has a connection to the internet.

Cons
Crazy amounts of sales forecasting and opportunity updates (3 TIMES PER WEEK FOR MOST SALES TEAMS!) If you are an account manager, you'll submit your forecast over the weekend, have some sort of large opportunity review at the beginning of the next and then do another forecast at the end of the week. This leads many managers to micro-manage their teams. Salary, as part of overall compensation package is below average. When you overachieve, you do well. If you have a bad quarter or year, your checking account will suffer big time. Company bureaucracy sometimes slows things down.

Advice to Senior Management
Reduce the amount of internally focused behavior and forecasting so account teams can maximize the amount of time they have with their customers. Integrate the forecasting process and make it happen twice a week for the first 2 months of each quarter. Then move to weekly forecasts for the final month of a quarter or year.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8169277.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8169277.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, October 03, 2015 4:59 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager says "It's All Relative"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager says "It's All Relative"

From Cisco Systems Senior Program Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Sat, 3 Oct 2015

Pros
There are a lot of good things to say about working at Cisco, e.g., the benefits are good, there are a lot of good people there, and they encourage their people to give back to their community.

Cons
Cisco terminates thousands of employees every year through "restructuring" events. Rather than retraining and retaining talented employees they often replace them with younger, lower paid new hires. I guess that's the new normal in high tech.

Advice to Senior Management
Rather than terminating good, loyal employees, give them time to find another position within the company, even if means asking them to step down in pay grade.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, October 02, 2015 12:36 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Project Manager says "Superbe entreprise mais à fuir pour les métiers support"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Project Manager says "Superbe entreprise mais à fuir pour les métiers support"

From Cisco Systems Project Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 2 Oct 2015

Pros
J'ai passé de grandes années chez Cisco . Bon salaire, grande flexibilité. Les salariés qui sortent de Cisco sont en général de gros travailleurs, ouverts à l'international, agiles, dynamiques.

Cons
L'ambiance à Paris n'a rien a voir avec d'autres bureaux étrangers. Après trois plans de réduction des effectifs successifs les salariés français sont démotivés, exténués ou au bord du burn-out, notamment pour les fonctions supports presque toutes délocalisées en Pologne. Tous les salariés sont touchés par ces délocalisation (erreurs dans les paies, suivi des salariés...)

Advice to Senior Management
Voyez plus loin que la simple réduction rapide des coûts. La qualité doit rester au coeur des métiers.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8153257.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 01, 2015 4:49 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Bad Management-Too much Ego & Micro Management going around."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Bad Management-Too much Ego & Micro Management going around."

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Thu, 1 Oct 2015

Pros
Cisco has been a fantastic place to get work. Appreciated for innovative ideas and you are giving importance to your role. They treat you as experts in your area which is a big plus point :)

Cons
Sr. Managers/Directors have their own pets in the team. Some people don't deserve to be a Sr. Managers give stress to their team members who work under them. Some team members are allowed to go for training, certification but others are just told a BIG NO or NO budget. WFH is just say an option anymore and team members are forced to come to work or else told that they would loose their space or get into the bad list. Some Managers do micro management. What time we come to work , what time we leave and influence JR. people do report to them regarding this. No growth, everything is stable...no increment, no bonus...

Advice to Senior Management
Please remove these kind of micro managers from Cisco because they are not creating a healthy environment but stress. Every employee deserve to WFH as long as they are delivering and getting their work done. If we are talking about collaborative environment then why are we not giving space to sit with the team.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 01, 2015 10:13 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Software Engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Software Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Thu, 1 Oct 2015

Pros
* Great Technology. * Training opportunities. * Most groups allow flexibility with Working from Home one or two days a week. * Annual Bonus based on company & individual performance.

Cons
* Layoffs (Restructuring) occurs on an annual basis. These restructuring are usually not just for individuals, might be a entire group with the decision made from management so your individual performance is not taken into account. Not a good environment to feel secure in your job. * Large company red tap and politics. * If you do not working at the mother ship location(San Jose) then you're considered a second class citizen.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, October 01, 2015 3:08 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems IT Architect says "Many positives"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems IT Architect says "Many positives"

From Cisco Systems IT Architect (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Thu, 1 Oct 2015

Pros
Great benefits, global team, open to improvement, flexibility, work-life balance, connectivity, win, win, win mindset, customer focus, a vision of making the world a better place - all these things and more contributed to a sense of real pride in being a Cisco employee, regardless of the stock price.

Cons
Departure from employee ownership mindset was a terrible loss and reduced management credibility. Being the apparent source of many Dilbert strips regarding the over-reliance on meetings for every decision led to a great reduction in ability to delivery solutions in a timely, cogent manner.

Advice to Senior Management
Restore employee ownership mindset, reduce decision by committee via perpetual meeting.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 30, 2015 1:53 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Company isn't what it use to be"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Program Manager says "Company isn't what it use to be"

From Cisco Systems Program Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Wed, 30 Sep 2015

Pros
Work from home, interesting technology, great customers.

Cons
Cisco is highly political. There are constant layoffs on a yearly basis. Often times contract workers are much more responsive and harder working than permanent staff, but contract workers go unrecognized and permanent employees receive preferred treatment over contract workers. The balance is not equal. Its also very difficult to get converted from contract to permanent employee.

Advice to Senior Management
Reward contract employees by their majority of their customer sat scores and based on what the majority of their colleagues actual experience is, rather than a 1created political story a few bullies create. This represents very poor company values and corporate culture.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8134804.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8134804.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 30, 2015 1:47 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineering I says "Mediocre Giant Corporation"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineering I says "Mediocre Giant Corporation"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineering I (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 30 Sep 2015

Pros
Flexible, good pay, good benefits. If you are looking to sleep through life then this is a comfortable company.

Cons
No motivation to innovate. Projects were dumped on my team 80% finished and tasked to make it "just work". Not a lot of design of the project itself so many things were less than optimized as well.

Advice to Senior Management
Let your employees innovate new products and steer the direction of development, instead of buying companies and spending years trying to figure out how they make sense as part of yours.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 30, 2015 5:50 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Bad Talent Retention"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Manager says "Bad Talent Retention"

From Cisco Systems Senior Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 30 Sep 2015

Pros
Great place to learn about new technology. People are OK.

Cons
Very top heavy. People above senior director level make more money relative to the hours they put. But for manage level who really do the grunt work, no pay off. Progression is based on how long you have been with the company than your merit. Very political because of the leadership. Good people leave the place leaving it to the mediocre ones rise to the tiop as time goes by.

Advice to Senior Management
Improve the talent retention and promotion culture

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, September 27, 2015 10:09 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Integrated Communications Manager says "Integrated Communications Manager"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Integrated Communications Manager says "Integrated Communications Manager"

From Cisco Systems Integrated Communications Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sun, 27 Sep 2015

Pros
Flexible work environment (though varies significantly with the manager), good benefits. Easy to do minimal work and stay employed for many years.

Cons
Little chance for advancement, many vicious self-promoting middle management who lead with fear. HR is useless of course, and upper mgmt is too stupid to see what's going on. Last many years have gone way over board hiring undergrads who many of which have contributed nothing after 2-3 years. I know a few who are great, but most get by on being cute and perky, while the long term employees are forced to cover. Annual layoffs mostly hit those who do the most work, while middle management stays fat. Reorgs are done on a regular basis just because. If the current structure was so great last year why have yet another reorg? I've been moved 10 times between teams often even my own manager didn't know about it. No one asks if you want to move to that team, or if your skills are what is needed. We're just numbers.

Advice to Senior Management
Don't bother spewing the "we are family" BS, we see right through you. That motto died many years ago. Fix the layers and layers of processes to get even the simplest marketing campaign out the door. The Brand police are devoid of any creativity or innovation. Trust was broken many years ago.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8098060.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8098060.htm>

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "Almost 15 Years"

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "Almost 15 Years"

From Cisco Systems Account Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sun, 27 Sep 2015

Pros
Glad to work from home. I get more done and am more relaxed.

Cons
There is no logic to who gets promoted. Often, it's the least qualified. The good old boys network is clearly at work at Cisco. Very few women are even considered for promotions. There are lots of minority and women groups but I don't see that it's helping.They are all talk and no results.

Advice to Senior Management
Get to know your employees. Know who is contributing. Don't just look at their smooching ability and whether or not, you can relate to them. Consider their results and contribution..

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8091771.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8091771.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, September 26, 2015 7:52 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Old school company falling below the competition"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Old school company falling below the competition"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Sat, 26 Sep 2015

Pros
Pay is on par with large companies. Office location is convenient. Benefits options allow flexibility on what to choose, but overall, you have to pay for everything, gym, childcare, onsite health care, etc.

Cons
Very conservative, old school way to run a company. Very political backstabbing environment. Limited growth potential. Benefits sound good, but in reality are not all that great...rather disappointing in fact. The entirety of free food offered is Coffee, Tea, filtered tap water, and popcorn. Overall, I'm sorry I chose to come to Cisco.

Advice to Senior Management
When your whole org repeatedly tells you that there are morale problems, listen to them and do something about it. Treat your employees with respect, and make it a priority that all employees do so. Look at what your competition is offering, and understand why you're unable to hire talent you are looking for. Figure out why people don't want to work for Cisco, and change it. It's not that hard.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8089561.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8089561.htm>

Cons
Changing culture- there used to be a Cisco family, now became a layoff culture. Weak innovation culture, weak leadership and unclear company vision. Employee quality went down dramatically as managers don't want to hire competitive employeees for their own job security

Advice to Senior Management
Innovation instead of acquisition, and hire best people, go to stanford university instead of Santa Clara university.

Stop being so greedy

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, September 25, 2015 2:52 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Best 13 years of my career....so far! :-)"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Best 13 years of my career....so far! :-)"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2011) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 25 Sep 2015

Pros
My director was an inspirational leader, someone who strongly advocated for his team. Our team was a family, a wonderful - too rare - collaborative family. Strong compensation including great benefits and campus perks.

Cons
I never knew which way the sand would shift underneath me. The company's senior leadership would point the "ship" in one direction and just when I was getting good progress toward the goal...they would change course significantly and I had just lost 6-9 months of work (60+ hour weeks, etc.)

Advice to Senior Management
Make sure you are prepared to follow through on a strategy before you "sell" it to the masses that it will be a critical key to the company's success....only to dismantle it midway into implementation.

Advice to Senior Management
Don't have the mindset of govt. offices..give chance to talent...Don't judge techies by their mouth..Real techies won't brag about much & only half baked techies willl advertise themselves..people with big mouth are given reward..

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 23, 2015 10:06 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Solution Architect says "It used to be a great place.   Now it's ok."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Solution Architect says "It used to be a great place.   Now it's ok."

From Cisco Systems Solution Architect (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 23 Sep 2015

Pros
Flexible hours. You are free to work whatever 70 to 80 hours you prefer each week. The yearly layoff packages are fairly generous. When you finally get laid off (and that is how most people who leave the company do so, you have a good chance to double dip for awhile) You learn alot about corporate politics. You learn how to keep your Director happy and what happens when you get a Director that doesn't like you. You get to say you worked at Cisco and it looks good on a resume.

Cons
Yearly layoffs. NO ONE is ever safe. No one. I have seen top tier, highest rated engineers be cut. I have seen low performers cut. The cuts rarely have anything to do with performance, but are based primarily on how much your Director likes you (or knows you) Cisco has fairly low voluntarily attrition, but very high layoff attrition (the PC term is "limited restructure". Management fails to realize that every LR is a failure of management.

Advice to Senior Management
You are destroying the Cisco culture, by continuing to bring in people from the outside who do not value it, and in some cases resent the Cisco culture.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8058955.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW8058955.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, September 22, 2015 11:59 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Working for the GDC is like working in an IT Sweatshop"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Working for the GDC is like working in an IT Sweatshop"

From Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Tue, 22 Sep 2015

Pros
-The floor is air conditioned. -There's free coffee in the break room. -It gives you the opportunity to move to better departments within Cisco that treat there employees very well.

Cons
-They don't pay for their own certifications anymore, with the exception of the CCIE certifications. -Despite not paying for certifications the GDC still requires that you earn those certifications. -Don't ever expect to get raises or promotions. Cisco just had the best quarter they've had in years and no RTP GDC employees received raises due to budget constraints. -Despite the lack of raises and promotions your manager will expect that you perform like the salary grade above you is supposed to perform. -If you work hard you will be placed in a "queue," which is the GDC's way of retaining experienced employees for as long as they possibly can while they train new hires to replace them.

From Cisco Systems Technical Leader (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 21 Sep 2015

Pros
Great place to work with some great benefits. Work life balance is good. Company being large provides ample opportunities to switch in case one is not happy. Stock has languished for a while but that is had to understand.

Cons

Advice to Senior Management

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, September 21, 2015 11:44 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "bad company"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "bad company"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Mon, 21 Sep 2015

Pros
Only name is big plus some company perks thats it.

Cons
Every year huge layoffs which makes it very unstable while upper management able to continue and secure their jobs which is totally unjust. Useless restructuring all the time which is just moving same teams under one manager to another while keeping same management team which is not going to improve anything. employees buttering their managers got promotions and higher bonuses even if they are not doing anything throughout the year which is culture adopted due to higher presence of people from India where this is pretty common. outsourcing of jobs to India which is on rise as Cisco is cutting jobs from here and hiring folks heavily in Bangalore India which is not a healthy trend and it was tried and failed in some groups in past. Some groups do not even have any USA employee presence and they are totally located in India while dev team is located here which caused latency in progress but since Indian lobby is pretty strong in Cisco they are able to save their jobs easily and rule the company. Moreover folks are laid off from here while people from India are pouring in every day in numbers.

Advice to Senior Management
Please stop these layoffs due to heavy outsourcing of local jobs in India, all these never ending layoffs/reorgs making it more unstable and bad mark on Cisco's employee loyalty. Funny thing is every year management announces record earnings like this year and there are behind the scenes huge layoffs which makes no sense and looks like employee hard work is not appreciated.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 16, 2015 2:59 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Change Management Engineer says "Stagnant"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Change Management Engineer says "Stagnant"

From Cisco Systems Change Management Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Wed, 16 Sep 2015

Pros
-Co-workers are generally good people -Access to large internal wiki with vast amount of information on various technologies

Cons
-Compensation is extremely low and takes far longer (if ever) to get a raise or promotion than suggested during interview. -Management is shielded from floor-level employees and has no idea what kind of impact they have when changing processes -Sales-oriented organization where engineers struggle to meet customer demands that sales team agrees to just to collect commission -No room for promotion within department

Advice to Senior Management
-Pull head out of the sand and listen to the intelligent people you hire that actually care about giving customers a better experience and making processes more efficient -Cultivate a culture within the company that is more about a better work environment, new ideas, mobility within organization, and encourages taking on learning opportunities and attaining certifications -Cultivate a management culture of customer service/customer experience above all else

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 16, 2015 11:05 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Company Proud"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Company Proud"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 16 Sep 2015

Pros
I'm not one to be company proud - I'm more focused on my own area of expertise and doing it great for whomever I work for. However, Cisco is the first company where I'm like, "Wow! I WORK here? Seriously? Cool." It started with the little things, like seeing how the employees all came together around Girls in Tech day. Then, it was my team's global volunteer day. Then, it was watching our new CEO step into big shoes with grace and humility. Then it was seeing women in tech not treated really like "women. in. tech." but more like just people who do awesome things because they're awesome. Here are my pros: - Flexibility. Honest truth, I couldn't work at all without the flexible workplace option. I know everyone wants the cool office environment (as do I) but in my situation it wouldn't be possible. Thank you Cisco for being on the edge of that innovation. - The people. I have never gotten to work with such caring, smart, great people. Yes, there's a bad apple in every bunch, but this team comes together for each other like nothing I've seen before. - The work. Almost everyone I know talks about how their job changes the world. It's not a slogan, it's a reality. - For me personally, it's my manager. Orgs change all the time, but I hope she's always my lead. She says I'm the expert in what I do, so go do it. :)

Cons
Cisco is a big company, and thus has big company problems. They can be tackled, but turning a big ship takes a lot of effort. - There are silos. The left hand should really know what the right hand is doing. With an employee base of 75K, that's hard to do. But Cisco needs to get more in touch with its inner self. - Cisco likes process for process sake. I'm type-A, so I'm all for process. But filling out three forms to get one thing moving? They're working on this, I can tell. - Politics. This is a common problem with big companies. It's the part I hate the most. Stop marking your territory and just get things done.

Advice to Senior Management
- Create synergies (I hate that word) so people can work together, rather than on parallel paths. - Stop the process madness. - Foster an environment where politics aren't what gets things done, but people. - Keep focusing on employees and the People Deal - still aspirational, but a great direction.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7971575.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7971575.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, September 15, 2015 9:38 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Very Ethnocentric Culture"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Very Ethnocentric Culture"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — Tue, 15 Sep 2015

Pros
At least I had some level of day-to-day freedom in my job, but that really depends on the department/management.

Cons
Wow, where do I begin? The company is headquartered in Japan and runs all it's international offices like they do in Japan, without taking into account that there are vast cultural and business differences at each country site. Due to this ethnocentric behavior, it was very difficult to get employees to buy into the "how' and "why" things were being done or not done a certain way. Senior management was essentially all from the Japan office, very bull-headed and two-faced. The US employees, including senior management, knew this, tried to appeal to HQ's better business sense, but more often than not failed to convince them to do things differently. There were really good people that left ACCESS, either willingly or RIF'd, but that's the cost of bad business decisions and poor communication.

Advice to Senior Management
I'd give advice if I thought they cared, but they don't. If anything, they resent being told they are doing anything wrong.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7964931.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7964931.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, September 15, 2015 3:10 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Human Resources Manager says "One week in and loving it!"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Human Resources Manager says "One week in and loving it!"

From Cisco Systems Human Resources Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 15 Sep 2015

Pros
People are passionate about the strategy the new CEO has laid out, including the opportunity to transform the culture to make sure Cisco continues to be a leading technology company. They may not have all the answers on how they will do it, but they are willing to try different approaches and there is a very open, transparent approach being taken to how things will be done in the future to accomplish lofty goals and an inspiring vision.

Cons
Cisco is a large company and sometimes getting easy things done can be overly complex. They also need a better tool that enable teams to collaborate on editing files in real-time to save time managing through file changes when working across large groups.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep up the excellent work, stay on message and hold onto the open, transparent approach. They will help the company continue the transformation!

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, September 15, 2015 12:19 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Director of Engineering says "Going out with a fizzle and not a bang"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Director of Engineering says "Going out with a fizzle and not a bang"

From Cisco Systems Director of Engineering (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 15 Sep 2015

Pros
Reasonably good to work at if you have other responsibilities (like a family). Reasonably diverse (at least as compared to other SV companies), but still a long way to go, particularly with respect to women in senior management, Hispanics and African Americans.

Cons
Offshoring and shrinking like crazy at every opportunity. Terrible hiring practices ensures mediocre talent pool - stunningly poor in some cases. Substitutes "going through the motions" for "getting results" as primary goals - lots of meetings, emails, powerpoints, committees and so on. Hero worship at all levels of the org ensures groupthink prevails (which could be a positive if they had any heroes worth listening too, which they don't).

Advice to Senior Management
Replace the board. Stop holding your breath and hoping the competition will go away. Find some real growth and embrace it rather than digging your heels in like the competitors you once vanquished. This industry will eradicate you and in ten years nobody will remember your name otherwise.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7958506.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7958506.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Finance Manager"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2013) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Tue, 15 Sep 2015

Pros
Good work life balance. Co-workers are highly collaborative. Great opportunities to change roles every 18 to 24 months and work in another part of the company

Cons
No focus on career development. Managers can be out of touch. Not much focus on developing people and bench strength. Decisions take too long and company can be too slow to act.

Advice to Senior Management

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, September 14, 2015 8:49 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great company, in touch with employees, competitive pay"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great company, in touch with employees, competitive pay"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 14 Sep 2015

Pros
- Excellent people to work with. Very fun and friendly atmosphere. There's pretty good "social" perks, like quarterly outings with the team, free donuts and bagels, and even beer on Thursdays. Management even listens to suggestions, and recently starting giving people their birthday off, company-wide! -There's some pretty neat projects to work on. It's always good working with relevant technologies and picking up skills that are valuable even on other projects and at other companies. I'd argue this is one of the most important aspects of a tech job. -Cisco is pretty good about recognizing achievements. If you do a really good job, Cisco will recognize you with some award, almost always accompanied by some cash and a goofy but appreciated certificate or plaque or trophy. -Pretty decent opportunities to move up and get raises. I've only been here a short while, but they do give modest annual raises, and I know people who get promotions every so often.

Cons
-A lot of the tooling is out of the stone age. It's extremely frustrating when you're trying to build the hot new thing, and you're constrained by tools and systems that have been obsolete for over a decade. In some areas we're using the hottest new things (docker, Jenkins, artifactory, VMware, etc.), and in other areas we're using systems from the 90s (CVS, SVN, a homemade bug tracking system, decade-plus old poorly written perl scripts, etc.) -Like any company this size, your experience will largely vary on who your manager is and what project you're on. I've personally had a great experience, but I know a few managers (definitely in the minority, but they do exist) who I would have a terrible time working for.

Advice to Senior Management
-You're doing great on the social aspects - keep up the good work there! -Work on the technical side. Be open to new technology, allocate money to move to it, and don't let stubborn old tech guys block progress when something better comes along.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7950350.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7950350.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, September 14, 2015 11:05 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "Slow moving, but opportunities will be found"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Account Manager says "Slow moving, but opportunities will be found"

From Cisco Systems Account Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 14 Sep 2015

Pros
- Market leading technology, lots of acquisitions too, which make approaching customers with new propositions much easier. - Great team culture around collaboration, and working together as one unit - Work life balance and flexibility to work from home is brilliant and is aided by Cisco's technology. - Company trying to evolve and capture market transitions - Software, IoT, Cloud which makes for an existing future.

Cons
- Pace of change and execution is awfully slow - Despite claims of being a software company, sales team is still heavily product orientated. - Stale middle management have become "stuck in their ways" and lack new innovative ideas to drive real change.

Advice to Senior Management
Invest in graduates, and rotate middle management to ensure fresh ideas and new talents is promoted and recognized.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, September 14, 2015 5:10 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Good, with room for improvement"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Good, with room for improvement"

From Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer (Past Employee - 2011) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 14 Sep 2015

Pros
good exposure into various clients. Flexible work hours, no one cares where you work from as long as you are doing your work to the satisfaction of your managers, field engineers and clients. compensation was good, and so were other benefits. Very employee friendly. certifications and continued learning.

Cons
Some of the teams in India were more back end. Even with client relationships, you would be doing work that the Field engineers were not interested in doing. It was cost effective for you to be doing the work. Not easy to shift teams. If you get stuck in some of the teams from which you wanted to shift, it would take a long time. There is no internal mechanism to rotate or provide opportunity for people to explore other roles within the company.

Advice to Senior Management
Provide opportunity to rotate employees. Create a platform where roles within the company are actively advertised and internal candidates can apply and shift roles.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7939100.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7939100.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, September 12, 2015 10:39 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Contractor says "Committed to Diversity"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Contractor says "Committed to Diversity"

From Cisco Systems Contractor (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sat, 12 Sep 2015

Pros
I liked the diversity of employees hired as contractors. Working conditions include flexible hours and lots of challenging opportunities.

Cons
If one is looking for permanent employment, contracting is not a stepping stone to that. Contractors do not get benefits so it can be uncomfortable to work very hard for permanent staff who have paid vacations; many contractors because they are not paid for holidays or mandatory vacation days make a lot less than their stated annual "salaries".

Advice to Senior Management
Keep up the diversity of employees, both permanent and temporary. Treat the janitorial folks well and don't neglect cleaning facilities frequently enough just to save some money.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, September 12, 2015 5:44 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader I says "cisco india"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader I says "cisco india"

From Cisco Systems Technical Leader I (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sat, 12 Sep 2015

Pros
Culture of innovation, early adoption, several groups/technologies to pick, flexible management which is employee friendly most times, good reward system (works well most times but has some flaws as well)

Cons
Management relies heavily on managers feedback. There are instances when good employees suffer due to poor managers. And stress on innovation seems artificial many times leading to several employees pretending to be innovating by trying to file patents on someone else's ideas or simple ideas ..

Advice to Senior Management
Engineers must have more autonomy and managers hold on engineer should be reduced. Undue stress on innovation will not yield results. Create environments that are conducive for innovation and growth and leave the rest to people...

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, September 11, 2015 7:44 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "It was better"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV says "It was better"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer IV (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Fri, 11 Sep 2015

Pros
Cisco is the Industry leader, and you get exposed to all the technologies needed.

Cons
The company is too big and each team is more concerned about short term budget and goals, rather than planning for the long run. The idea of "getting fresh blood" and "restructuring" that pushed the experienced ones out (either voluntarily and involuntarily) is a big loss to Cisco's investment. While there is a need to adjust to ever-changing industry need, the negative spiral and the huge loss of intellectual assets, which were really invaluable and hard to replace. I personally had to witness a good number of colleagues go in last couple of years leaving. They were all smart and important to the team. Letting them go were really wrong decisions.

Advice to Senior Management
Employees are not commodities. Domain expertise can not be easily swapped out, especially in networking software. Management team need to work harder to treasure the real assets... the engineers.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7913229.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7913229.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, September 10, 2015 6:26 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Business Development"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Business Development"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Thu, 10 Sep 2015

Pros
Great people, solid well known brand and flexible working conditions. Cisco employees receive numerous benefits including but not limited to health insurance, gym membership, finance & decent salary + bonuses.

Cons
Cisco enables it's workforce to work from home and remotely, as a result you are expected to be available outside of b/hrs and working collaboratively with counterparts located in other countries achieving global reach and collaboration.

Advice to Senior Management
Introduce new hire training for contractors. This will improve on-boarding employees and reduce time-to-market. Reducing complexity and improving the overall employee experience.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7908085.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, September 10, 2015 10:41 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II Intern says "Work Environment"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II Intern says "Work Environment"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer II Intern (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Thu, 10 Sep 2015

Pros
Lot of intern activities. Manager, mentor and other team members were very supportive, encouraging and more than happy to explain technologies, when available. If you're lucky you can get really good work wherein you know exactly what and why you are doing what you're doing. You get the whole picture of the project

Cons
Less base pay, expensive corporate housing - so I decided to arrange for my own accommodation.

Advice to Senior Management
They should provide free/subsidized corporate housing because bay area is super expensive.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, September 10, 2015 10:01 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Opportunities available for quick movers but strategy is often unclear"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer says "Opportunities available for quick movers but strategy is often unclear"

From Cisco Systems Network Consulting Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Thu, 10 Sep 2015

Pros
Cisco is dynamic and large, it's easy, for those with the right skills, to switch or change roles between departments and groups. Large and exciting projects are available in Advanced Services for willing engineers. Easy access to tools and software as well as cutting edge technologies and global clients.

Cons
Work is often cyclic with dead periods and then manic phases. Strategy from the VP/SVP and CX levels are often not disseminated to the delivery and team level. Often disjointed information is provided.

Advice to Senior Management
Clear up strategy, align with local and delivery teams.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7901867.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7901867.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 09, 2015 9:50 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great place"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great place"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 9 Sep 2015

Pros
Great place to work at. Interesting technology. Able to work on a product well-accepted by the public, and actually engage with the users.

Cons
Culture varies wildly by BU. A number of BUs (like most companies) have lifetime riders in positions working on products they don't care about. Politics are typical.

Advice to Senior Management
Get rid of the politics between BUs. Minimize committee decisions. Reach out to ICs and learn what the problems are. Adjust.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7896148.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7896148.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 09, 2015 5:21 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Finance Intern says "Finance Internship"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Finance Intern says "Finance Internship"

From Cisco Systems Finance Intern (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 9 Sep 2015

Pros
-The people -Since Cisco is a big company, you get to meet a lot of different people. During the internship we were placed in groups and worked in various different functions for a group project, on top of our more concrete job roles in Finance. It was great being able to work with and get to know other areas of the company such as Marketing, HR, along with upper level management at Cisco. The internship was a great experience.

Cons
If you aren't from the area pray you have connections or can get connections to find housing in the Area. 3k signing bonus came out to $1600, a lot of people not from the area barely break even with the wage.$22 an hour in Silicon Valley is hard to get by on, that is, if you are coming from out of state and don't have your parents fund to tap into. -There wasn't that much diversity in terms of the schools represented.

Advice to Senior Management
-higher bonus could help get more people to try Cisco -More details on events for interns and make them mandatory -Keep up the good work!

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7893523.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7893523.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Customer Support Engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Customer Support Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 9 Sep 2015

Pros
Better company to work for in Research Triangle Park. Diverse teams spread globally. Good pay and bonus. Some groups pay incentives based on performance and deliverables.

Cons
Some teams and team managers expect you to work over the week ends to meet dead lines and schedules. Most of the time tight schedules for deliverables and support issues.

Advice to Senior Management
Support periodic training and proactively invest in employee skills development. Remove confusion around yearly performance reviews process.Improve quality in deliverables and service engagements.

Environment. Benefits. Work life balance. And at times, good quality work.

Cons
Lack of learning opportunities - most of the time involved in integration of acquired products into the company. Frequent lay-offs to accommodate acquisitions.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 09, 2015 10:14 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Network Engineer says "Love working at Cisco"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Network Engineer says "Love working at Cisco"

From Cisco Systems Network Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 9 Sep 2015

Pros
I love working in the Technical Services organization at Cisco in RTP, NC. There is a competitive, yet laid-back atmosphere that I really enjoy. There are many opportunities for development and coworkers and managers are very supportive and are typically quick to recognize individuals for their good work. The salary is decent but coupled with all the great benefits the overall compensation package is certainly competitive.

Cons
Skilled engineers can make a better base salary at smaller companies in the area although job stability and the benefits are likely the trade-off. Otherwise I can't think of many cons to working at Cisco.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep inspiring engineers to perform their best and never stop recognizing the high performers on your team!

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7887782.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, September 08, 2015 12:26 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer says "Average place for a Software Engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer says "Average place for a Software Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Senior Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Tue, 8 Sep 2015

Pros
Once you understand that Cisco has a multitude of drastically different groups, then you can understand that all the reviews (positive and negative) are not contradictory. This is a pro in that you can find practically any work environment you would like. Modern, agile environments, chaotic start-up like, to stable, legacy ones. Unfortunately the great ones are a bit hard to find among the mediocre. Decent work like balance, with some telecommuting the norm.

Cons
Moral has taken a beating with 4 years of consecutive LR. Management is over-bloated, despite attempts to trim down. Upward progression and salary raises are difficult with the stack rank approach. Eventually compensation lags behind industry norms, forcing good people to look elsewhere. Difficult environment to innovate. Tools and software practices lag behind industry standard by years. Too much attachment to legacy. Too much re-invention of the wheel. The culture of frugality is a bit extreme. The quarter to quarter chasing of the shareholder expectations creates a poor environment for long term strategy. Too much chasing/trailing the competition.

Advice to Senior Management
Need a coherent software strategy that isn't based on chasing the latest Senior VP's need for a legacy. Too much middle management politics, favoritism and cronyism. Lots of talk about risk taking and innovation, little to show for in reality due to unwillingness to be held accountable.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7876742.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7876742.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, September 08, 2015 11:15 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco Systems Boulder Group"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco Systems Boulder Group"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — Tue, 8 Sep 2015

Pros
Good benefits and flexible work hours. Office is located in Boulder Colorado. A lot of sharp co-workers. If you get your full bonus, compensation is decent.

Cons
Terrible local senior management. No possibility for growth. Facility keeps shrinking. Poor work/life balance - 24/7 pager duty. The site is always scrambling for work.

Advice to Senior Management
Senior management comes from Avaya and needs to learn a different style of management. Reviews are very subjective instead of objective. Also reviews are used as punishment instead of constructive feedback.

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems CRMS Network Engineer says "Great Company, Excellent Atmosphere, lacking organization"

From Cisco Systems CRMS Network Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 8 Sep 2015

Pros
Awesome company, with great name recognition, beer on fridays, tons of little perks to having the job such as discounts on utilities, free snacks, catered food at least once a week. The team is very capable and will help each other out without hesitation.

Cons
Most companies policies are black and white, it seems as though CNS (Classified Network Support) operates more in the "do what you think is best" category and it can be stressful at times.

Advice to Senior Management
Get your practices down to a science so your employees know exactly what to do in every situation.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, September 07, 2015 4:16 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Flexible work culture, but beware the politics"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Flexible work culture, but beware the politics"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2011) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Mon, 7 Sep 2015

Pros
Flexible work hours, good work from home policies. Facilities are good, great gym and cafeteria facilities. Good work life balance, rarely work on weekends except during project go lives.

Cons
Politics and outsourcing. Cisco is an outsourcing hub and has a very skewed employee to consultant ratio in some departments. (IT etc.). Expect lots of finger pointing, non accountability and immense politics. Organization goals change every year, annual lay offs. Too many old timers and entrenched silos, too much stake in retaining status quo. Speak up and be punished.

Advice to Senior Management
Organization has too many layers, corporate initiatives simply do not translate down meaningfully to the rank and file. Cut down on the outsourcing, it might be lowering costs but comes at the cost of reduced accountability, loss of expertise and lots of politics. It does not promote efficiencies.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7867312.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7867312.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, September 04, 2015 10:58 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Product Manager says "Lots of changes"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Product Manager says "Lots of changes"

From Cisco Systems Technical Product Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 4 Sep 2015

Pros
There are a lot of smart people here. New CEO seems to be moving pretty quickly. Buildings have been updated and there are lounge areas, games on each floor. Pretty good employee discounts.

Cons
Still getting used to the open floorplan and pods with 4-6 people with no storage or set locations. I have ergonomic issues so have requested an "anchor' location. Hiring standards seem to be deteriorating as my new neighbor is kind of creepy and strange - frequently talks to himself and doesn't understand boundaries. Hope this is just an aberration.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep folks informed of what's going on and provide greater transparency. Technology wise I think things are on track. Looking forward to seeing more of the Internet of Everything.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7842720.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Network Consulting Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Thu, 3 Sep 2015

Pros
Work from home and flexibility in work hours are the biggest Pros why people want to stick to with the company.

Cons
Network Consulting Engineer job is a thankless job at cisco with no great pay compared to other job roles. No one values this job role as much as they do if you were in Sales. Software Development and/or Hardware Development. Very hard to grow up if you are sincere, hard working and self starter, probably you will end up working more and nothing else. Other big companies give benefits to their employees and so does cisco, so nothing different and great in it.

Advice to Senior Management
Please take care of your Network Consulting Engineers rather than just increasing work load with less or no increase in pay. There is lot more dissatisfaction.

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Contractor/SME -- WW Sales Support says "Like many companies -- diseased in its own ways ..."
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Contractor/SME -- WW Sales Support says "Like many companies -- diseased in its own ways ..."

From Cisco Systems Contractor/SME -- WW Sales Support (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 2 Sep 2015

Pros
Generally friendly and employees do not seem to have a cutthroat attitude. People do go out of their way to help you

Cons
In terms of documentation or training or expertise, nobody knows what anybody else is doing. There may be three or four groups trying to accomplish nearly the same goals in providing training labs or POC environments, and none of the groups even know that any other exists. TOI and documentation are miserable.

Advice to Senior Management
Documentation is so bad, I truly believe it is an intentional strategy to sell classes and certifications. Inexcusable bad documentation and TOI

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, September 02, 2015 8:29 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer III says "Good place to work and learn"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer III says "Good place to work and learn"

From Cisco Systems Customer Support Engineer III (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 2 Sep 2015

Pros
Cisco TAC is a nice place to polish the technical skills, learn troubleshooting methodology, and get various kind of customer service experiences.

Cons
Many engineers after working for a certain period, start to rely on routine responses and loses the excitement on problem solving, which as a result would harm the career. So the advice is, if you want to keep working in TAC for a long time, make sure to rotate to other team or products periodically and leave the comfort zone before it became too late.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Thursday, August 27, 2015 8:29 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Architect, Enterprise/SP/Hybrid Cloud Solutions says "Best Large Corporation Job You Could Have"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Architect, Enterprise/SP/Hybrid Cloud Solutions says "Best Large Corporation Job You Could Have"

From Cisco Systems Architect, Enterprise/SP/Hybrid Cloud Solutions (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Thu, 27 Aug 2015

Pros
People. Easiest way to explain it is, at Cisco people Care. They care about the customer, they care about doing the right thing, they care about the companies vision and direction. I have sent mails to VP's and even the President of the company and have always been treated with respect and deference. That is very telling on what a true open door policy looks like. I think the greatest support for Cisco statistically is that people who work here don't leave. I'm in a high level consulting position and get constant job offers, but no other companies create as compelling and challenging of a work environment as Cisco has to offer. Absolute great company to work for, and has my highest recommendation from a 15 year industry vet who has worked for top companies around the world including Microsoft.

Cons
Typical Company cons that can all be summed up by "slow moving". But nothing that effects my job. If I ever have a blocking issue I tell management and they take care of it.

Advice to Senior Management
I see you putting a lot of focus on career development. I see you taking organizational health survey's seriously. Keep that up, it helps employees understand and feel the appreciation you have for their work. - The division of sales and services in field engagement is Cisco's number one customer satisfaction problem. - Server and Network support contracts should be converged instead of separated. Disjointed contracts create one level of Network Service and a different level (almost always less or below standard) for server services. - Clear cloud leadership and vision should be defined for all major sectors (Microsoft / Amazon / Openstack)

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7743515.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7743515.htm>

Great and super flexible work environment. For the most part you can work from home whenever you feel like it. Challenging work. Descent Salary.

Cons
Company is too big. Upper management doesn't seem to know what is going on at the bottom. The structure and groups are constantly changing. Too many products. Engineering is dominated by a mafia.

Advice to Senior Management
Cisco is a big city that has all these neighborhoods which are divided by these huge walls. No one seems to know what is happening at the other side.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7736402.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Cloud Engineer @Cisco Cloud Services says "Cloud Engineer @Cisco Cloud Services"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Cloud Engineer @Cisco Cloud Services says "Cloud Engineer @Cisco Cloud Services"

From Cisco Systems Cloud Engineer @Cisco Cloud Services (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Wed, 26 Aug 2015

Pros
Very nice employee policies, facilities are at the top of the world. Food, canteens. Work culture, work from anywhere policy is the best in world.

Cons
If your a smart/hard worker, its easy to get laid off. You are just a number and who should involve in team politics. Team lead should be your role model & manager should be always right;else you are useless for the team. Change in processes near impossible, even if it makes total sense, typical of large corporations.

Advice to Senior Management
Employee should be free to contact any peer manager and there should be a review meeting with two senior managers of his/her manager, before a employee leaves the project or company.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, August 26, 2015 10:34 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Home of Technological innovations | House of bad policies and management"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Home of Technological innovations | House of bad policies and management"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Wed, 26 Aug 2015

Pros
- The best place to dive deep into and get your hands dirty working on technology, for those who like it. - Employees are mostly well looked after, though there have been gradual cost cuttings in the last 5 years. - Management is very chaotic but the employees are very professional and maintain a good environment. - Work life balance can be awesome or horrible based on your manager.

Cons
- Management level changes are so frequent that it instils a lack of confidence in your career in the org. - Politics is everywhere. Sometimes very evident, sometimes subtle. - Vision is very high level and implementation is very chaotic. Low level employees rarely have a say in any decision. - Work life balance can be awesome or horrible based on your manager.

Advice to Senior Management
One very fixed poll for management feedback is not enough. Management needs to take an open ended anonymous feedback from the employees at every level to really have an insight into what is right and what is not.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7730780.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, August 25, 2015 8:31 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Product Manager says "Product Manager, Marketing SW"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Product Manager says "Product Manager, Marketing SW"

From Cisco Systems Product Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Tue, 25 Aug 2015

Pros
Good opportunities to do impactful work for Cisco's customers, plus great co-workers make the day-to-day work enjoyable and successful. Just an aside: Cisco's quality cafeterias serve delicious breakfasts and lunches to fuel all the extra PowerPoint slides you'll have to complete.

Cons
Management needs everything translated into PowerPoint to understand SW development status; unfortunately, they don't understand typical Agile, bug or analytics reports. It will seem like you have to do twice as much work to complete a task: once to complete the actual work product, then a second time to redo things in PowerPoint for your manager.

Advice to Senior Management
Learn some modern Agile/Scrum management skills so that your employees can be more a lot productive.

From Cisco Systems Financial Analyst (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — Tue, 25 Aug 2015

Pros

Cons
Their consistent layoffs were always a major downer amongst the team. You never knew if this was the year your position would be cut or if they would move it to the North Carolina in order 'save money'.

Advice to Senior Management

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, August 25, 2015 10:56 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer says "An amazing company with plenty of growth opportunities"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Systems Engineer says "An amazing company with plenty of growth opportunities"

From Cisco Systems Systems Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Tue, 25 Aug 2015

Pros
I have been with Cisco for 3 years and I believe overall that this is an outstanding company to work for. This is the first company I have worked for that actually recognizes, values and *compensates* you for hard work. And if you prove to management your value and contributions to the overall company, they will absolutely take care of you when it comes to things such as relocation, education, and schedule flexibility. Since collaboration technologies are a huge part of the business model, there are a lot of remote work options (i.e. work from home, road, etc.) - but this depends on your exact role in the company.

Cons
The dreaded "work/life" balance is probably the number one complaint across Cisco employees but it is what you make of it. I know plenty of people that work at Cisco and maintain a pretty close 8-5 work schedule and are highly productive; I know others that work seemingly all hours of the day and night. It's up to you, setting the level of expectation and how efficient you are. But it is extremely easy to get very wrapped up with work and leave little time for anything else.

Advice to Senior Management
Cisco has weathered the storm of numerous disruptors and market transitions over the past 30 years. To remain successful, which I have no doubt they will, they will need to continue to be aggressive on acquiring key talent, intellectual property, and not catch trends from behind (i.e. universal compute, SDN).

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7716054.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7716054.htm>

From Cisco Systems Tech Lead (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 24 Aug 2015

Pros
Big Name adds to resume. Big Lab adds to motivation initially. Big infrastructure. Flexible environment

Cons
Webex - every one (locals) wants to work/connect on webex only If teams members are sitting away you are never sure if someone is working from where. It looks good but it is not. It affects your performance too. You will always be seeking appointment. Cisco is confused elephant now. Unsure what it wants to do. Networking or Small Cell or Cloud or Data Center or Smart City or IoT. Many other company failed in past and re-focused on what they do best. Wants to become #1 IT company but using only networking product, yet doing all stuff. For it employee are mere commodities. Does not have any emotional attitudes towards them. It is flexible bcos most team at world wide so you will be on call most of time and rest in lab. Indians engineers spoil their personal life and become 24*7 slave if they can not handle it smartly. Infra looks good but once in team you will realize how hard to get good cubicles is big task. All are fitting for it, so you will end up sitting somewhere.

Advice to Senior Management
Do Business by heart. Dont run to be number 1, just do good work. Share company success with employee and just do not fire them like annual festival, instead adjust salaries. No point acquiring companies at extra price every week and firing own employees regularly.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7702031.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7702031.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, August 24, 2015 7:08 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco Worldwide Sales Internship"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Cisco Worldwide Sales Internship"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 24 Aug 2015

Pros
Unbelievable experience. I had the privilege of interning for two different companies prior to this internship. The Worldwide Sales Internship blows the other two out of the water. The training and structure of the program is impressive. You are able to communicate and work alongside actual account managers, and really make contributions to account teams. You are able to see and meet C-level executives, and be in an environment where people are always looking to help others. The managers are awesome. I'm a firm believer that this is one of the top internships offered in all of business.

Cons
Cannot think of a con.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, August 23, 2015 2:58 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Treats employees like poker chips"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer says "Treats employees like poker chips"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2014) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Sun, 23 Aug 2015

Pros
Flexible work-from-home policy. Reasonably good benefits.

Cons
Cisco is an engineering company run by Sales people. Always has and probably always will be. This shows in the way they are always chasing the cash flow instead of thinking about what lies ahead in the world of networking. This is why the missed the whole Cloud computing market and when they finally found it, they fell back on their old game of trying to lock-in the customer with a proprietary (no matter what they may say) solution. The world isn't buying that any more. Not to worry, they can just layoff staff and buy more with a technology that's currently hot.

Advice to Senior Management
Find a way to quietly retire and let your employees breath.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7692754.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7692754.htm>

Cons

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Sunday, August 23, 2015 8:47 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Cisco"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Cisco"

From Cisco Systems Marketing Manager (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sun, 23 Aug 2015

Pros
Great team environment, open to provide support and collaboration when needed. Projects that have to span teams are able to be completed because each group is held accountable for pulling their own weight.

Cons
Lack of transparency from peer reviews regarding promotions. Feeling the immediate impact of your day to day work in a company this size is not easily noted. Difficult to implement change. Process heavy day to day work.

Advice to Senior Management
Streamline the promotions process. Find a way to make end to end reporting play a role in strategy. So much energy is focused on execution - with no results based feedback taken into account on future work that needs to be done.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7689950.htm>

name is big that is only pros in this company

Full of politics and only those close to upper management are rewarded with promotions.

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Wed, 19 Aug 2015

Pros
Great employees, talented and motivated to work. Great work environment and depending one department possible to work remotely. Great technology and sometime leaning opportunities (i.e. if your schedule permits)

Cons
Unstable work environment due to constant restructuring and lay offs some of which are done without consideration for the valued talent. Individual performance is not considered when your unit falls on the chopping block. It is like cut off the the arm, and the finger is not saved. Lot of internal politic.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep your talents. Do more home work before you lay off middle managers and the reporting structure. When you lay off, remember to leave some employee to mentor the new one- for better knowledge transfer.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, August 19, 2015 5:01 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Company"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Great Company"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Wed, 19 Aug 2015

Pros
Flexibility in schedule, company culture of inclusiveness, transparency, and willingness to help one's peers are all reasons I enjoy working for this company. I have had many managers, and each one has created a positive team environment over the years... this is driven from the top down.

Cons
Like any company of its size, it can take a long time and involve a large number of people, to steer the ship. I would love for Cisco to bring to market solutions more quickly than they sometimes do.

Advice to Senior Management
Keep up the good work. Encourage transparency among your employees and support them when they are looking for other opportunity inside the company. There are a lot of jobs to go around inside Cisco, and supporting these transitions will encourage the best back fills to come your way.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7650007.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, August 19, 2015 11:28 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Losing it's way in the face of a major market disruption"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Losing it's way in the face of a major market disruption"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Wed, 19 Aug 2015

Pros
Smart people who really want to work together Great networking technology Strong industry and brad recognition Broadest networking portfolio in the industry World class supply chain Good pay and benefits

Cons
Most executives aren't prepared to lead (Think IBM in the 90s) Market is moving to a software model and Cisco is not prepared Major customers want alternate suppliers due to Cisco's historic pricing Slow to deliver customer specific features Too may silos. Like any large company, lots of political fiefdoms.. if you're in a good group, great company. If you're not it's pretty unpleasant.

Advice to Senior Management
Package half the VPs who are just vesting in place and who offer no vision other than political positioning Create a clear vision that is more that marketing (IoE and cloud is not a plan) Incent and inspire workers to stay... there's a massive talent exodus

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7645267.htm>
