From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Wednesday, August 19, 2015 7:27 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader says "technical lead"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader says "technical lead"

From Cisco Systems Technical Leader (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Wed, 19 Aug 2015

Pros
Flexibility - people can work remote somewhat, depending on your manager. However, if people don't see you in the office, people may not know who you are. When the next localized or global layoff (which is very frequent) comes, you may have the high chance to be on the list.

Cons
There are groups at Cisco which are plainly fat. There primary existences are to justify their own existences by spinning initiatives to make them look good even though there are no meets in those initiatives.

Advice to Senior Management
Changes are good. Majority of the top folks have been run the same folks for the past decades - layer 1 is done. The CEO needs to do the same on the 2 - 3 layers down.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, August 18, 2015 8:21 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Beware of Team Culture and Management"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Marketing Manager says "Beware of Team Culture and Management"

From Cisco Systems Marketing Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Tue, 18 Aug 2015

Pros
Stayed at the company because telecommuting is a great perk. But at some point, you wonder if that is enough to offset the kind of poor management and unhealthy team dynamic. Note this is dependent on the team you're on. Company culture as a whole is not bad.

Cons
Lots of strong individual contributors get promoted but I've seen too many of those promoted to people managers who make terrible bosses. The worst part is they were able to get promoted because of political savvy so even the type of bullying, micromanagement, and all sorts of management nightmares go undetected by most with their subtle harassment.

Advice to Senior Management
Get rid of the middle management. Actually make people managers accountable for their actions based on their reports' feedback.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7636349.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7636349.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Tuesday, August 18, 2015 6:19 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Product Engineer says "Good pay, bad innovation"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Product Engineer says "Good pay, bad innovation"

From Cisco Systems Product Engineer (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — 1 of 1 found this helpful — Tue, 18 Aug 2015

Pros
Competitive pay and benefits. Getting to work on products that build the worlds network infrastructure. There are tons of training classes that you can take at no cost.

Cons
Cisco has become so large that it can't effectively innovate anymore. It seems like all the new and best tech coming from Cisco is a product of recent acquisitions.

Advice to Senior Management
Stop running the company with a spreadsheet and put the engineers back in charge. Without a focus on substantial innovation and talent retention the days of Cisco leading the telecom market could come to an end.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, August 17, 2015 5:04 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Senior Director says "Great legacy, still good people, need to broaden and modernize"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Senior Director says "Great legacy, still good people, need to broaden and modernize"

From Cisco Systems Senior Director (Past Employee - 2011) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 17 Aug 2015

Pros
Incredible engineering depth in many areas -- obviously more true in networking related products, but there are very strong people in many parts of the company. The engineering / product side (CDO) is a kind place - they legitimately try to do the right things the right way. Most senior management (SVP and above) is very competent.

Cons
Promotion and growth opportunities for the rank and file are too few, with forced stack-ranking creating dis-incentives to the largest proportion of engineers (who are not deemed top 10%). Constant spin-in process for new and next-generation platforms from a very small cadre of (admittedly very talented) folks leads to morale issues in teams left to focus on legacy platforms.

Advice to Senior Management
Broaden the offerings within the data center to include full range of infrastructure (networking and compute need storage too.. both scale-up block and file as well as scale-out). Focus on adding software for scaled deployments -- archaic CLI and SNMP must go across the board. Data Center/Cloud infrastructure platforms should be combined with full-stack IAAS and PAAS for both on-premises and SP offerings.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7618874.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7618874.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, August 17, 2015 3:04 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Secure but not Challenging"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Secure but not Challenging"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Current Employee) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Mon, 17 Aug 2015

Pros
Your experience will vary significantly based on which department you work in. For most supply chain management roles, the work & life balance is exceptional and hard to give up.

Cons
The downside is that although the company's goal is to be the number one IT company in the world, there is little to none creativity encouraged, your coworkers will have been in their same role for 15+ years, and your day to day activities will not be challenging/ exciting/ motivating. I found it hard to stay fulfilled at Cisco. But depending on what you are trying to get out of your career, this might as well be listed as a pro.

Advice to Senior Management
Don't discourage creativity, disruption. Clean up the promotions process, the fact that one can only move up the ladder based on seniority is unmotivating. Talent, hard work, and risk should be rewarded not discouraged to excel. And moving up should not solely be a product of how many years you have been there.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7617389.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7617389.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, August 17, 2015 12:06 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "So big, so corporate, so so"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "So big, so corporate, so so"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 17 Aug 2015

Pros
Flexible employer, easy to work from home, six weeks vacation for Norwegian employees. Also, in many ways remarkably open in sharing information publicly for a company in this industry, which is sympathetic.

Cons
Yearly layoffs euphemized as "limited restructuring" for many years in a row, with little and mostly useless information to the organization both leading up to and after the layoffs. Lack of clear direction for many functions and products, leading to uncertainty and frustrations. In many cases horrible coordination across sites, teams, and time zones on larger projects and programs, which the org seems to struggle to admit to, pretending cross-site collaboration is a cinch.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, August 17, 2015 7:01 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Software Technical Lead says "This is a big big company - gone are the days of the "smallest large company you could know""
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Technical Lead says "This is a big big company - gone are the days of the "smallest large company you could know""

From Cisco Systems Software Technical Lead (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Mon, 17 Aug 2015

Pros
When I started at Cisco the corporate culture was all based on the premise of independent, small groups working furiously to move the company forward. I recall Chambers referring to this culture with a statement that went something along the lines of "Cisco is the largest startup around". There certainly were drawbacks to such an approach - mostly around the costs - but on balance this system worked. Cisco was a great and dynamic place to work, filled with folks who were enthusiastic about their work, excited about the future, and ready to sacrifice for a place they felt cared about their welfare. This is no longer the case. Cisco has morphed over the years into a large corporate hierarchy filled with the same political intrigues and maneuvering that plague other companies of this size. Gone is the sense that the employee matters; gone is the willingness to sacrifice; gone is the sense that the company as a whole is united. But this doesn't necessarily make Cisco a bad place to work - it's just not particularly exciting or different from other large corporate behemoth's. Nowadays, people don't come to Cisco to find groups bubbling with excitement, they come to Cisco for the stability of a large, entrenched, and healthy company with a solid compensation system. If you're comfortable with a silo'd environment, where you keep your head down and do what's asked of you than Cisco may be a good fit.

Cons
This is a large company - with large company politics, management, and stifling red-tape overhead. It can be a stable place to work, but be careful to attach yourself to projects that are focused on the corporate development plan. Failure to follow this advice will place you square in the sights for their bi-annual layoff's.

Advice to Senior Management
Work to regain the spark - break huge development teams up into small hyper functional blocks, Incentivize the employee's again with financial benefits, restart annual pay raises.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7609538.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7609538.htm>

Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Product Manager says "Cisco"

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, August 14, 2015 6:21 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader I says "Technical Leader"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Leader I says "Technical Leader"

From Cisco Systems Technical Leader I (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Fri, 14 Aug 2015

Pros
Reputable company, doesn't hurt to have them on the resume. Cisco tries to do something for their employees. Of course it's easier for big profitable company. Good work/life balance, good benefits and corporate perks.

Cons
Too much politics and too many conflicting groups of interest. Many layers of management. Not all are capable. Regular layoffs to weed out the lower 5%, I guess. Mix between Cisco veterans and more recent additions. Veterans can be lacking sense of ownership and don't really own/drive or behave like they could make a difference. Maybe that happens if one stays too long at this company.

Advice to Senior Management
Adopt more humbleness and don't rest on old laurels. Willingness to reinvent the company and break down historic power channels.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, August 14, 2015 1:04 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems IT Engineer says "IT Engineer Internship"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems IT Engineer says "IT Engineer Internship"

From Cisco Systems IT Engineer (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 14 Aug 2015

Pros
Flexible hours. As long as you get your work done, nobody cares what you do or where you do it. Lots of corporate-wide events where you get free food and booze. People are friendly and there are enough younger folk to make it interesting. I'm fairly certain everyone there gets baked on a regular basis.

Cons
Weird mix of young and old. People there longer than two years tend to stagnate. Not a lot of upward mobility, but diagonal is always an option. Campus is giant, so a car is needed. Cisco overall doesn't really change. They're trying to get into this "Internet of Everything" but they don't really know how to do it. Expect a lot of self-congratulation from the senior management.

Advice to Senior Management
Pay people what they're worth. Average salary is 90% or lower than the industry average. Meet with your employees more often. I saw my manager once this summer.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7585869.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7585869.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, August 14, 2015 8:45 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Director says "Cisco is losing the fight to attract and retain talent"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Director says "Cisco is losing the fight to attract and retain talent"

From Cisco Systems Director (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 2 of 2 found this helpful — Fri, 14 Aug 2015

Pros
(1) Flexible work environment. Can work from home (2) Salary and benefits are good (3) Still has a few good executives and leaders

Cons
(1) Cisco has been in a state of constant restructuring for the last 4 years. Roles and responsibilities can change overnight (2) Morale of employees is at an all time low. And most of the management does not seem to care (3) Cisco has lost its innovation edge. Its a company that is slowly going out of business (4) Zero career growth opportunities

Advice to Senior Management
Please recognize people for their skills and talent. Employees are paying the price for poor judgement and poor execution at the top.

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Software Engineer II says "great co-workers"

From Cisco Systems Software Engineer II (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 2.0 out of 5 — 3 of 3 found this helpful — Thu, 13 Aug 2015

Pros
Great co-workers, great place to learn, great environment, great benefits, overall lots of fun day to day. Lots of good outings as well.

Cons
terrible bureaucracy. and lack of pay and respect for their employees long term careers. So much transition that helps benefit them short term but is deceiving for long term benefits to the company

Advice to Senior Management
I know you are trying to change to a new direction but cycling through employees are a bad idea long term, good short term but you are going to kill productivity and products faster than you will start them. I am sad I had to leave before team got layoff after layoff to the point they got cut. please respect operational rigor as not just a budget tool but consider the impact and investment also to the teams and respect the people more than just a number.

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, August 10, 2015 7:52 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems IT Program Manager says "Don't even think about taking a contract position unless you want to be unemployed quickly!!!"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems IT Program Manager says "Don't even think about taking a contract position unless you want to be unemployed quickly!!!"

From Cisco Systems IT Program Manager (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 1.0 out of 5 — 5 of 5 found this helpful — Mon, 10 Aug 2015

Pros
Laid back environment, good amount of training opportunities. Good internal network, if you last for a decent amount of time and want to move around

Cons
The project I was on got terminated less than 2 months into the 18 months the contract was listed (and supposedly pre-funded) to last. The entire team was let go without notice, and Cisco (nor the agency we worked through) did not issue any notice nor severance. This is unacceptable, and a very horrible business practice that shows the management doesn't know how to plan and doesn't care about it's staff. It's understandable that contract employees ("red" badge ad Cisco calls them) are contingent, but there is no reason an 18 month project shouldn't be have guaranteed funding/payout for at least 3 months or a reasonable notice given. Many folks on the team (myself included) left permanent jobs to take what we were told was a great opportunity to join Cisco and become part of a long-term project, team, with possible conversion to full-time "blue badge" employees. I've heard numerous horror stories from other folks in my network, former employees and contractors as well as recruiters. This seems to be "business as usual" at Cisco and the cost associated with bringing in new staff and quickly getting rid of them...is very wasteful. In many other ways, I noticed the hand does not know what the foot is doing at this company, during my short time there. The team I worked with was originally a startup that Cisco acquired some years ago, they all absolutely HATED the "Cisco way of doing things", which was nearly impossible to get anything done.

Advice to Senior Management
Stop being wasteful, and plan your projects better. Simple processes such as ordering new employees a computer or creating an account should be approved and happen at the click of a button....not take two and a half weeks!!!

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7531146.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7531146.htm> 

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, August 10, 2015 6:18 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Technical Support Manager says "Job security is scary at times"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Technical Support Manager says "Job security is scary at times"

From Cisco Systems Technical Support Manager (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — 4 of 4 found this helpful — Mon, 10 Aug 2015

Pros
Excellent benefits and starting pay is competitive.

Cons
Raises are almost non-existent. Raises do occur, but they seem to be only for a small section of employees at the absolute top of the performance scale or who have made the right impression with senior leadership. So you can do a great job and not see a penny more for 3 or more years. So while the world becomes more expensive to live in, you are are having less an less expendable income. If this methodology resulted in more job security it would be worth it, but it is just Cisco&#039;s normal business model to force management into stack ranking exercises to determine who could be fired. Also, Cisco does not value most experience gained outside of Cisco. So you may have years of experience coming in the door, you will not be considered for promotions until you have gained the same experience under Cisco.

Advice to Senior Management
Implement cost of living raises at a minimum. This alone would have a dramatic effect on employee satisfaction.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7530072.htm> 


View article... <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7530072.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Monday, August 10, 2015 12:14 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Staff Software Engineer says "Staff Engineer"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Staff Software Engineer says "Staff Engineer"

From Cisco Systems Staff Software Engineer (Past Employee - 2011) — Rating 5.0 out of 5 — Mon, 10 Aug 2015

Pros
Cisco benefits and business ethics are great. They are technology leaders and have a lot of interesting work to do. They treat employees well and with respect.

Cons
Doing software in a hardware company always has the big question of whether the software is there to sell the hardware or if the software is a product in itself. This can lead to a tiring tug of war on this topic and recurring reorganizations.

Advice to Senior Management
Recognize and account for software as both marketing collateral and product. Make the hardware side pay retail for the software investment, not just to hire a head.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7525299.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Saturday, August 08, 2015 10:03 AM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Manager, Software Development says "Company trying to Re-invent itself"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Manager, Software Development says "Company trying to Re-invent itself"

From Cisco Systems Manager, Software Development (Current Employee) — Rating 3.0 out of 5 — Sat, 8 Aug 2015

Pros
- Competitive salary with good bonus plan puts them towards the high end of the pay scale - Most teams allow flex-time and working from home when needed - Excellent collaboration tools to support workers

Cons
- Annual lay-offs (6 out of last 7 years) at end of fiscal year (July) - Frequent re-organizations - Burdensome/rigid processes and design leverage from previous products stifle creativity and new approaches

Advice to Senior Management
I certainly understand the companies efforts to re-invent itself and focus on Security and Cloud but why do you overlook the talent you already have. Rather than lay-off experienced and knowledgable talent every year - why don't you work to re-train the people that got you where you are. Your people are able to twist existing products into new designs and applications - perhaps they could do it with their careers as well if given an opportunity.

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7504382.htm>

From:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews
Posted At:	Friday, August 07, 2015 1:46 PM
Conversation:	A Cisco Systems Supply Chain Operations Intern says "Great Place to Intern"
Posted To:	Glassdoor Cisco Systems Reviews

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Supply Chain Operations Intern says "Great Place to Intern"

From Cisco Systems Supply Chain Operations Intern (Past Employee - 2012) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 7 Aug 2015

Pros
I was a summer intern in the supply chain and I had a fantastic time! Great coworkers who were always willing to help, fun perks, competitive salary, and a real-world look at what industry is like. The people I worked with really made me feel appreciated too, and that was a huge plus.

Cons
While I got good experience and lots to talk about in interviews, I don't know how much my work actually helped the company. Near the end of my internship I got the feeling that the interns from the year before had done the exact same projects we were assigned to do, making it almost feel like our time was wasted. I wish our projects had more of an impact on the company.

Advice to Senior Management
Continue to have interns! You cultivate a respect and a love for your company with us. And please continue to treat us well!

Add a Comment <http://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Cisco-Systems-RVW7497354.htm>

Subject:	A Cisco Systems Employee says "Excellent place to do business research"

From Cisco Systems Employee (Past Employee - 2015) — Rating 4.0 out of 5 — Fri, 7 Aug 2015

Pros
Wonderful colleagues. Fascinating business questions. Ability to contribute data that makes a difference.

Cons
A little too political at the top, but probably no more so than any other large organization.

Advice to Senior Management
Go slow. Breathe. And do what's right.
